BREAK.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1997
Madam President this bill implements the government's election commitment to provide rollover relief for the disposal of active assets used by small businesses.

Rollover relief has been eagerly awaited by thousands of small business operators that potentially faced a capital gains tax bill when they sold an asset and sought to invest the capital in a new one. The CGT acted as an impediment to small business growth and jobs in the small business sector.

This bill demonstrates this government's strong commitment to small business. This measure provides small business with a boost of $200 million per year. The removal of the "like kind" business test and the extension of time for the acquisition of replacement assets further demonstrates our commitment to listening to the concerns of small business.
Taxpayer's eligible for the rollover relief are individuals, partners, companies and trusts.
The measures will apply to disposals of assets on or after 1 July 1997.

Madam President, the bill also implements the government's election commitment to inject $15 million per year to provide more generous tax treatment for employee share schemes in recognition of the role of employee share schemes in strengthening employee participation in Australian business. The bill will double the income tax exemption from $500 to $1000 per employee per year, with a matching increase in the deduction available to employers. This bonus to employees will be available for shares or rights acquired on or after 1 July 1996. The bill also eases the employee participation condition for employee share schemes to qualify for concessional tax treatment from 75 per cent to two thirds of employees.
Amendments to the employee share scheme provisions announced in the budget are also being made together with a number of technical amendments raised in submissions.

The bill also implements the election commitment to bring an end to the concessional 20 per cent prime cost depreciation rate for trading ships. Transitional arrangements will enable ships that already qualify for the concession to remain eligible, as will as ships in respect of which a purchase or construction contract was signed before 1 May 1996 provided the ship is delivered to the shipowner and registered in Australia before 1 July 1997.
The amendments to section 160ZZS of the Income Tax Assessment Act announced in the 1996‐97 Budget are also contained in the bill.

The bill will amend section 160ZZS to require public entities—that is, public companies, publicly traded unit trusts and mutual insurance organisations—to test for changes in the majority underlying interests in the assets of the public entity every 5 years from 20 January 1997 or where there is abnormal trading. To assist public entities to undertake these tests, streamlined rules for determining majority underlying interests will be able to be used by public entities.
Taxpayers other than public entities will not be affected by the amendment of section 160ZZS.

The pay‐as‐you‐earn provisions, and certain rebate and exemption provisions of the income tax law will be amended to replace the current references to Commonwealth education or training programs with a generic term, Commonwealth education or training payments.

The use of the general expression in the tax law to describe the Commonwealth education or training scheme payments administered by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and some other Commonwealth agencies will ensure the taxation result intended to apply to such payments is consistently achieved even when changes are made to those schemes or schemes are deleted or added.

The bill will amend Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 4) 1995 to allow companies the option to defer conversion to the class C franking account after they are paid a class C franked dividend or a trust or partnership amount with class C franking credits attached.
The bill will also amend that act to eliminate an unintended dual liability to class A franking deficit tax or franking additional tax which may arise in certain situations.

Technical amendments will also be made to the foreign source income regime, commercial debt forgiveness provisions, tax file number provisions and provisions relating to equity investments in small and medium enterprises.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill amends three Bounty Acts to achieve savings announced by the government in the 1996‐97 budget. The savings are to be achieved by the termination of the Computers Bounty and the Books Bounty with effect from 30 June 1997 and the Machine Tools and Robots Bounty with effect from 20 August 1996. The bill also extends the ships Bounty to 31 December 1997.

The government is abolishing the Computers, Books and Machine Tools and Robots bounty schemes as they have run their course and are no longer considered to be an appropriate or cost effective means of industry assistance. Recent Industry Commission reports have recommended that each of the bounty schemes be allowed to lapse on their scheduled statutory termination dates. The government has decided to terminate the schemes ahead of their scheduled dates (9 months early for the Machine Tools and Robots Bounty, 6 months for the Books Bounty and 3 and a half years for the Computers Bounty) to assist in eliminating the budget deficit.

As the Bounties are being paid at declining rates of support, in line with the reduction of general tariff levels, their impact on industry development objectives is declining in importance. The declining rates of assistance also mean that an ever increasing percentage of the total cost to the Commonwealth of each of these bounties is represented by administration and compliance costs.
I will now turn to considerations in respect of each of the affected Bounties which the government took into account in making the decision to bring them to an early end.

The decision to abolish the Computers Bounty was made because, in the government's view, there are more important factors than the bounty in determining the continuing profitability of Australia's information technology and telecommunications industries.

These factors include the fundamentals of Australia's broad economic environment, the sophistication of the Australian market place and the enormous opportunities for trade in information technology and telecommunications products and services within our region. Therefore, considering the government's need to address the budget deficit problem, it is not possible to maintain the Computers Bounty.

Moreover, I should note that following the budget announcement concerning the cessation of the Computers Bounty, the government has honoured its commitment to convene an Information Industries Taskforce.

The Taskforce, the membership of which has largely been drawn from industry, has been asked to provide advice on any alternative measures that might be pursued to ensure that the information industries are able to take advantage of emerging opportunities. In particular, in the light of the termination of the Computers Bounty from 30 June 1997, the Taskforce has been asked to consider whether, and in what form, the information technol ogy and telecommunications industries might require industry assistance from that date.

Bounty assistance for the production of books has been in place since 1969 with the current scheme operating since 1987. The Bounty was introduced to offset duties on manufacturing inputs and to enable printing companies to remain internationally competitive. The rate of bounty has declined from 20% in 1987 to its current level of 4.5%.

The Industry Commission has recently reviewed assistance for book production. In its draft report, released prior to the budget, the Commission recommended abolition of the Books Bounty when the current scheme expires on 31 December 1997. It noted that industry has improved efficiency despite reducing levels of assistance and this would be expected to continue.

The government's decision to terminate the Books Bounty from 30 June 1997, rather than budget night as originally announced, has provided industry with 6 months notice of the government's intention to terminate the bounty. The decision speeds up the process recommended by the Industry Commission and yields a small contribution to the process of fiscal consolidation in 1997‐98.

The Machine Tools and Robots Bounty scheme, which has been in place since 1 July 1985, was also the subject of a recent Industry Commission inquiry. The Commission found that the scheme could not be considered a success as it had not effectively promoted production of metal working machines nor the development of machinery for working advanced materials. It also found that the scheme had not been a significant stimulus to the export of machine tools and robotics, nor had it been effective in encouraging Australian industry to invest in advanced technology machinery. The Commission recommended that the scheme be allowed to lapse on 30 June 1997.

The government's decision to terminate the Machine Tools and Robots Bounties from 20 August 1996 merely speeds up the process recommended by the Industry Commission and yields additional savings to help balance the budget.

To minimise disruption to industry, the bill includes transitional arrangements for the Machine Tools and Robots bounty. The amendments will allow bounty to be paid on equipment already in production on budget night, or the subject of certain contracts entered into before budget night, provided that production is completed by 20 February 1997.

The Australian shipbuilding industry has established itself as a world leader in the construction of small to medium lightweight vessels. The innovative use of technology and advanced materials by the Australian shipbuilders has meant a growing market for fast ferries, which are in operation in many countries providing new services as well as replac ing the more traditional ferries. The economies of travel time savings have provided the stimulus for ferry operators to buy Australian built fast ferries. The Australian industry's share of the world fast ferry market has ranged from 25 per cent to 30 per cent in recent years.

The success of the shipbuilding industry was reported on by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) in its March 1995 report reviewing the Ships Bounty. One of the recommendations of that report was that it was now time to consider the termination of direct bounty assistance to the industry. In the context of competition from subsidised foreign shipbuilders, the government has therefore decided as an interim measure, to extend the operation of the Ships bounty to 31 December 1997.

The government will review the need for any further extension of the bounty (beyond 31 December 1997) in the second half of 1997. The progress towards implementation of the OECD Shipbuilding Agreement (which provides for the cessation of official subsidies by major shipbuilders) is being closely monitored.
I commend the bill.

DEBATE.TITLE:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated previously, in the second reading stage, the income tax legislation is very important. After all, it affects all of the taxpayers all over Australia. I was surprised—and I reiterate my surprise—that this was going to go through with a flick in non‐controversial time. The day that I see any tax law that comes before this chamber which can be regarded as non‐controversial will be the day that I should consider leaving the place.

SPEECH.PARA: This certainly is not a non‐controversial piece of legislation. It is intended to rewrite in simple terms the previous legislation. That is fine and I would like to commend Mr Nolan and his colleagues for the work they have done on this over a period of time. I also commend them for their diligence and for the fact that they have had widespread consultations but, nevertheless, at the end of the day the rewrite is simply just that; it is a rewrite. The jurisprudence that has thus far occurred is on the old piece of legislation.

What I am trying to do is to make sure that with this new rewrite that is intended just simply to rewrite the provisions of the old act to make them simpler or more easily under stood, the new words will not be able to be interpreted to the detriment of the taxpayer. Minister, we can get this over and done with in five minutes if you will agree to my amendment. The amendment is absolutely non‐controversial, surely, unless somebody has got it in for the taxpayer. The amendment simply says that the rewritten act is not to disadvantage the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it encourages tax planning, doesn't it?
—No, it does not.
—It does; it gives them another year.

—I'm sorry; I misunderstood you. You are talking about the amendment to delay the operative date. I am happy if you want to press that. It is of concern to me, but I will let that go. I am talking about the essence of ensuring that there is no disadvantage to the taxpayer. My amendment reads:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Rewritten Act not to disadvantage taxpayer

SPEECH.PARA: It is hereby declared that nothing in this Act:

(a) makes a person liable to pay income tax if, under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, that person would not be liable to pay income tax; or

(b) makes a person liable to pay a higher amount of income tax than that person would be liable to pay under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force immediately before the commencement of this Act.

What is wrong with that? I ask the minister: are you saying that this legislation that is now before us is to be interpreted as not in any way disadvantaging the taxpayer by reference to the 1936 act? I want this very clear statement by the minister and I want to know how this will happen. I know he will point to the new ideas section—and that is a beauty, I might say—but I will let him point to it then I will deal with the matter further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, do you wish to move amendment No. 2 at this stage?
—Not at this stage. I would like to hear the minister's response. If he is not prepared to agree to it, we will have to tediously go through the legislation and ask some questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that you make threats like that, Senator Harradine. I would have thought that the important thing was to debate the issue and to set down the explanations so that people can understand the way this chamber is voting. I find it extraordinarily tempting, nonetheless, that, if we accepted what you are saying, we could be through this bill within a matter of minutes. I think it is more important to get the bill right. We will persist with the position which I outlined in the second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the comments that you have made in relation to the tax law improvement project and the work of Mr Nolan. Some of that flavour may not have come through your remarks last time this bill was debated. I am sure that the officers in the advisory box listen carefully to your remarks and welcome them.

In relation to your amendment headed `Rewritten Act not to disadvantage taxpayer', the first point I make is that twice the JCPA has considered this matter. I stress that this bill has been subject to very long exposure, very long debate and analysis by the JCPA. This issue has been considered on two separate occasions. My advice is that, on both those occasions, they have rejected the approach which you were outlining.

Your idea, as I understand it, is to allow taxpayers to fall back on the 1936 act if they have been disadvantaged by the rewriting of the law. This departs from the normal approach in rewrites of Commonwealth law, which is that the meaning of the rewritten law is not changed merely because different words are used. This is detailed in section 15AC of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and is repeated as clause 1-3 of the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996.

We believe that what you have proposed would lead to unnecessary confusion for taxpayers preparing their own tax returns and will have a particularly heavy impact on small businesses and tax agents who have to prepare and weigh up two potential returns. I think that is what you are saying; that they have to have two potential returns before sending one in. I think tax law is complicated enough with one Income Tax Assessment Act. Having two acts to contend with would be even worse and would probably ultimately delay the transition to the new law.

Again, I stress that what you have proposed has been considered by the JCPA. This is part of what has been a very long public exposure of this bill. This issue has been well canvassed before. The government will not be accepting the amendment which you will move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that my colleague Senator Cook was unavailable to conclude the consideration of this legislation on behalf of the opposition because of the change to the order of business for today. I do not intend to criticise the government but to highlight the difficulty that the chamber is under in sitting on a public holiday. There are committee hearings going on at the moment in respect of a range of other pieces of legislation that we are all trying to cooperate with in order to have the government's program dealt with prior to the Easter break. I hope my Tasmanian colleagues are listening to this. I note that the parliament down there does not sit on public holidays. Indeed, it does not sit very often at all from my reading of the covering of that particular parliament in recent times.

SPEECH.PARA: I concur with Senator Kemp in the reasons that he has given for not supporting the amendments that Senator Harradine has indicated he will move. As Senator Kemp has highlighted—and as Senator Cook highlighted last week in the debate on this legislation—this is a rewrite and simplification in respect to income tax legislation. It commenced under the previous Labor government I think in 1994. It is a very solid and substantial attempt, which was begun by the Labor government and we are pleased to see concluded by this government, of a simplification and rewrite of the bill.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Harradine, I certainly would be tempted to support your provision if it were drawn to our attention any particular example of disadvantage. We have not had that drawn to our attention. I certainly will be tempted to support something like this next week when we debate the superannuation surcharge. That is another issue. I do not think Senator Kemp's advisers will be looking forward to that particular debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you mean `a tax'?

—Sorry; it is a tax. I have to get this right. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) says that it is a tax. Senator Kemp slipped when he said on PM last week that it was a tax, but the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is still holding out.

BREAK.PARA: This particular no disadvantage clause reminds me of our industrial days, with a blanket no disadvantage provision. I think it is a sound principle. However, whilst you may have some information on an identifiable complainant, we certainly have not been made aware of any particular disadvantaged taxpayer. In fact, we are aware only of the general advantages to taxpayers from this significant simplification. For that general reason, and for the reasons outlined by Senator Kemp, on this occasion the Labor opposition will not be supporting Senator Harradine's proposed amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just indicate a position too, Mr Chair? The Democrats will not support this amendment either. We see it as having the capacity to be applied to every tax bill and, in effect, set up an entirely parallel tax system which we think is counterproductive to the aims of simplifying the system. Then, taken in conjunction with amendment 1, it will push the date out for a year, and it has already been deferred once. But that gives the tax planners another opportunity, which I want to deny them. So, mostly for the reason that we think it is wrong to set up a parallel tax system, the Democrats will be opposing this amendment.
—Of course, we are not setting up a parallel tax regime at all. You are falling for the statement of the minister at the table.
—I never do that.

—Oh no! Let me just ask you this: how? Are you really saying that accountants and taxpayers are going to get the 1936 Income Tax Assessment Act, or are they going to look at this simplified legislation? The point that I was making and which was not addressed by you is that, up until this stage, there has been a body of jurisprudence based on the 1936 act. What will happen, though, if a judge then sees different words and makes a different decision? Something will need to be determined. There should be something in this legislation, along the lines of my amendment, which says that nothing in the legislation should disadvantage the taxpayer.

BREAK.PARA: I am not on my own here. As a matter of fact, in the summary of the joint submission on the Tax Law Improvement Bill to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants—all of whom have ordinary taxpayers and businesses, small business and the like, as their clients—are saying, quite frankly, that this legislation could disadvantage taxpayers. That is not me saying it; these expert bodies are the ones saying it. Don't you take any notice of them?

TALK.START.PARA: —But they have their agendas too; they have their own agenda as well.
—It is not for me to imply dishonourable intentions on their behalf.
—No, just political reality.

—I am asking for you to look at political reality. You said, `What a terrible thing that in future we'll have this attached to every piece of taxation legislation that comes in; there should be no unintended disadvantage.' What a dreadful thing that would be.
—I did not say that. I said that it has the capacity to set up a parallel system.

—No, before then. Have a look at what you did say when the Hansard comes out. I am saying that it does not set up a parallel at all. It would apply only if a judge, for example, or the Taxation Office were to interpret this simplification legislation in a manner that would not have been otherwise done had the old law been retained.

BREAK.PARA: The minister points to section 1-3 of the act, which says:
(1) This Act contains provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in a rewritten form.
(a) that Act—
that is the 1936 act—
expressed an idea—
and `an idea' is an interesting concept to have in legislation; my goodness, we have some ideas at last on an income tax assessment piece of legislation—
in a particular form of words; and
(b) this Act—
this is the simplified version—
appears to have expressed the same idea in a different form of words in order to use a clearer or simpler style;
the ideas are not to be taken to be different just because different forms of words were used.

Are you suggesting that that is a fail‐safe provision? I do not think it is a fail‐safe provision at all. Looking at 1-3, which is what I have just read out, I would suggest—and I ask you, Minister, to comment on this—the effect of those words is that there is no presumption that a changed meaning is intended because different words are used.

However, that section does not create a presumption that the ideas in the 1936 act are taken to be preserved when the provisions are merely rewritten—does it? In fact, why was the word `just' included? The word `just' makes it quite clear that a small change in words may change the meaning. My question to you is: is section 1-3 really adequate to prevent major disputes and litigation arising where there is a small difference of style?

I ask you this, Minister. And consider it politically, if you would not mind, bearing in mind that there is a whole heap of people out there who will be right on your head. You are not Gareth Evans. I know what Gareth Evans, the honourable member for Jagajaga—

TALK.START.PARA: —Holt.
—Holt, is it? I know what he did in 1983, and you know what he did in 1983 to shaft the taxpayer.
—He was not the Treasurer then.
—In respect of those particular areas. No, he was Leader of the Government up here.
—I thought Senator John Button was.
—John Button was.

—I am sorry. I am bit hazy but I am almost certain that what he was doing at that time was changing tax interpretation policy by the amendment that he proposed and got through this place, an amendment to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. It certainly had a substantive result.

BREAK.PARA: At that time, there may have been some argument about what His Honour Mr Justice Barwick was doing but, leaving that aside, I am asking you, Minister, to consider quite carefully my further question. My first question is: is 1‐3 really adequate to prevent major disputes and litigations arising where there is a small difference of size? And why is the word `just' included? As I mentioned to you, the ideas are not to be taken to be different just because different forms of words were used. Secondly, should there be instead a presumption that the ideas are taken to be preserved where the words have been rewritten in a different style unless it is apparent from the use of different words that a different meaning is intended?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to answer your questions, but I think that you equally have got to start to respond to some of the issues that are part of the debate.
—I did that in the debate on the second reading.

—I do not think you did, Senator. You have been unkind enough to me on a couple of occasions, and the reality is that what your amendment is seeking to do will effectively, I believe, leave two acts to contend with. I have made the point that the tax law is complicated enough without having two acts to contend with. Frankly, as I have said before, this would only delay the transition to the new law.

SPEECH.PARA: But, Senator, I am not the only one saying this and it is not only the government saying this. The JCPA considered this very issue, and in report 345 the committee concluded that `tax law is complex enough' with one set of operative provisions and that having two sets of operative provisions to contend with `would be even worse'. And then they go on to repeat the words that I have just said. The reality is, Senator, that this is the problem that you have presented with your proposed amendment, which we are not disposed to support, and I think you really have very little support around the chamber for this.

You referred to clause 1‐3 of the bill quite appropriately, which tells you that if the same idea is being re‐enacted in different words you should not presume that a different meaning was intended. This clause is deliberately expressed in quite broad terms because it is a very general note of guidance on how the courts and others involved in interpreting the law should proceed. It tells them that they should put aside a presumption that there is a difference in meaning because an idea is expressed in simpler terms.

You raised the issue of why the word `just' is used with `because' in the clause. There will be times, Senator, when deliberate changes are also made. In fact, this bill does do some of that, but the intended changes are clear and expressed in the explanatory memorandum. So we believe that clause 1‐3 is sufficient. In the end, if people wish to take court action, they will decide to take court action and there is nothing that we can do in this chamber which will stop some determined people who rightly or wrongly may feel that they have been unjustly treated. We believe that clause 1‐3 is sufficient, and the reason for putting in the word `just', as I have set out, relates to the fact that there will be times when the deliberate changes are also made.

BREAK.PARA: Senator, I think the problem that we are facing here is that your proposal will lead to greater complexity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—For the reason that there will be two sets of laws and taxpayers, in preparing their own returns, will have to weigh up two potential returns. I have to tell you that extensive exposure was given to this bill and the government supports their recommendation. We have decided to proceed along the lines I have set out, and we will not be accepting your amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just follow that through for a minute. Minister, since the wording of the legislation on 1‐3 refers to the 1936 act and says that if this legislation before us `appears to have expressed the same idea in a different form of words in order to use a clearer or simpler style' and `the ideas are not to be taken to be different just because' et cetera, would you not agree that you are setting up a parallel regime? Because what you are saying in this legislation is that if there is a dispute then where do you go to; you go to the previous legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: That is all my amendment is doing. My amendment directs you to the previous legislation and having determined what the previous legislation would do in respect of the taxpayer then the no disadvantage clause prevails. It is ludicrous for you to accuse me of manufacturing a dual situation here when your legislation itself presupposes that the previous legislation should be looked at, doesn't it? Where do they look? They look at the 1936 act, of course, if there is any dispute.

You have not responded to my question. I asked you a question. I did accept the effect of clause 1‐3, the effect of those words—that is to say the ideas are not to be taken to be different just because different forms of words are used. Would you or would you not agree that the effect of those words is that there is no presumption that a changed meaning is intended because different words are used—yes or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think I did answer your questions. I shall have another shot at it if I did not satisfy you.
—No, just yes or no.

—Senator, I will answer the questions the way I wish to answer them. You will be able to respond. I do not know if it gives you any comfort—I hope it does—but clause 1‐3 is identical to the rule that applies for all rewrites of Commonwealth acts, I am advised. This includes the corporations law rewrite.

SPEECH.PARA: Your proposal, I believe, goes far further than the meaning that can be given to 1‐3 because there will be times when deliberate changes are made to the act. Under your proposal—and I think Senator Kernot picked this one up quite well—you could say, `We don't like that change to the act, so we will go back to the 1936 law.' That is the effect. That is why yours goes far further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!

—If it does not go far further you had better stand up and explain to the Senate why it does not. If in the budget session we make an amendment to this act, what will happen is that someone will say, `We don't like that amendment, so thanks to Senator Harradine we can go back to the 1936 law.' If that is a wrong interpretation, Senator, you had better tell me because that is my understanding of what you are saying.

SPEECH.PARA: I think you have raised what I can only describe as a furphy. Clause 1‐3, as it is currently worded, is a general note of guidance on how the courts and others interpreting the law should proceed and, to repeat, it tells them that they should put aside a presumption that there is a difference in meaning because the idea is expressed in simpler terms. That is not setting up a parallel act; that is just commonsense. I think your amendment would cause huge problems. The government certainly will not be supporting the proposal you put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last the minister has agreed with me that the effect of the words is that there is no presumption that a changed meaning is intended because different words are used. But I go to the next question which you have not answered; that is, do you agree that clause 1‐3 does not create a presumption that the ideas in the 1936 act are to be preserved when the provisions are merely rewritten? That is what I am asking you. I would like an answer to that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I think I have answered that on a couple of occasions. You have come back again. I am now turning to the adviser that you praised so highly at the start of your remarks to see whether there is any additional information we can give to you. Senator, this is a serious matter and we take it seriously. We do feel strongly that the amendment that you have put up will create two parallel acts which will add to huge complexity. With respect, I do not think you have addressed that issue. You did not address the point that I made.
—I will do so when I move my amendment. I have not even moved it yet.

—It is so fundamental to this debate and the position you are adopting. Is it correct that your clause would override any amendment that was put through to this bill, say, later this year because it would refer back to the 1936 act? You are shaking your head and I take some comfort from that, but I would like to get you on record.
—Does a shake mean yes or no?

—I think Senator Harradine was saying no. Clause 1‐3, especially the word `idea', is deliberately expressed in broad language because it is a general note as to how the courts and others involved in the interpretation of the law should proceed. I think that to me is crystal clear. I do not think there is a complexity about it. I understand it is a formulation which has been used in previous rewrites. It is the same as in the Acts Interpretation Act. You have now happened on an idea whose time I do not think will come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There are simplifications and simplifications. I can think back a couple of years to the precursor of the simplification bills, when I spoke at length. What we saw at that stage was the previous government putting in simple terms more onerous requirements which in fact, at that stage, meant that fewer people would be eligible for legitimate tax deductions, because the amount of documentation was considerably increased as a result of this so-called simplification. We do have a situation where the devil is in the detail. There are two things here; there is the ability to look carefully at the implications of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that there must be a lot of tax lawyers rubbing their hands with glee. Why would they be doing that? They would be doing that because they would realise that we know that there will be a whole new set of test cases run on the new wording. We all know that. A number of case precedents have been set up to this point of time. My understanding is that Senator Harradine's proposed amendment, at this point of time, relates to the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996. Any changes that occur after that obviously amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1996. Therefore it does not mean that the tax law is set in concrete forever. It means that it is agreed that the history of case law to the point at which we are does not have to be totally redone. We do not have to go into this situation of totally rerunning test cases, which will happen.

Over time if, for instance, the Australian Taxation Office were to see the ability to remove tax treatments and tax concessions and to reinterpret them at some stage someone would challenge that. People do not tend to go down with no comment if such reinterpretation takes place. Therefore, if you were going to get a complaint about complexity, you would probably get it from the tax professionals association, in terms of their job. But from what I hear it seems that they believe that it is going to be simpler for them to operate with the surety that that whole raft of case law does not have to be redone, does not have to be relooked at, does not have to be renegotiated, with the risk involved in rerunning test cases. In that way a lot of the cost involved with interpretation of tax law may well be kept down by the type of amendment that Senator Harradine is proposing to move. I would therefore like to indicate that Senator Harradine in this regard is not on his own, and I am prepared to support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say, Senator, you are supporting it for totally different reasons than those that Senator Harradine put up. I accept your right to support this amendment, but I have to say that the argument you have used is the total reverse of the argument that Senator Harradine used. Senator Harradine quoted a number of professional associations who were not rubbing their hands in glee, but who were unhappy with aspects of the bill.
—Yes.

—That is right. They were not rubbing their hands in glee, as you indicated. They have indicated to Senator Harradine that there are aspects of the bill which they are unhappy with. We have maintained that this bill has gone through a very long consultation process. I hear what you say, Senator.
—No, you do not. You totally misinterpreted what I said.
—No, I haven't. I will go back to Hansard . You said that they will be rubbing their hands in glee at this bill.
—`Tax lawyers'! Watch my lips—`tax lawyers'!

—`Rubbing their hands in glee'—that is what you said. I will go back to Hansard . Both of us will look with interest at what you said. The `rubbing their hands in glee' line was totally contrary to the line of Senator Harradine, who did not say that they were rubbing their hands in glee; he said that they are shaking them because they do not like it. I pointed out that all these issues have gone through the JCPA. There has been lots of discussion on this bill; it has had huge exposure. I do not know whether I can add much more to what I have already said. I respect your right to vote how you do. I see my words have failed to persuade you. A fair reading of Hansard would suggest that, in substance, you are supporting Senator Harradine's amendment for reasons which are quite different to those which he put forward. I would have to say that your reasons are almost the opposite to the reasons that he put forward.

—I object to being misinterpreted in that way. I said `tax lawyers' and I meant that. I do not mean tax professionals in the general sense. There obviously are concerns about this simplification bill by a number of tax professionals. What I suggested was that those people involved who are likely to make money out of running cases, which will inevitably occur as a result of this new bill, would be definitely rubbing their hands because they would realise that they were going to be quite busy over time. What I suggested is that, rather than suggest that a reference back to the 1936 bill would make things more difficult for other tax professionals, the indication from them is that if they have the certainty that the current case law applies, then that makes it simpler for them. You have totally misinterpreted what I was saying. In fact what I was saying was backing up what I listened to and heard from Senator Harradine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you have not the slightest bit of evidence for what you have asserted—that there will be more tax cases. I think there is general agreement that this law is written in a more straightforward language, in a simpler form. So the reverse should occur. It is no good your just standing up here and asserting something. We can assert anything. But you did not adduce any evidence whatsoever for that assertion. In fact, the counter argument is a powerful argument—that because the provisions of the law are written in a more straightforward language, in a way which is more easily understood, the very reverse will occur. So we cannot accept the arguments that you have put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the matters raised by Senator Margetts, certainly in my time in this chamber—just over 6½ years—it has always been my experience that tax and accounting professionals who are involved in the interpretation and the litigation surrounding tax law have done very well in terms of the cases that have been conducted since 1936. I have not done any particular study and I do not have any particular statistics on this, but I am sure that since 1936 the amount of litigation has generally been on the increase and will continue to increase.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not have before us any specific case where an accountant or a lawyer—people who are experts in the tax field—has been able to identify a disadvantage that will flow from this particular legislation. Given that at least part of the reason for the increasing litigation that has generally occurred since 1936 is set against the general complaints from the industry itself that the 1936 act has grown enormously in complexity and size due to changing circumstances which are, in many ways, understandable, it is certainly our hope and I think there is a reasonable expectation that the amount of litigation arising from a rewrite in a considered way will decrease over time. This matter has not been rushed. It has been dealt with broadly in its consultative phase over three years.

That is one of the reasons why Labor initiated the examination and simplification of the tax acts which, by general complaint from everyone involved in the field, were too complex. That is why this review was initiated. What we have before us is unquestionably a much simpler and more easily understood set of bills that will simplify the income tax laws in this country when they are ultimately passed and become law.

For that reason, I think the reverse is true—from your assertion, Senator Margetts, that there will be a more complex set of litigation—I certainly hope it is the case. On the advice that I have had from people in the area, we believe it is the case. For that reason and the other reasons that we have debated, we do not believe it is appropriate to support Senator Harradine's amendments on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not moved the amendments yet. We are being diverted by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp). I have asked him a number of questions and I am about to ask him a few more questions. Might I just say that Senator Margetts' remarks on this and her understanding of the taxation measures show how perceptive she is.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp, perhaps you have not heard or it did not come to your mind the case in New South Wales where an insurance company rewrote a policy in plain English terms and the insured suffered as a result. The matter came before Mr Justice Hutley—there was no ambiguity in the terms of the new contract, by the way—and Mr Justice Hutley found against the person insured. That was a plain English policy.

Frankly, I believe that Senator Margetts has hit the nail right on the head. Time will tell as to whether there is substantial litigation in respect of this matter. But the fact is that you are setting up the parallel situation because you are saying in 1‐3 that, just because of the fact that the words are different, the ideas should not be considered as being different.
I will go to another question: is it a fact that the legislation that is before us proposes that the 1936 act have a commencement date from 1 July 1997?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say the 1936 act?
—Yes.
—The 1936 act commenced from 1936. This bill commences 1 July 1997.
—In 1‐3 there is a guide to how this is to be used, I think—no, it is not.
—Page 2, is it, Senator Harradine?
—It is 1‐2 on page 2—you are correct, Madam Chair—where it says, `This act commences on 1 July 1997.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, Senator, this bill does commence on 1 July 1997. I think that is written there. I go back to an earlier point that was made. A great deal of emphasis has been put on the courts and litigation, particularly by Senator Margetts in her comments. The simpler law benefits tax agents who just want to get on with their job and with clear law. A lot of these tax agents rarely go to court. Senator Margetts, the idea is to simplify things and put it into more straightforward language.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to assist you, Senator Harradine, I have some further advice on your amendment. The advice I have is that your amendment—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Temporary Chair. No amendment has been moved. Senator Kemp has been addressing an amendment that is not before the chair.
—That is correct. At this stage, Minister, there is no amendment before the chair.

—I was just trying to assist, Senator. We are having a reasonably wide-ranging debate on this issue. No-one is trying to gazump anyone. I think you initially raised this issue. You may not have moved your amendment, but you raised the issue. I did feel that it was appropriate for a minister to respond. When you move the amendment, I will respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —We are back to the fact that this bill commences on 1 July 1997. Have a look at 995-1. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: this Act includes:
(a) the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936; and
(b) Part IVC of the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

If clause 1‐2 is enacted, the effect is that the 1936 act commences on 1 July 1997. This odd result is apparently intended, as clauses 6‐3 and 8-3 of the Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1996 state that for the 1996‐97 income year or an earlier income year, assessable income and deductions will be determined under the 1936 act. These provisions in the transitional provisions bill would appear to displace the normal rule that legislation will not be retrospective and appear to have the effect that the 1936 act, which will now commence on 1 July 1997, will retro spectively apply to determine assessable income and deductions for the previous year.

However, there are a number of obligations created under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which are apparently not dealt with under the transitional provisions bill. An example is the obligation to pay withholding tax, which is created by section 128C of the 1936 act. If you assume that income subject to withholding tax has been derived during June 1997, at present section 128C(1) creates the obligation to pay the withholding tax by 21 July 1997. If the 1936 act commences on 1 July 1997, it is possible that section 128C(1) will not create an obligation to pay withholding tax on income derived during June 1997, as this is income derived prior to the commencement of the legislation. This is very relevant.

Clause 6-3 of the transitional bill, which deals with assessable income for income years prior to 1997-98, does not cure the problem because section 128D states that income that is subject to withholding tax is not assessable income. Nor is there any provision within the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996 which appears to be relevant to this problem. It is at least a potential problem.

I ask the minister: can he point to any provisions in the transitional provisions bill which will authorise the determination of withholding tax unpaid as at 1 July 1997 and referable to income derived before that date?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an exceedingly long question and raised a number of fairly technical points. It will not surprise you that my advisers are now looking at the matters that you raised. However, the whole nature of transitional provisions is to allow for that period to make sure that people understand how this new act is going to apply.

SPEECH.PARA: You referred to clause 1-2. The context makes it clear that the act referred to is this act—that is, the 1996 bill, not the 1936 act as well. Section 995-1 begins with the words `except so far as the contrary intention appears'. The contrary intention is obvious in clause 1-2. We believe that the draftsman is clear on that point. In relation to the issue on withholding tax, I will come back to you when we have some advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the minister that clause 2-30 is headed `Gaps in the numbering'. The committee will have noticed that there are huge gaps in the numbering. On page 7, for example, the first item is 2-25, the next item is 2-30, the next item is 2-35, the next item is 2-40 and the next item is 2-45, et cetera. Clause 2-30 says:

SPEECH.PARA: There are gaps in the numbering system to allow for the insertion of new Divisions and sections.
Except where the gaps follow a regular pattern, notes are included at the end of one group of units to indicate the number of the next unit.
Why is this, Minister? Are you expecting a huge number of amendments to this legislation? How many new sections are actually planned by this government?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not too sure how this is advancing the cause, Senator. As to the gaps, a new numbering system has been developed, as you are aware.
—Isn't that for the superannuation surcharge provisions?

—Senator, you and I will lock horns on that in a few days time, and I hope you are in training for it. I look forward to the debate with considerable enthusiasm, Senator, so you get to the gym early every morning.
—You have your cappuccino at Aussies.

—I will have a couple. Senator, the numbering system allows for expansion. This issue does make sense. It went before the JCPA, and I am advised their report endorsed that system. It has to be said that from time to time tax acts and, indeed, a whole host of acts are amended, and I suspect that this act would be no different from other acts which are before the parliament. I would have to say that I do not think that you should presume anything from that, Senator. On the withholding tax issue—I do come back and answer your questions, Senator—
—Through the chair, thank you.
—Okay, Madam Chair. Madam Chair, the bill does not rewrite the withholding tax provisions of the 1936 act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would agree with Senator Kemp that there is commonsense in having a standard numbering provision that maintains the same subject matter over time. Often, from my experience with various bills before this place, provisions become known as a particular provision by virtue of their number. When we amend legislation and amend the numbers, it creates confusion because people over time come to accept a standard meaning to a particular phrase and a standard numbering.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the gaps left in the legislation for possible future amendment—despite my comments, somewhat in jest, to Minister Kemp—I think that is a good approach. There is commonsense in maintaining the standard numbering system for as long as possible because that in itself avoids some consequential confusion due to renumbering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Minister Kemp and Senator Sherry. I was just hoping that we might have got from government an idea of what they had planned. I am interested and have noted the minister's comments relating to withholding tax. All I can say is, `We shall see.'

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 1‐2 is an attempt to determine what commences on 1 July 1997. You will admit that what this does is provide for the 1936 act to commence from that date—not the standing clause that is already in existence. Proposed section 995‐1, as I pointed out before, states:
this Act includes:
(a) the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 . . .
except in Division 950 (Rules for interpreting this Act).

I assume the purpose of the exception, Minister, is that the rules for interpreting the proposed 1997 act are not to apply when interpreting the 1936 act. If it is, note that clause 2 of schedule 1 of the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996, which amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, states:

BREAK.PARA: this Act—
that is, the 1936 act—
includes:
(a) the Income Tax Assessment Act 1996 . . .
But, unlike the definition of `this act' in the 1996 act, it fails to exclude 950, that is, the interpretation provisions.

On the face of it, there seems to be a failure to match the definitions of `this act' in proposed section 995-1 with the definition of clause 2 of schedule 1 of the consequential amendments bill. The effect would appear to be that the interpretation rules contained in division 950 may apply to the 1936 act, notwithstanding the apparent intention of the exclusion set out in the definition in proposed section 995‐1. I wonder whether there is any explanation for that apparent difference or discrepancy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, a number of issues were raised there. Your questions are always long and detailed and have us dance from clause to clause, that is why we have some very proficient advisers here who are now looking at what you have said so we can provide you with a fuller and more detailed answer. I can say that clause 1‐2 has nothing to do with the commencement of the 1936 act. You keep on coming back to that. The 1936 act commenced in 1936.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, the clauses of this bill, as I have said, have gone through rigorous analysis. They have had a very long exposure. They have been before the JCPA. It sounds as though one or two accountants are not altogether happy with the bill and are looking for complexities which simply do not exist.

I have in front of me schedule 1 on page 3 of the consequential amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act. I think you referred to section 1. We do not use, as I understand it, the 1936 act to interpret the 1996 act and vice versa.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is interesting, given your previous comments. I move on to clause 4‐1, which states:

BREAK.PARA: Income tax is payable by each individual and company, and by some other entities.
Aren't certain charitable companies exempt? Why is this put in such a bland form? Also, as far as I know, income tax is not assessable on non-residents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the clause before me, and it is actually quite clear. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Income tax is payable by each individual and company, and by some other entities.
Note: The actual amount of income tax payable may be nil.

TAB.TAB: For a list of the entities that must pay income tax, see Division 9, starting at section 9‐1.

SPEECH.PARA: Do you have section 9‐1? The part of the note which says `The actual amount of income tax payable may be nil' may well cover your point. Have you read that section?

TALK.START.PARA: —I couldn't work it out.
—It seems pretty clear to me. I know Madam Chair will censure me if I do not speak through her, but you asked whether this includes charitable bodies. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Income tax is payable by each individual and company, and by some other entities.
Note: The actual amount of income tax payable may be nil.
They may well be one of those other entities. It then states:

TAB.TAB: For a list of the entities that must pay income tax, see Division 9, starting at section 9‐1.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems clear to me, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not labouring the point—
—I think you are, Senator.

—No, no, no. Clause 4‐1 says `Who must pay income tax' and then it says `The actual amount of income tax payable may be nil'. Clause 4‐5, which is headed `Meaning of you', is also very interesting. Look at clause 4‐5 and then go to clause 4-10, which is headed `How to work out how much income tax you must pay'. Clause 4-5 defines `you' as entities generally, but subclause 4-10(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: You must pay income tax for each year ending on 30 June, called the financial year .
Is that correct? Some entities are exempt and other entities will have nil taxable income because their deductions will be greater than their assessable amounts. It states:
You must pay income tax for each year ending on 30 June, called the financial year .

You must not pay income tax if you happen to be an entity which is exempt or you have deductions greater than your assessable income. Senator Kemp might think this is an odd question to ask, but it is of interest to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only suggest that Senator Harradine turn to clause 4-5, which is headed `Meaning of you'. Senator Harradine raised what the meaning of `you' is. Clause 4-5 says:

SPEECH.PARA: If a provision of this Act uses the expression you , it applies to entities generally, unless its application is expressly limited.
Note: The expression you is not used in provisions that apply only to entities that are not individuals.

Senator, I do not know what you are driving at here. You raised what `you' means, but it seems to me that it is explained quite clearly. I will turn to my advisers and they can politely nod their heads about whether this information caused any confusion in the JCPA and whether this issue was raised by any of the accounting bodies. My understanding is that the use of language was carefully considered by the JCPA and they basically endorse the way the language is used, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only difference is that we are in committee in the Senate and you are relying on what accountants or the joint committee may tell you. For your information, this is of interest to me, especially considering that you have given an explanation which proves my point. You may recall my reference to clause 4-5 defining `you' as entities generally. That is the very point that I made, Minister. Then I went to clause 4‐10, which says:

BREAK.PARA: You must pay income tax for each year ending on 30 June, called the financial year .

It is clear that some entities are exempt, and therefore they are not required to pay taxation, and that is not clear if you are looking at something very clear. I will raise another issue and I would like to hear from you on it; it is a policy matter. Clause 8‐1 is headed `General deductions'. It says:

(b) it is necessarily incurred in carrying on a *business for the purpose of gaining or producing your assessable income.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)
