—Is that HECS payment not in a whole number of cases necessarily incurred in gaining a degree which is required for the purpose of gaining or producing income?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a specific provision which overrides the general deduction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In clause 6‐1 there is a diagram. There are some diagrams in this piece of legislation. I assume the minister finds them helpful. He probably could issue colouring‐in pencils for those people who would like to see those diagrams in multicolour! To go to a serious issue: clause 6‐5 is headed `Income according to ordinary concepts (ordinary income)'. Subclause 6‐5(4) states:

SPEECH.PARA: In working out whether you have derived an amount of *ordinary income, and (if so) when you derived it, you are taken to have received the amount as soon as it is applied or dealt with in any way on your behalf or as you direct.

The word `derived' is used twice and it is in bold print. The word `received' is then used as though `received' is the equivalent of `derived'. Is there something different from the derivation intended by the use of the word `received'? The equivalent provision in section 19 of the 1936 act does not create this confusion, as it states:
Income—
or money—

shall be deemed to have been derived by a person although it is not actually paid over to him but is reinvested, accumulated, capitalised, carried to any reserve, sinking fund or insurance fund however designated, or otherwise dealt with on his behalf or as he directs.

`Receipt' is not always equivalent to `derivation', as taxpayers taxed on an accrual basis may derive income before it is received. What does the minister have to say about that? Does he think that a clear provision—that is to say, section 19 of the 1936 act—will now be replaced by a confused provision which seems to assume that `received' in all cases is the equivalent of a derivation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not find this confusing at all. Subclause 6‐5(4) states:

SPEECH.PARA: In working out whether you have derived an amount of *ordinary income, and (if so) when you derived it,—
that gives you the two cases of `derived' you refer to—
you are taken to have received the amount as soon as it is applied or dealt with in any way on your behalf or as you direct.
I am not a tax lawyer and I am not a tax accountant, but that text seems to me to be clear. I am not quite sure what you find confusing in that. You put some weight on the word `derived'. It states:
. . . when you derived it, you are taken to have received the amount as soon as it is applied or dealt with in any way on your behalf or as you direct.

We may have to agree to differ, but that seems to me to be pretty clear. I can report to you, if it gives you any comfort, that this wording was agreed to with the Corporate Tax Association as a way of resolving the issue. So it is not only my word. Apparently this matter was discussed and the agreed wording came through the Corporate Tax Association.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I do know that your response—and perhaps you could think about it—went to the question of the essential aspect that in this new provision `receipt' is used in such a way as to be read as meaning `derivation'. That is not the case under the previous legislation. Is that agreed? It is not agreed because under the previous legislation—or at least on the interpretation of the previous legislation—`receipt' was not always equivalent to `derivation' as taxpayers taxed on accruals basis may derive income before it is received. Of course, there are different applications of the taxation principles.

SPEECH.PARA: I go to my next point on 165(10). This deals with tax losses. It says:
A company cannot deduct a tax loss unless either—

and then it lists (a) or (b). I am looking at the situation where there is a change of ownership. As I understand it, this provision would deny losses in certain circumstances. Why is it equitable to deny losses if there is a change of ownership? Isn't the Australian Taxation Office getting it both ways? If there is a change of ownership, why not give the previous owner the right to deduct the tax loss?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill does not change the law as it has been commonly understood. You related to losses in a change of ownership and that has been one of the tests which has been in the bill for a long period. The loss deduction of companies has been restricted to prevent trafficking in losses. I do not think this is anything new. This is well known and it has been debated from time to time in this chamber. There have been arguments about whether ownership actually changes. The general principle is very clear and I believe it is well understood by the professions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Section 166(1) and 166‐260 deal with establishing continuity of underlying ownership for the carry forward of losses by listed public companies. Both sections, which are guides, state that the company:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does not have to trace through any complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds or special companies that are interposed between the company and the persons who control any of the voting power in the company, or who have rights to its dividend or capital.

Is that correct because sections 166‐265(2) and (3) and sections 166‐270(2) and (3), which are the operative provisions as distinct from guidelines, state that it is necessary to trace through the members where there are 50 members or fewer in the fund or special company? Why, on the face of it, are the guidelines inconsistent with the operative provisions and is it worth having them if they are misleading?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We should be very wary about jumping to conclusions about being misleading. As I said, this bill has been through quite a grinder in order to sort out areas which could be seen to be ambiguous or anomalous. I think you should be more wary about jumping to a conclusion that they are misleading. You have mentioned three sections of the act. My advisers are now looking at each of those sections and within a short period I should be in a position to respond to you.

—Be assured that I did not jump to any conclusion. I did in fact ask you whether this was the case. You may well come back and say that my assumptions are incorrect for reasons that you might like to give the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, the tracing rules are designed to assist public companies. The guide notes that you quoted are a broad introduction to the subject matter and they cannot be expected to hold all the detail which is in the subsequent sections. I think it is probably best to describe them as an entry point. Again, I would stress that a lot of consideration has gone into this bill and there has been a lot of exposure and a great deal of public debate. I think that these sorts of issues were very well canvassed during this period of time.
—Again, we will wait and see what happens. Section 165‐195 deals with an issue with which I have been interested for some considerable time. It deals with redeemable preference shares.
—Where have I heard that before?
—You have, yes. It says:

BREAK.PARA: Disregard redeemable shares.
For the purposes of a test, a person who beneficially owns redeemable shares at a time during the income year, is taken not to own the shares beneficially at that time.
Why is this legislation inconsistent with the view of Treasury as outlined in `Taxation of financial arrangements', page 86?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are looking at those two particular sections that you referred to and the Treasury paper that you also referred to. If you will bear with us, Senator, we will respond.

—Just for the information of the committee—no doubt it does not need to be for the information of the minister or his advisers because this paper was released in December 1996 by the Secretary to the Treasurer and the Commissioner of Taxation—the paper on page 86 talks about hybrid instruments in the hands of the holder and states quite clearly and categorically that cumulative preference shares—that is non‐redeemable—with fixed dividend rights are debts, and non‐redeemable, non‐cumulative preference shares with fixed dividend rights are equity. So you have here an indication that certain types of preference shares if they are redeemable at the issuer's option are equity, not debt. Here in this legislation you are presuming they are debt.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have the Treasury paper with us at the moment. I am sure we will try to lay our hands on it if you would like us to. This section simply restates section 80B part 8 of the old law, without change. What you are referring to is a Treasury paper which is about future policy proposals. That paper is out for discussion and consultation at this period of time. One is the existing position and the other is a paper to look at possible future directions. That paper is now out before the public and public responses have been sought. I do not think the two are directly comparable, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I am getting that page copied for you. It is very important. The fact of the matter is that redeemable preference shares are either equity or debt, depending upon what type of redeemable preference shares there are. What I am asking you is a direct question because this deals with a section of the Income Tax Assessment Act which says `Disregard redeemable shares'. But if those preference shares are non‐cumulative and redemption is non‐mandatory I am asking whether they are debt or equity. It is very important for a lot of people. For example, on the Telstra issue I stood in this parliament and, I thought, made out a case for the issue of those shares as redeemable preference shares.

SPEECH.PARA: We should bear in mind that the chief executive officer of Telstra has just said that the Telstra balance sheet was lazy. That is an interesting comment on its own, when you think about whether a particular hybrid instrument is debt or equity. So I am asking this question very deliberately, Mr Temporary Chairman—you as the chair of the economics committee would appreciate it. I am asking the government whether non‐cumulative preference shares, where there is a non‐mandatory redemption factor, are debt or equity and, if so—depending on what you say—how does this square with the legislation that is currently before us?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It squares with the legislation currently before us because the legislation repeats the old law without change. I recognise your interest in preference share issues, Senator Harradine. You are quite right when you say that this issue was well canvassed before the Senate. However, I am advised that the law we are debating before this chamber simply restates section 80B part 8 of the old law without change.

SPEECH.PARA: If you have another bit of paper, which I understand you do, which relates to future policy directions, I would have thought that was a debate for another day. I do not deny your interest in this matter. In fact, I think you created a lot of interest in this matter. The point I am putting to you is that what we have before us is no change in the existing law. You are interested—and, as I have said, I do not deny your right to be interested—in a discussion paper, but that is not the substance of debate before this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I really think this is a question of fact. Mr Chairman, as chairman of the economics committee, you would appreciate that this is a question of fact one way or the other. I have asked for a response to what I believe is a question of fact. I think this is very important because there will be many more people who will be interested in hybrid securities.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are looking for investment in Australia, we should have a range of opportunities for small investors as well as large investors. They are very interested in the tax treatment of the results of their investments. That is why I am asking the simple question as to whether non-mandatory redeemable preference shares or non-cumulative redeemable preference shares are debt or equity. It is a very important question when you are dealing with the taxation regime. If you do not want to answer my question with respect to this legislation, what was the situation under the previous legislation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how I can better satisfy you on this issue, Senator Harradine. We have simply rewritten the existing section to make the existing section clearer. It has been through this grinder process. Thanks to you, I suspect, Senator, I now have a copy of the `Taxation of financial arrangements: an issues paper', which refers to chapter 6, scope arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: That paper addresses the issue of hybrid instruments and classifies various types of preference shares—redeemable cumulative preference shares, non-redeemable cumulative preference shares and non-redeemable non‐cumulative preference shares with fixed dividend rights. I cannot add much more to what is in that paper. What we are debating is the existing law which stands. This paper is essentially about looking at other arrangements. Its title, `Taxation of financial arrange ments: an issues paper', indicates that it is out for discussion. It may not give you much comfort, but this section rewrites the existing law and, in substance, is exactly the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I sat on the economics committee, as I know you did, Mr Chairman, and we heard extensive evidence about redeemable preference shares. I appreciate Senator Harradine's interest in the area. However, frankly, I do not appreciate the wanderings we are now engaged in. I do not want to be overly harsh, but I do not see the relevance of this issue before the legislation that we are considering at the present time. I know that Senator Harradine has a point to make, and I think he has made it very effectively, as he usually does. However, I do not believe the issue currently being discussed before the chair is relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: I know this is important legislation. I am happy to sit here until 11 o'clock tonight without break—although I did just go to the toilet—to deal with this very important legislation, but we have to have consideration to the overall program. We have other very important legislation to consider before Easter. I certainly do not want it said that the opposition is in any way being unduly obstructive on this matter, which is what I think could emerge. We have been very restrained in our questions and contribution in this debate. I find more often than not on this issue that I am in agreement with Senator Kemp. I appeal to Senator Harradine to have some regard for the enormity of the program we have to get through before our Easter break.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point that Senator Sherry has made that we are under a great deal of pressure, but I hope we will not regret what we have done in this piece of legislation. All I am trying to get to is the bottom line: that is, the taxpayer should not be disadvantaged in any way by the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the minister cannot tell me of the tax treatment of redeemable shares, then we have a problem. I thought that was a matter of common interest, of vital public interest. The Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Kemp) is not able to tell me about that, particularly when we are talking about non-cumulative preference shares which are redeemable at the issuer's option. They are down as equity. This measure here treats them as debt, as I see it, unless the minister can tell us otherwise.

Bearing in mind the points that have been made, I have quite a number of other matters, but it is obvious that we are not getting very far. I do thank the minister for attempting to respond, but I will have a look at the responses and we will just have to see what the ultimate result will be. I have a very funny feeling that Senator Margetts's perceptive comment was really looking into the future as to what might well be—and I think she may well be right. I now seek leave to move amendments Nos 2 and 3 together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 2 (after line 26), at the end of Division 1, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1‐4 Rewritten Act not to disadvantage taxpayer

SPEECH.PARA: It is hereby declared that nothing in this Act:

(a) makes a person liable to pay income tax if, under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, that person would not be liable to pay income tax; or

(b) makes a person liable to pay a higher amount of income tax than that person would be liable to pay under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force immediately before the commencement of this Act.
Note: The Table of Sections to Division 1 is altered by adding at the end "1‐4 Rewritten Act not to disadvantage taxpayer".
(3) Page 370 (after line 25), after clause 950‐150, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 950‐155 Ambiguity in the interpretation of this Act

SPEECH.PARA: In the interpretation of this Act, any ambiguity must be construed in favour of the taxpayer and must be so construed as not to derogate from any common law right.
Note: The Table of Sections to Division 950 is altered by adding at the end "950‐155 Ambiguity in the interpretation of this Act".

I will not debate these amendments. They probably have been canvassed around the place. But I would like to respond to the minister's suggestion that this is somehow putting in place a parallel situation in that you will be referring to the 1936 act and this particular act when passed.

Quite frankly, everybody will be referring to this particular act as passed, except the Taxation Department, possibly a few accountants and, of course, the judiciary. The point I am making to you is: that is what you have done in the legislation itself. In 1.2, as we have said before, you have referred to the 1936 act. You have said that, just because there are different words in this piece of legislation, they should not be construed as meaning there are different ideas. You did not say it the other way around, but you should have. That is what you have said.

Ipso facto, you have done precisely what you have accused me of doing—and that is, you have said that there has to be a comparison made at some stage in the event of a dispute. Can't you see that? That is what you have done in your own legislation.

Then you accuse me of setting up a parallel. Obviously you have to have a parallel, if you are rewriting a piece of legislation in a simplified form; some people have to compare it at a particular stage when there is a dispute. That is what I am saying here. But I am also saying that, in that comparison, there should be no disadvantage to the taxpayer; and, if there is any ambiguity, it should be resolved and construed in favour of the taxpayer. That is all I am saying. I thought that would be a most reasonable way of saying that.

Now the minister comes back. He does not say that that is all very well, but he does say that what it then does is to say that this new act cannot then be amended in a way that would place a further burden on the taxpayer because of this piece of legislation. You have to compare that to the 1936 act.

With due respect, that is a nonsense. The courts always take cognisance of when the provision was inserted; thus, they do not assume that it was intended to take in later amendments. That is made perfectly clear. `Rewritten act not to disadvantage the taxpayer'—that is in my amendment, for goodness sake.

The statement made by the minister in opposition to the amendment falls. All I ask, through you, Mr Chairman, is that the committee pass these amendments which ensure that there is no disadvantage to taxpayers and, in the interpretation of the act, any ambiguity must be construed in favour of the taxpayer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you are quite right that we have canvassed this issue of the parallel acts quite extensively, and we will have to agree to differ. I think the Hansard record stands and, undoubtedly, there will be a few people who will be interested in that debate, as there should be.

SPEECH.PARA: We discussed also the wording of your amendment, and it is our view and the advice I have, Senator—you say that this is not correct—is that your amendment would place an indefinite cap on the amount of tax a person has to pay under the new law so that it could never exceed the amount of tax payable under the old law, regardless of what changes are made to the new law. I am sure that lawyers will argue that debate, but I think you would have to agree, Senator, that your amendment did leave itself open to that interpretation. I know you assert that that is not the case, but that is the advice I have received and I put that on the record.

In relation to the ambiguity issue, in this country specific rules have been introduced into the Acts Interpretation Act to assist judges in finding the meaning of ambiguous material. The central theme is that the parliamentary intention is the important factor to be applied and extrinsic material is available to assist. In this bill, Senator, we have a rewrite that reduces ambiguity and uncertainty. That is one of the objectives. There is no case, I believe, for taking exceptional measures as indicated in your proposal. It could not be done in the way proposed without taking stock of the existing interpretation statute, so the government will be opposing both your amendments, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated earlier and following the very extensive canvassing we have had of the particular issues that Senator Harradine in particular has raised, we will not be supporting the amendments that Senator Harradine has moved—for the same reasons that Senator Kemp has outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one area in which I disagree with Senator Kemp. I would not go quite as far as he does in saying that there would be another parallel tax system created as a consequence of Senator Harradine's amendments if they were carried. But I would certainly contend that if they were carried, there would be ongoing and, I would suggest, very complex and costly comparisons made in a parallel way. I think that would be the view of the opposition.

Our great hope—on the evidence suggested and as part of the process in the rewrite of the income tax act—is that there will be less litigation. My great hope would be that there would be no litigation, but I accept that the reality of the commercial world is such that, regrettably, lawyers, tax experts and accountants in this area always seem to find some area of debate and contention. I think that is a consequence of our legislative process.

It is the Senate's role, obviously, to try to minimise areas of doubt, particularly where there is major concern raised. But as I have said earlier on behalf of the Labor opposition, we have not had detailed, major concerns raised about this legislation. It has been through an exhaustive process which Labor began in 1994.

We have had concerns raised by a number of very important accountancy organisations. I do not question the validity of their raising their concerns but I do suspect that no matter how much consultation, how many years of rewriting and attempting to simplify, we would always have some concerned individuals and organisations in the community who would want something different.

BREAK.PARA: As Senator Kemp and I have said, this has been through an exhaustive process, three years of rewrite, and I do not really think we can afford to put aside the process because I do not think we will satisfy all of the competing interests and totally satisfy them that legislation is perfect. It is a significant improvement on what we have.

As I say, I hope we do not have—and I believe we will not have—an increase in litigation resulting from it. Our fervent hope and belief is that there will be a reduction in litigation resulting from this comprehensive, wide ranging and extensively consultative approach in the rewriting of these tax bills that will lead to a greater simplification of the system—and, particularly importantly, not just greater simplification for the purposes of the tax accountants and the tax lawyers but for the community at large to have an improved faith in our tax system and particularly our income tax system. It is necessary that it is easier for members of the community to understand and read this legislation, and that is one of the by‐products of this legislation that I hope will occur.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time we were debating the bill in the committee stage last time we were sitting I had spoken to my amendments which were to delete lines 18 to 25 of clauses 330 to 435. I gave my arguments at the time in relation to the treatment of tailings dams in mining. The government seemed to give us no clear explanation of why this was necessary and has given us no indications of where this will apply. In that argument I have asked that we not include this measure at this time, considering how little rationale has been given for the instrument and how it might lead to potential situations where something that really is not rehabilitation at all gets classified as tax deductible under rehabilitation. I seek the Senate's support in opposing those lines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, when dealing with this legislation, indicated that the opposition would not support Senator Margetts's opposi tion for two basic reasons. Firstly, there is the issue of principle and the approach to general tax legislation. This legislation before us is a massive rewrite and simplification of general tax laws. We initiated that. This government has concluded it. We applaud them for concluding the process, and it has important consequences. We have already been over the importance of the consequences in the previous contributions in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have some particular concerns about individual aspects of the tax system. We will debate those on another occasion. Senator Kemp and I are looking forward to it. That is just one area; there are other areas of concern about which we receive numerous representations. But we believe this is not the appropriate place or the time to deal with those very important issues of principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a new measure, Senator.

—I accept this is a new measure and I accept that, from your political and ideological perspective, it is an important issue. I have similar concerns about other issues, not about the particular one you raised. But I do accept that when dealing with a comprehensive rewrite of general tax law it is not the place to deal with the matter.
—What!
—That is the principle we are guided by.
—The time it is put in legislation is the time to amend it, surely.

—I hope I would not unnecessarily provoke you. I am really not trying to. I am trying to explain the principal approach we adopt. Let us go to the specific issue. Let us put aside the issue of the general principle of seeking specific amendments of issues that do concern us, quite validly—I do not question the validity of your concern. I do not agree with it but I do not question the validity of your concern from your perspective, from the people you represent in the Australian electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Cook very effectively made the point, there has been some significant improvement in the approach of the mining industry in the areas of rehabilitation. He gave an example of Alcoa in the Darling scarp, east of Perth, in respect of bauxite mining. Frankly, as Senator Cook said, the principle underlying your amendment would undermine the enormous strides that the mining industry has made, for example, the enormous improvement in rehabilitation.

It is not perfect. I accept that. I have seen some startling examples of the lack of perfection in Tasmania in respect of Mt Lyell, for example. Nevertheless, I think it is very important that we do not undermine specific measures that encourage rehabilitation that do go to ensuring the maximum reasonable safety levels. The mining industry is not perfect. I would be the first to say that. There still can be some considerable improvement, but we do not believe that that should in any way, by changing the deductions regime, be weakened. We believe, frankly, that is what your particular approach will do. For that reason, we cannot support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only assume that Senator Sherry is acting on notes that are not clear. I often find myself trying to green the agenda by adding amendments to a bill where we think a particular amendment is appropriate to change the agenda so that the views of a wider section of the community are included. I really would appreciate it if Senator Sherry could at least listen to this response because his response to what I said seemed to show little understanding of what we were trying to do.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, on many occasions when we have attempted to green the agenda by adding amendments to a bill, which we felt were appropriate, people from the government or the opposition have stood up and said, `This is a great idea but this is not the place.' The interesting thing is that this is a change to this bill at this time. This is not just a rewriting of the tax bill. There are elements in this bill which are new and this is one of them. Basically, this is the most appropriate time. It would be nice if the person who has just made statements would actually listen to the response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am discussing the issue.

—Terrific. The time when one should speak up about concerns about a change to any legislation, one would think, is when that change is made or the first time you find the community expresses some concern about it. Sometimes it is too late once a measure is put into a bill because then you are dealing with retrospective legislation or you are dealing with changing a system which industry then got used to and then you have a huge amount of pressure from industry not to take away something which has gained them benefit in the meantime.

SPEECH.PARA: The appropriate time, the right time, is to speak up when a change, which seems to have no rationale, is mooted. The government could give us no clear indications of what kind of revenue is involved. They seem to indicate there would be almost no revenue involved. That still left us in a position of not knowing what the heck they were doing putting it in in the first place. It is not about removing something that exists. Given that you have given us almost no explanation of why it is here, it is probably not appropriate to be put in because it may lead in the future to extra pressure put on to cause the construction of tailings dams of any sort to be considered as rehabilitation, which in my view, and in the view of a lot of other people in the community, is not appropriate.

When you construct a tailings dam it is generally not about rehabilitation. It is not about environmental standards. We are talking about people leaving great big holes in the ground and then saying, `Not only do we leave this great big hole in the ground but we are going to get a special tax deduction which may in the future be given the same weight as rehabilitation.' We do not think that is appropriate. We do not think we should lead to that future concept. Now is the right time to bring these issues up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of greening the agenda, I think the preferable way to have proceeded would have been to have followed the ESD working group recommendations of the previous government. These were reported in Novem ber 1991. I think they are still relevant. Recommendation 31(a) says that:

SPEECH.PARA: companies be required to lodge security bonds or similar financial instruments to ensure that the cost of rehabilitation of mine sites can be met by the miner rather than through public funding.
Recommendation 35 says:
that governments not fully release security bonds until they are satisfied that mining sites have been rehabilitated to a maintenance‐free status.

The fact of the matter is that we had this debate back in 1992. I do not think Senator Margetts was here then. That does not mean that she cannot revisit it. We are revisiting it. But we lost the debate about which way was the best way to proceed. I am going to keep saying that I think bonds are the best way to proceed, but the reality is that deductibility for partial rehabilitation is now the law.

I think it is wrong to say that you can have a deductibility for partial rehabilitation even if you had no intention of completing the work. My amendment goes to addressing the distinction between partial and full rehabilitation and what I find odious about that distinction. But to accept Senator Margetts' amendment would mean that we allow no rehabilitation at all. The political reality is that we are going to lose this debate again. I would rather we confine it to the government's interpretation of why partial rehabilitation is eligible for deductibility. Because the reality of the debate has moved on, I would prefer to support my amendment than to knock out rehabilitation totally.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not let go that remark from Senator Margetts in response to my remarks. I will be very brief; I am conscious of the time. I would contend that the construction of tailings dams is good for the environment at a mine site.
—Excuse me?

—I would contend that the construction of tailings dams, if that is the only option facing a mining operation, is a very important part of the environmental considerations and safety considerations in respect to a operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, cyanide is great for the environment; it is great for the bird life. But it is not rehabilitation. Uranium tailings dams are not good for the environment and they are not rehabilitation. They might be better than not having a tailings dam, but they are not rehabilitation. That was the point I was making. Senator Sherry made general comments such that, `Aren't the mining industry doing better things?' Yes. That is partly because of the pressure people are putting on them to make them achieve better standards. But building tailings dams is not and never was rehabilitation. Building wetlands after a mine site might potentially increase the environmental benefits, but there are also lots of areas where the digging of a hole or the building of a tailings dam is going to mean huge problems into the future—unsolved and unsolvable problems in many instances. Senator Sherry indicated that somehow or other I had missed the point in relation to rehabilitation. I would suggest that Senator Sherry might want to go back and see what rehabilitation means.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Senator Kernot's comments, I do not believe my amendment interferes with her amendment. I am happy to support her amendment in relation to partial rehabilitation. My amendment relates to the previous section; it is not actually included in there and it does not actually swallow the whole kit and caboodle, as far as I can see, in terms of rehabilitation. So I do not think it means that I am suggesting that rehabilitation is not a good thing. My amendment is page 307. Her amendment is page 308. I do not think my amendment does refer to what Senator Kernot said; that is, it wipes out all tax deductibility. I am happy to support her amendment and I would like to think that she would be happy to support mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not happy to support either amendments and I will not be supporting either amendments. This debate has been well canvassed. It was canvassed when this bill was debated previously. Senator, I think the matters you raised were well answered. You do not seem to think they were, but I thought they were rather well answered.

SPEECH.PARA: Deductions for mine site rehabilitation expenditure were introduced initially in 1991 as part of a more general initiative to protect and restore the environment. I think that was touched on in the debate that Senator Kernot raised. These measures included deductions for environmental impact statements and land degradation. The pursuit of land care and management should be encouraged, and that was the view of the government of the day. It was never intended that dams and levees integral to the rehabilitation process should be excluded from deductibility, and hence the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wasn't it?

—By contrast, tailings dams, which you raised, Senator, are part of eligible mining operations and are either deductible as allowable capital expenditure or as plant. So we will not be accepting your amendment. We think it is a good thing to encourage environmental activity. Much of the mining work is deductible. Senator, you would leave that as deductible but not provide deductions for work to rehabilitate the environment. We do not accept your view and we do not accept your logic.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened carefully to what Senator Kernot said in relation to an earlier debate in this chamber, which I have to say that I cannot fully remember. I cannot have been in the chamber at the time, but I am sure it was a very productive debate. Your amendment would disallow rehabilitation expenditure unless the mining site were fully restored. I think that is the argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not moved mine yet.

—Haven't you? I thought we might even shorten the process, dare I suggest. We will see how we go. The existing 1992 legislation recognises that it is not always to fully restore a site, yet it is sound environmental policy to do as much as is practicable. I do not whether I have jumped the gun on your amendment, but we will not be supporting yours either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 330‐440, page 308 (lines 10 to 12), omit subclause (2).

Restoring, rehabilitating (or partly rehabilitating) a site to a reasonable approximation of its condition before the mining or quarrying operations or prospecting or exploration.

I just find it hard to understand how you can partially restore something which is a reasonable approximation of its condition before the activities were carried out. I think it is bad public policy to allow the deductibility but I think it is good public policy to encourage full rehabilitation.

If you exploit something and you have benefit from that exploitation, you should be required to repair the damage. I do not think `reasonable approximation of its condition' is tight enough either, although it is better than what we used to have. It is just bad public policy. TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that having a go at rehabilitation should not be fully rewarded. Near enough is not good enough. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I would like to say a few words about this bill. The Family Law Amendment Bill 1996 implements yet another broken promise by the Howard government. In the budget, the government said it would be implementing a $40 per hour fee for voluntary mediation and counselling provided by the Family Court. This fee was due to commence on 1 January 1997 but now has been delayed. It was estimated to raise some $835,000 in 1996-97, rising to $1.9 million by 1998-99. This bill provides the mechanism to implement these measures.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that this bill does not of itself introduce this fee. Rather, it amends the Family Law Act 1975 to permit the making of regulations that will allow the Family Court to charge the fees. It also allows for the making of regulations to provide exemptions from those fees. I understand that the proposed regulations will contain exemption provisions similar to those that apply to other fees in Commonwealth courts and tribunals.

The concern that the Labor Party has about the introduction of these fees is twofold. Firstly, there are the access to justice implications of slugging families in crisis with a $40 fee for the provision of a service which, in fact, ultimately saves the government money because it helps to reduce the rate of divorce. Secondly, we are concerned at the long-term objectives underlying this bill.

The 1995-96 annual report of the Family Court shows that the court's counselling and mediation service dealt with 31,147 counselling and 416 mediation cases last financial year. About 60 per cent of the clients of the counselling service and 83 per cent of the mediation clients approached this service on a voluntary basis. In estimates it was revealed that 75 per cent of those cases were successfully resolved by the counselling and medi ation service. Were it not for the provision of these services, one can only wonder how many more divorces we might have had.

By comparison—quite regrettably, I might say—there were 49,700 divorces in the last year alone. I do not want to suggest that any number of divorces is desirable but, clearly, the number is too high. We need to find ways of reducing the number of divorces in this country. It is in this context that the imposing of cost recovery on this service is simply bad policy. Despite the fee waiver and refund provisions, which will protect the poorest in our society, most Australians who access this service will have to incur this fee. To place a barrier to accessing a service that helps keep families together and reduces the number of cases in the Family Court is simply not good policy. Not only is there the very real personal pain and financial cost of divorce, but our entire society suffers when families come asunder.

I note that Mr Kevin Andrews, the Chairman of the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, has suggested that all new couples should be given a voucher that would provide free marriage/relationship education. Why? Because, as he rightly asserts, this will build and strengthen more successful relationships. Surely the process of helping keep families together is just as worthy of such a sentiment. Or does the government believe that families in crisis should be treated differently—that they should be punished in some way for the failings of their relationships? I submit that they should not be.

The move to introduce these fees is a clear breach of the government's election commitment to the Australian people. In its law and justice policy, the coalition promised to `support and implement moves to increase counselling, conciliation and mediation options for the resolution of disputes'. A measure such as this one, which makes it harder to access mediation and counselling services, hardly `supports' or increases the options that are available to families in crisis.

In his second reading speech on the bill, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) sought to defend the government's introduction of these fees on three bases. The first was by reference to the need for fiscal consolidation—a problem that exists largely in the government's mind alone, with the exception, of course, of the $3 billion hole that their bungling of the economy has cost us. The second was by claiming that the previous Labor government had foreshadowed that it might consider such a proposal in the 1995-96 budget statements. Indeed, the portfolio budget statements for that year did state that the review of court and tribunal fees was initiated by the previous government and would examine the suitability of `fee regimes for voluntary or optional services which a court might provide'. However, the Attorney fails to say that the previous government, in light of that review, rejected the introduction of fees for these services.

Finally, he argued that failing to impose these fees was a form of discrimination for people living in rural and regional Australia. This argument ignores the fact that the Family Court provides extensive mediation and counselling services in rural and regional centres either through permanent offices or via circuits. Upon closer examination, the Attorney's rhetoric on this point is not only hollow; it is, in fact, hypocritical.

If the Attorney really cared about providing services to people in rural and regional centres, he would not have cut funding to the Family Court by some $3.5 million in the last year. These cuts have led to the closure of the Mackay and Bendigo registries, the downgrading of the Launceston registry, the reduction of judicial circuits by 30 per cent and the reduction of registrar and counselling circuits by 50 per cent.

Nor would he have cut the provision of family skills training services that were to be opened under Labor's Justice Statement this financial year in the Richmond-Tweed area, the central Murrumbidgee, Shepparton-Mooroopna, Bendigo, Ballarat, Gold Coast, Wide Bay‐Burnett or the Greenough River region. He would not have cut the adolescent and family mediation services that were to be provided this year and next year in Newcastle, the Clarence, Geelong, Whyalla and Preston. Nor would he have cut the family mediation services which were to be opened in Gosford, Newcastle, Wollongong, the northern outer suburbs of Melbourne, Geelong, Bendigo, Ipswich, Wide Bay-Burnett or Perth's south-eastern metropolitan area.

But the Attorney's insupportable arguments did not end there. In a desperate attempt to further defend his floundering case, the Attorney, in reply to speeches given by my colleagues Mr Melham, Mrs Crosio and Ms Macklin, he argued two further points. First, he argued that it was necessary for there to be greater coordination between the counselling and mediation services provided by the Family Court and those provided by the community sector. However, the Attorney failed to give any reasons as to why the imposition of a $40 per hour fee would encourage this coordination. This is the case because there is no causal nexus between the two, nor obviously could there be. Secondly, he argued that there was something inconsistent about trying to encourage people to use mediation and counselling services to avoid going to court and having those services co‐located and administered by that court.

The logical failing in this argument is again manifestly obvious. It demonstrates clearly this Attorney's complete lack of understanding of the role these services play. It first ignores the reality that many people facing difficulties in their relationships turn to the Family Court as a first point of call, simply because they do not know where else to go. Co‐locating a service which can deflect people in crisis from the doors of the court, or which provides them with another option as opposed to proceedings within a court, is, of course, one of the best forms of intervention and ultimately—hopefully—resolution that is available.

Further, by his comments Mr Williams seems unable to understand the very simple point that the referral of people to the Family Court's mediation and counselling service means that these matters are decided outside the courtroom. The Family Court and the court's mediation and counselling service are different yet complementary services. Co‐location of these services is one of the very real reasons why the counselling and medi ation service has been so successful. Mr Williams's argument is therefore logically flawed.

For the Attorney to pretend that this bill will mean fairer access to justice when he will cut some $320 million from access to justice programs over the next four years is the height of hypocrisy and must be rejected by this Senate. However, I am afraid there is still a more sinister agenda afoot here. The introduction of the fee is, I believe, the first step in a campaign to remove the Family Court's ability to provide mediation and counselling services altogether.

The Attorney‐General has said that he would like to see mediation and counselling become the primary means of dispute resolution in Australia. The truth is that well before this government came along Labor was well on its way to establishing that ideal as a reality. Only five per cent of Family Court cases are resolved by way of court imposed solutions. In the overwhelming majority of cases, the parties reach an amicable solution.

The reality of modern family law is that the court‐imposed solution is now the alternative dispute resolution mechanism. But in the last few months public attention has been focused, by the actions of this Attorney, on the role of mediation in our court system. The Attorney indicated his view on 2 October 1996, when he said:
We would like to see a reduction in the volume of mediation and counselling services provided in the court and the transfer of those to the community.

This was a view he did not derogate from in his more substantive speech to the National Press Club on 15 October 1996. I recognise that in that speech the Attorney backed down somewhat from his previous comments by committing himself to extensive consultations on the issue. Nonetheless, he said:
There is much to be said for the view that the Family Court should be freed up to concentrate on its primary function, that is to hear and determine legal disputes in family law matters.

This approach is at odds with the well recognised need to further integrate mediation into court processes. In his speech to the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration on 24 September 1996, Chief Justice Brennan said:

BREAK.PARA: Mediation and arbitration will continue to be familiar and prominent features of the system of dispute resolution in the future. There is no reason why, in the vast majority of cases, mediation should not be compulsory in the sense of being a condition of the right of any party to have the dispute brought to trial. But—
I emphasise this—

let it be court attached mediation. Either the mediator should be a court officer or a private mediator selected by the parties, or by lot or by rotation. In either case, the fees should be a charge on public revenue.

In direct response to Mr Williams's comments, and in support of the approach suggested by the chief justice, the Chair of the Family Court Council, Ms Jenny Boland, has publicly stated that the council had already advised the Attorney that the court should retain its counselling services.

Indeed, in a letter of advice to the Attorney dated 30 June 1996, and annexed to the council's 1995‐96 annual report, Ms Boland advised the Attorney of the council's view on recommendation 7.26 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues titled Funding and administration of the Family Court of Australia. It is this recommendation upon which the Attorney has based his view of the appropriateness of retaining counselling and mediation services within the court. Ms Boland said:

If implemented, this recommendation would destroy the successful conciliation aspects of the court's operation, it would hamper the settlement of matters particularly those involving children and result in the loss of a significant degree of expertise within the court which has benefited the interests of children, as the legislation requires.

The recommendation ignores the important role played by court counsellors, mediators and registrars, and omits any reference to the extent to which the conciliation services are integrated with the litigation process. It fails to differentiate between voluntary and court related counselling, each of which requires particular skills and knowledge which the court counsellors have acquired and built over the two decades of their operation.

The Council believes that what is required is the provision of appropriate primary dispute resolution processes at both the community and court levels, rather than the either/or approach adopted by the JSC.
As the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Justice Nicholson, pointed out last week:

Recent research being conducted by Professor Thea Brown and others at Monash University has demonstrated that the only intervention which clearly leads to an early and long lasting resolution of disputes involving child abuse allegations is a reliance on family reports prepared by Court counsellors and the use of child representatives. When both are used together they are even more effective. Primary dispute resolution services provided by the Family Court have obvious and direct benefits to very vulnerable families.

Even Ms Helen Disney, National Director of Relationships Australia—an organisation likely to benefit if the court's counselling and mediation services were to be privatised—recognised the fundamental flaw with the Attorney's suggested approach. She said:
The best option is for the court to continue to have counselling and mediation services because of the need for those processes to be linked with the court's case management approach.

The Family Court made similar criticisms in appendix 5 of its 1995‐96 annual report. It concluded its remarks by making an interesting point. We often talk in this place of the need to establish world's best practice in the administration of our public service: it should be no different for our courts.

Interestingly, the government of Singapore recently decided to review the use of alternative dispute resolution services attached to its courts. After studying various models in the United States, Europe and New Zealand, Singapore decided to adopt conciliation, counselling and mediation services based on those provided by the Family Court of Australia. Fiji and South Africa are currently examining the Family Court model. Surely, if these services are good enough to export, if they are thought by others to be worthy of imitation, then we should retain those services here in Australia.

It seems Mr Williams does not understand this. Rather, the Attorney prefers to disregard the plethora of expert advice warning him against the approach that he is taking. In a speech to the Victorian Court Network just last week, Mr Williams gave ample evidence that he has simply failed to listen to the experts on this issue. He indicated that, in a discussion paper he proposes to release shortly, he will canvass the establishment of a specialised agency within the Attorney-General's Department that would eventually assume responsibility for the planning, contracting and management of all non-judicial family law services. This service will take over the management of the Family Court's counselling and mediation service.

With all due respect, and as the Chief Justice of the Family Court pointed out in his speech to the same conference, the Attorney-General's Department has no experience in the day‐to‐day running of such a service. To place the management of those services in the hands of an agency that is also responsible for contracting out similar services places that agency in the centre of an extraordinary conflict of interest.

Senators, we can put into practice the advice the Attorney fails to listen to. We can stop the passage of this bill and, in doing so, we can send a strong message to the government that its old‐fashioned view that the court should be a court and nothing but a court is simply inappropriate in this day and age. The primary objective of any dispute resolution service must be to resolve disputes, and we should put in place the best mechanisms available to enable ordinary Australians to sort out their problems for themselves and as quickly and as cheaply as possible.

Counselling and mediation are an integral part of the Family Court. It is a service that must be accessible by all. The imposition of fees that this bill will allow will create an unnecessary barrier to a service which saves both individuals and the public purse money. Mr Williams has said that, on average, families in crisis will have to pay only $240 to access this service. But, even with the exemptions that are proposed under the various regulations which will protect the most pernicious in our society, $240 is a lot of money for the average Australian family to find, particularly at a time of great crisis. Surely it would be better to invest this money in saving our families now rather than paying for the considerable human and economic costs of divorce. This is particularly so when the service in question is successful in 75 per cent of cases, a standard equal to or better than any private sector counterpart. That is a demonstrably regressive measure, and I urge the Senate to reject this bill.

Finally, I draw to the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) a report that appeared in yesterday's Sunday Age which addressed the issues being canvassed by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues concerning the child support scheme. According to this report the government is considering changes to the formula used in relation to those matters. I note that the government has not made any announcement to that effect. I ask that, in the government's response to this debate, some attention be given to whether or not those reports are in fact valid. Is this government attempting to introduce measures in that scheme? When would they take effect? What is the nature of the changes proposed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew
