I could not agree more. Should this bill progress to the committee stage, I will be asking questions regarding the extent to which the government has factored in the impact of this fee upon women who have been subjected to domestic violence and I will be asking questions regarding other matters.

In the 1994-95 annual report of the Family Court of Australia, it was reported that the counselling service of the court dealt with 32,378 cases. I think that is a figure worth repeating: 32,378 cases—an increase of 7,800 on the previous year. About half of all counselling was voluntary and held before the parties filed for divorce. According to the Family Court, most of the voluntary counselling was aimed at settling issues like property and maintenance rather than at the reconciliation of relationships.

The second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) gives no indications on whom the proposed fee would be levied. I suppose the government will say that it will sort out these details when the regulations are made. But, if that is so, it is not good enough. We do not know how the fee will be imposed, whether it will be up‐front or collected at an hourly rate; nor is there any indication as to who—one or both of the parties—will pay the fee. This fee has the potential to become yet another financial issue that has to be negotiated between parties during what are ultimately quite complex financial settlements and for litigious parties to wrangle over.

To the extent that many women and some men will be in an inferior bargaining position through either domestic violence or other factors, this fee has the potential to militate against them as parties in family law proceedings. The fee that this bill would usher in would cause a cost of $40 to be levied against users of those services, or so it appears. In the 1996-97 budget statements for the Attorney-General's Department, the government expects the fee from voluntary counselling to raise $835,000 in 1996-97—rising to $1.9 million in 1998-99, being the first full financial year in which the measure will take effect.

I wish to now pay some attention to the revolutionary changes that have occurred in family law. In general legal matters there has been a welcome shift from the adversarial system of dispute resolution towards a more alternate model that seeks the agreement of the parties through counselling, mediation and conciliation. But in family law such methods are sometimes only partially welcome. Evidence has accumulated that alternative dispute resolution can in fact have a downside.

We must be careful not to embrace models as complete and total solutions. Sometimes a mix of solutions is better, because many things do have a downside. By way of example, I cite the report by Dr Hilary Astor in 1991 regarding mediation and violence against women. In cases where domestic violence had occurred, that report illustrated the inappropriateness of mediation due to the relative unequal bargaining position of the victim as against the perpetrator and the psychological disadvantages of being placed in that position. Fees for these services can work as a disincentive to enter into counselling. On that basis, these fees should be condemned. The government has obviously yet again not taken into consideration the possible social and family consequences of its revenue driven approach to deficit reduction.

Even so, the Australian Democrats do support government and community moves that divest conflict from adversarial forums and work towards using the cooperative power of individuals. It is a trend that is ushering in a cultural change for users of Family Court facilities. According to the court's annual report for 1994-95, only about five per cent of cases before the court are now litigated. If nothing else, this signifies a welcome cultural shift that is occurring towards dispute resolution in this country. Testimony to this change has come from eminent lawyers in the field such as Mr David McKenna, who has practised in the family law jurisdiction for the last 33 years in suburban Melbourne. Mr McKenna reports to us that, where previously few people used to contemplate alternative dispute mechanisms or counselling, now this is relatively the norm.

I cannot emphasise enough that what the government is seeking here is mean spirited, tight‐fisted and, in the view of the Australian Democrats, totally unnecessary. We all know prevention is better than cure. But how do you measure prevention? We will never be able to ascertain the number of suicides and domestic violence cases that will not occur because of Family Court counselling and mediation. The Family Court is not a milkable deficit reduction cow; it is a sensitive social mechanism.

Counselling and mediation are preventative measures and should be seen as buffers against costly and time consuming litigation. It stands to reason that, if these buffers are removed, or at least are made unattractive to litigants or are made more difficult to access, the focus will necessarily have to be on remedial programs and shift back to litigation. For these reasons and the reasons I have outlined earlier, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting this bill and will oppose it at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that Senators Carr and Murray have canvassed a number of matters that I had intended to canvass. I must compliment Senators Carr and Murray for their very perceptive contribution to this debate. However, I will take the time of the Senate to talk about some of the practical concerns that practitioners in the family law area in the city of Launceston have brought to my attention—Launceston being the city in which my electoral office is based.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Law Act 1975 allows couples to access counselling when, for example, pursuing legal remedies for residency—a term now used to describe custody matters—property settlement and, to a limited extent, paternity matters. Couples can at this stage access this counselling prior to legal proceedings at no cost. Couples who are directed to attend counselling after initial hearing can also access counselling at no cost. Of course this bill is not proposing to change the latter circumstance but only the former.

The advice I have received from those practitioners who have brought this matter to my attention and who have been involved in counselling within the Family Court in Launceston indicates that the process of voluntary counselling has been extremely successful and that, in the Launceston region, the statistics would show, in so far as they are kept, that there is a success rate for counselling in excess of 70 per cent, and that success can be measured in different ways. For example, couples may, by counselling, be enabled to make a resolution not to do anything regarding their issue, so the matter never proceeds in any way to litigation.

Another way in which matters can be resolved in this fashion is that couples could reach agreement which only proceeds to court to allow the agreement to be confirmed or ratified. In other words, it is a consent matter before the courts.

In both of those circumstances, the process clearly not only saves the parties costs of legal proceedings or extended legal proceedings but it also saves the Commonwealth the time and money that is involved in conducting those proceedings through the Family Court. The coalition's position is hard to understand in that context.
On 15 October, the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, Mr Daryl Williams, in an address to the National Press Club said that counselling and mediation:

. . . should be the primary dispute resolution methods in family law, with litigation only in cases that really need it. Mediation can provide a more effective, less traumatic, and less expensive option for separating couples than litigation. It involves the parties agreeing what the issues in dispute are, agreeing to a process to consider them and attempting to reach agreement, with the assistance of a neutral third party.

However, the proposal to introduce a fee structure for counselling is estimated, by the legal practitioners who advised me, to be likely to result in a substantial reduction in counselling usage at least at the initial stages—that is, prior to the commencement of proceedings. It is my understanding that the Attorney‐General proposes that a fee of $40 per hour for counselling be charged by the Family Court counselling service. I am also advised that the average counselling session length is 2.5 hours—apparently a fee of $100.

However, should people not use this option and proceed directly to court—for instance, in a defended custody case—then the court requires the development of a family report, and the production of this report takes on average three days. Therefore, the cost to the Commonwealth is higher; there is no cost recovery in those circumstances. So, what the Attorney‐General may well be doing is increasing the cost to the Commonwealth by discouraging people from seeking their own mediation without the commencement of legal proceedings first. That will not happen in every case but cost savings are cost savings and the potential is there—and there is no need to tell the Senate or the community at large that the potential cost of litigation in all these cases is extremely high.

Senator Murray touched upon some of the problems of the administration of this sort of a fee, and there are a number of issues which will need to be answered at some stage. I understand that this is proposed to be addressed some time later by regulation, but I think the Senate is entitled to have some answers to these questions before this legislation is passed—if, indeed, it is to be passed. For example, what will be the fee collection process? Will couples be required to pay up front? Will the counsellors be required to add to the distressful situations by demanding the payment up front? And, if they do not demand the money up front and they seek to recover it later, who will be liable for the fee: will the couple be jointly and severally liable? Will the person who made the appointment be liable? Will the fee be pro rata—that is, for part of an hour will a part of the $40 be attracted; and how will it be ensured that the fee is treated equitably by the couple? For example, in the situation where one partner makes an appointment for counselling and the other partner goes along with it because they think it is the right thing to do; the first partner does not turn up but the second does, who is responsible for the fee? If the second partner decides to continue without counselling anyway, who is then responsible for payment?

The coalition, I understands, expects in a full year to recover $1.9 million out of this fee charge proposal. That covers about 47,500 hours of counselling. This is an awful lot of counselling. If that estimate is in any way based on the current situation, it clearly demonstrates that this service has a very high level of usage and it is a dangerous proposition to be suggesting a change to a system of counselling which, obviously, according to the practitioners that I am informed by, has a great effect in resolving disputes and also in saving the public a significant amount of money because of the reduction in litigation in this area.

It has also been said that a fee for a service is likely to be a discouragement to use that service—and I have said that before. It is an issue which Senator Murray touched on, and I reiterate it. If people are to consider counselling and to consider the financial burden that they will face if they choose counselling, then isn't that placing a barrier in the way of the stated desirable outcome by the Attorney‐General—that is, to say to people, if you want counselling, you are going to have to pay for it?

I do have another much more fundamental concern about this process. I draw the attention of senators to the comments by the Attorney‐General when he spoke to the National Press Club on 15 October. He said:

Secondly, there is something of a contradiction between encouraging people to resolve their family law problems outside the courts, while at the same time keeping a major source of counselling, including voluntary counselling, within the Family Court.
I think that most people would prefer to deal with the whole process of separation and associated agreements over children and property outside of the court environment.
He says later:

I also note that the report last year on "Funding and Administration of the Federal Court of Australia", by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, recommended that mediation and counselling under the Family Law Act be pursued to a greater extent in the community.

He also talks about the provision of that service while having regard to the value for money for taxpayers. Everyone would agree with that, but where you have on the one hand a proposal to strike a sessional fee for a government instrumentality—and the government alone will control the level of that fee—and on the other hand a proposal to perhaps put to tender some part of that service, the next step could well be obvious; that is, the government sets the fee for its own agency, is able to tender a lower fee for the private sector and then says, `On the basis of our stated policy that there should be value for money for the consumer, it is not appropriate that the Family Court conduct any counselling because they are too dear and the service will entirely be handed out to private providers.'

That may well be the ideological bent of this government, to privatise as much of the public sector as it can, but this Senate needs to ask the question: if the Family Court Counselling Service is providing an effective service at the moment, then why tamper with it, why take the risk? We have seen this government prepared in other areas to take the risk with legislation; for example, tampering with the employment services in this country. It is prepared to take the risk with this very important and very sensitive area in a way which I think is clearly designed to ultimately privatise the whole of this counselling service.

TALK.START.PARA: —An ideological obsession.

—As Senator Carr says, one could believe this government is driven by ideological obsession and not by the logic and reality that it ought to be having regard to when it makes important public policy in this area. I would suggest that it is appropriate that the Senate have answers to some of the questions which I have posed in relation to the way this charge is proposed to work and also to the question of the very future of the Family Court Counselling Service with the regimen that is proposed to be put in place through this government's policy and that has developed since the election. It is appropriate that unless the Senate as a whole can be satisfied that there is no risk to this counselling service in the future which would result from the changes proposed, this bill ought to be defeated at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the field of justice but in the field of safety, particularly where air safety is concerned, there has been a concept abroad about affordable safety. There has been much discussion as to whether or not standards should be set at a particular level because they are affordable. There has been a very stark and proper reaction in my view to that proposition because if you are flying an aeroplane and the amount of risk you face in doing that is increased because there is a reduction in the amount of money that can be spent on your safety, you are likely to be quite upset about the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill before us, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1996, is the latest bill which imposes a premium on justice. Nobody likes the idea of affordable safety and nobody I suggest should like the idea of affordable justice; that because there is a limited budget we as citizens of this country are going to be denied the full justice to which we would otherwise be entitled. One of the concerns I have with this bill is not so much with the terms themselves but with the second reading speech because when the second reading speech is read the attitude, the philosophy and the culture behind it are of great concern.

The Family Court deals with some of the most tragic situations that could possibly be imagined. It deals with families that are torn apart; it deals with the future of children, some very young; it deals with the income of spouses. There has been a terrible reaction to the way we deal with the split‐up of families, not only in terms of the financial hardship that that imposes on lots of people but on the emotional, spiritual and cultural impact that the break‐up has on lots of people. Therefore it is proper and right that the institution that deals with these problems be properly resourced and run. It is that concept that it would be good to know was behind this latest legislation.

That is not what the second reading speech points out. The second reading speech points out that the government has to save money and if justice has to suffer as a result of that, then so be it. If you think that that is a harsh statement on my part, I will just read the first couple of paragraphs of the second reading speech. The first paragraph states:

The Family Law Amendment Bill 1996 will amend the Family Law Act 1975 to provide a power for the Governor-General in Council to make regulations which provide for fees to be charged for use of the voluntary counselling and mediation services of the Family Court.
The second paragraph states:

The amendment is part of the government's overall budget strategy to reduce the massive budget deficit that this government has inherited. The essence of the government's response to the $8 billion budget deficit black hole has been to make sensible reductions in outlays and increases in user charges to ensure that the burden of the need to reduce the deficit is shared across the whole community. To ensure a fair distribution, each area must play its part.

One of the core purposes of government is to provide justice. The three branches of government are the legislative that sets the law, the executive that carries out the law and the judiciary that interprets the law. Those three arms have been the character of government since it has been in operation.

This second reading speech says that the Family Law Amendment Bill is about reducing the efficiency with which the third arm of government can operate. It says, `We will affect or change the way in which a particular instrument—that is, mediation—is used by the third arm of government by making it more difficult to get.' We are going to charge $40 an hour for anybody who wants to go to mediation. The second reading speech does not go into how that might affect access to justice; it details the costs.

This second reading speech is not the work of a person who has great dedication to the law, as the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) of this Commonwealth has. He has a great passion for the law. This is not a speech by him; this is a speech by the sorts of people that you would find in Treasury and in Finance. It is of great concern to see a trend developing whereby people are being shut out of something as fundamental as the Family Court because a saving has to be made. The second reading speech continues:
I remind honourable members that the cost of running the Family Court is now in excess of $100 million per year.

What that says is, `Is it not outrageous that government has to pay for courts? Is it not outrageous that government has to provide the proper instruments whereby people can get justice?' The next step is to say, `Is it not outrageous that people want justice when it is going to cost?'

This is a matter of great concern. This bill is imposing penalties in terms of money on people approaching the instruments whereby justice is done. If there is one thing that stirs in our breasts, if there is one thing that we are concerned about, it is that we all get a fair deal. We are not going to get a fair deal in the way that we should because it costs $100 million a year to run the Family Court.

We spend billions on defence, and so we should; we have to protect the country. People do not get up and say, `You are spending billions, isn't it awful,' because everybody knows we have to be defended from potential foes. Should we not also be prepared to spend $100 million or even more to ensure that our fellow citizens are given what we all so passionately want: that is, justice before the tribunals of the land? The second reading speech goes on to state:

One of the major considerations favouring the imposition of fees in this area is the fact that the Commonwealth funds the Family Court to provide counselling and mediation services and also funds community based service providers which provide similar services.

They are saying, `We are very upset because we have to provide what government is all about. We have to provide instruments whereby people can be given justice. We are very upset because the government has been asked to provide instruments where people might get together and settle their disputes.' If government is not about settling disputes, if government is not about keeping peace, order and good government, what is it about?

To produce a second reading speech which complains about the function of government—an obligation set out in the constitution in section 51 to see to the peace, order and good government of the country—is not only mean spirited but also quite wrong. The second reading speech continues:
The community based sector provides those services for a fee to those who can afford to pay.
They are private organisations outside the scope of government. If people want to go to private arbitrators or private mediators, fair enough.

Private mediators have no responsibility under the constitution, by tradition, by common law or by the very essence of government to provide these things. The private sector does not have that obligation, but the government—the public sector—has. That is what government is all about. It seems to me quite ridiculous to simply say, `Because people who have no obligation to provide mediation charge for it, the government, which does have an obligation to provide it, should also charge.' The next paragraph of the second reading speech reads:

The demand for counselling mediation is such that it is not possible for all to have access to the Family Court services. In these circumstances, it is inequitable that a service is provided for a fee to some, often residents of rural and remote locations, but others, purely on the basis of geography, receive a similar service for free.

What it is saying is that where government does do its job—that is, provides what it is meant to provide under its constitutional obligations, which are the very essence of what government is all about—it does not charge, and that is in the city. But where government fails to do its job—where it does not give citizens of this country, people in rural areas, the services to which they are entitled—those services then are provided by private mediation. Further, because mediation is provided privately in those rural areas because government will not, the argument then is made: well, people back in the city where government does meet its obligation should also pay. It is an argument that twists the whole concept around; it twists the true concept on its head. It is a very bad approach.
Another part of the second reading speech states:
While counselling and mediation are important, there needs to be an adequate contribution by those who use the services of all of our courts.

In other words, if you use courts, when the government does do what is needed and has provided what it is meant to provide—and when I use the word `government' here, I mean it in the sense of the three arms of government—when it does use the taxpayer's dollars to do what the taxpayer pays it to do, and that is to govern, the argument is made: well, people should not only pay their taxes for that, but should go ahead and pay extra for using the very function that government is all about.
Looking at the last sentence on the second page of the second reading speech, it says this:

BREAK.PARA: Community based organisations also provide pro bono counselling services for those who are unable to pay.

A lot of pro bono work is done in this community. A lot of it is done by the legal profession, a profession that is often condemned and criticised—and, in most cases, wrongly. The person who wrote this second reading speech ought at least be acknowledged for this: he or she has acknowledged the vast amount of pro bono work that is done. And government is relying on pro bono work to carry out the functions that government, by its very essence, is meant to carry out.
Then on the last page of the second reading speech, the member delivering it at least has had the decency to feel a bit ashamed of what he or she has read out up to this point. It then says:
I wish to assure the House that I and the government remain committed to encouraging the use of alternative dispute resolution services.

So, having spent two-thirds of the speech talking about the need to satisfy those who count the dollars in the counting house, and having bowed down to those people and sacrificed the dictates of justice to the dictates of the dollar—having gone through that for two pages—the speaker suddenly feels a little bit ashamed and says:
I wish to assure the House that I and the government remain committed to encouraging the use of alternative dispute resolution services.
They suddenly realise, yes, the government does have an obligation. Towards the end of the second reading speech, this is said:
We are currently examining with the Family Court the most practical way of effecting collection of such a fee.

Again, they do not say, `We are currently examining with the Family Court the most just, the most fair, the most equitable way of collecting such a fee.' They say, `What is the most practical way?' They do not use the word `justice' nor the word `equity' nor the word `fairness'. They just say, `Look, how can we best get this money out of these people in the most practical way?' Forget about the issue of justice.

What is all this for? It is to save $1.7 million in a full year. I am glad that the Attorney-General did not write this speech. He is a man who has a feeling for the law, a man who has spent his professional career in forwarding the interests of justice. But it is a pity that a speech such as this should have been written in his name. I believe that it is time we as a parliament, an executive and a judiciary—all being part of the government of Australia—start to deliver our obligations without attaching a price tag to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate, following my colleague Senator Cooney, to draw attention once again to the mean spirited nature of this initiative of the government. How lousy can you get? We are looking at $1.7 million in a full financial year. That is all that this is about. My colleague referred to the second reading speech before, and I will make some reference briefly to that also.
—It was a great speech, obviously.

—A great speech—one that one would rather forget than remember, I think. This initiative of the government is about denying access to justice. It is about low income earners and other people who find themselves, at a very emotional and difficult time, a time of stress, faced with the fact that now in a voluntary situation they perhaps will have to cough up a lousy $40 an hour to go into some mediation process. Of course, this begs the question as to whether in the end it will be a voluntary mediation session or a compulsory mediation session ordered by the court—and I will address that later.

SPEECH.PARA: But undoubtedly this initiative is another broken promise by the government. It has been condemned by the Family Court, by family law practitioners and by service providers. It seems that there is no-one in favour of this, save for a few on the government side.

PARA.TAB: If anything, this initiative provides a barrier to dispute resolution rather than something which will expedite it. It raises the key issue as to who is going to pay, as I said earlier, at an emotional time for people who are in a fractured or near fractured relationship—undoubtedly, when a relationship is undergoing not only emotional but financial stress. And here we have the government trying to put onto these people a fee of $40.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $40 an hour.

—That is right. It is $40 an hour. Disgusting! In this stressful period one finds that the people are generally jockeying for a financial position which is going to be advantageous for themselves because they know that inevitably the pending breakdown in their relationship will end in divorce and then they will be fighting over the goods and chattels as to who gets what. Of course, money is all-important to them at this time. Particularly if they are in the low income area, going through mediation sessions—and I understand that it is on average about 2.4 or 2.5 times that people turn up to the sessions—at $40 an hour is a financial impost that people will not be prepared to meet.

SPEECH.PARA: The impetus behind this is that it will be a voluntary rather than compulsory counselling session. But inevitably it is something that will go by the wayside for many people, who will not enter into it on a voluntary basis when they know that they can go to the courts and have it ordered and thereby avoid the cost.

In last year's budget the government set aside money for marriage preparation and ongoing relationship programs. Whilst that was laudable in itself and an initiative which one might applaud, all they have done is take off the back end a fee, a cost, to pay for what they are now putting up front by way of marriage preparation and ongoing relationship programs. So they are robbing Peter to pay Paul.

In the confrontationist situation that people get themselves into in marriage breakdown you are looking at the need for true mediation where people are going to come together and resolve their problems. I quote from last years' annual report of the Family Court of Australia:

Through integration of mediation, the Court is encouraging its use as a primary dispute resolution procedure, not only with voluntary clients but also with litigants who have already filed an application. For the year, 83% of mediation clients approached the Court specifically to seek the Court's Mediation Service without filing any other application, whereas only 17% were referred from the Court having already filed an application.

I believe that what we are going to see as a result of this is that people will not be approaching the court for voluntary mediation and, instead of having 83 per cent—as I interpret those figures—approaching for voluntary mediation and 17 per cent being in a litigious position of having been ordered by the court to have compulsory mediation, we will see a giant reversal of those figures.

It is going to force people to file applications. It is going to force people to take an adversarial position because that is the circumstance under which they will be able to get hold of mediation paid by the court. This is clearly brought out at the last page. It is probably the only part of the unforgettable speech that Senator Cooney did not quote. The second reading speech says:
The power to levy fees only relates to those services used on a voluntary basis. Where the Family Court orders or directs that counselling take place no fee will be payable.

And that is the crux of this: where people are put in an adversarial role where they have gone down the path of saying that their relationship has broken down, then the court will be in the position to order them into mediation which will be at no cost to them. Otherwise, they are going to be faced with something that is purely on a voluntary basis where they are going to be paying $40 per hour. Particularly if they are low income earners, that will hold no joy for them because, as I have already stated, when one gets to the end of one's relationship one finds oneself counting the dollars.

I would hope that this mean‐spirited initiative by the government ends up going absolutely nowhere, because that is what it deserves. It really holds out no hope for the reconciliation process where a marriage is in the death throes or where that marriage is in real jeopardy of breaking down irreconcilably.

It is worth while to look at another part of the Family Court of Australia Annual Report 1995‐96. Attached to the financial statements, it is the simplest outline I could find of the objective of the Family Court of Australia. I quote note 1:

BREAK.PARA: The Family Court of Australia operates in Australia to serve the interests of the Australian community by providing for the just and equitable administration of justice in all matters within the Court's jurisdiction, with emphasis in its family jurisdiction on the conciliation of disputes and the welfare of children.

That is the objective of the Family Court of Australia as outlined in the annual report attachment to the financial statements. And if that is the objective, then the $40 per hour voluntary conciliation really stinks. It is something that the government should drop like a hot potato. It is something that has no place in the mediation process between these people. The government should be bending over backwards to repair whatever damage there might be in the relationships between people.

If one looks further into this annual report there is a little bit more interesting reading at page 122. It is the court's response to the joint select committee recommendations, which were released on 29 May 1996. The last paragraph on that page says:

The Court considers that most of the savings to be made from an early intervention approach are savings that have allowed it to cope with an increasing volume of work over the years without an increase in resources commensurate with that volume. Early intervention has allowed an earlier resolution of cases which would otherwise have lingered on at greater expense.

Yet here we have today, I believe, an initiative which is going to put people into a complete adversarial role if they want to avoid a charge which this particular piece of legislation seeks to levy. To me, it is really something which we could do without in this country.

If the government were serious about repairing the relationship breakdowns which occur, then this charge would not be levied for voluntary mediation. It seems to me that the emphasis must be on getting people there voluntarily rather than putting them in the adversarial role which I believe this could only do. The government's action in applying the charge on a voluntary mediation or counselling is counter productive and in direct conflict to what I have been referring to. The government's approach, in my opinion, flies in the face of the objective of the Family Court.

I believe that this piece of legislation should never have found its way into the parliament and shows how the government is being dictated to by the economic rationalists, as my colleague said, in both the finance and the Treasury areas. I believe that this legislation should sink.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in opposition to this Family Law Amendment Bill 1996 I would like to point out that the Howard government was elected on a promise to support and implement moves to increase counselling, conciliation and mediation options for the resolutions of disputes. Not only does this legislation make an absolute joke and farce of that promise, I believe the intentions are even more sinister and that this government is taking one of the first steps in destroying the Family Court altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: It is certainly going to destroy the court's mediation and counselling service and destroy an effective service that is helping to keep many families together. Only five per cent of Family Court cases are resolved by the court imposing its own solutions. In the majority of cases, the parties reach a solution or one of the parties stops putting up a fight. Many of these cases are assisted by the mediation and counselling service. In fact, in the 1995-96 year there were 31,563 such cases. The majority of those approached the service on a voluntary basis. The fact that 75 per cent of these 31,563 cases were successfully resolved shows the success of the service and the huge benefits both socially and financially, as it is the financial aspect that this government seems to be most concerned with, of this mediation counselling service to the community at large.

Isn't that the most important aspect of what this is all about—keeping families together rather than helping to increase the already high figure of over 49,000 divorces a year? Does the coalition really want to see more and more broken families and, worse still, even more and more such broken families in poor financial positions?

BREAK.PARA: It is very hard to believe the Prime Minister and his government when they go into their sanctimonious mode and extol the virtues of the family unit and how important it is to the Australian community. They do not believe what they say. They do not really believe in helping to preserve the family unit. This is only their pretend mode for the media to make everyone believe that this is what the government feels and believes in.

When it comes to the crunch this government throws all those pretences out of the window. This bill proves that they could not care less whether families stay together or not. The true nature of the coalition's support for the family unit is on display in this debate. In promoting and supporting this bill they do not support the family at all. In fact they are quite intentionally displaying a couldn't care less attitude by forcing many children to forgo the Family Court's mediation counselling service simply because they will not be able to afford to pay for it.

Whether it is $40 for each service or $90 for a private counselling service once this government forces the closure of the court counselling services the fact remains that it will severely discourage the use of any such services. The deception is that this will lead to the closure of the court counselling services. One has already closed in my home state of Queensland. The people of Mackay and surrounding areas are no longer able to use the services of the Mackay counselling subregistry.

When couples reach the stage where they contemplate legal remedies to resolve their differences, the government of the day, especially one that purportedly believes so strongly in the family unit, should be endeavouring to help these families resolve their difficulties, not putting impediments in their way. This government is asking couples who are facing difficulties in their relationships—and financial pressures usually are a significant part of their difficulties—to pay for counselling. That will only compound those problems.

This government is asking couples who might be trying to split their furniture and belongings in a fair way to pay for mediation to resolve those property settlements, thereby making it even harder for them to keep the property. Many couples may be forced to sell some of their furniture and belongings to pay the fee.

Unfortunately, it is usually women who are most financially affected by separation, due to the fact that most earn less than men or do not work at all because they are at home raising their families. They and their children will be even further financially disadvantaged by the fees that this government plans to impose on many of them. Where is this government's compassion for those families who are already going through one of the most traumatic periods of their lives? We all know that family breakdown is often racked with acrimony and bitterness, causing enormous stress and heartache to everyone involved. The answer, obviously, is that the government have no compassion. The election is over and therefore all their false compassion has disappeared.

To make matters worse, the government has given couples one more reason for mediation. Now, thanks to this government, they will also be able to fight over who is going to pay the mediation and counselling fees. I think this government has forgotten the reasons for the original introduction of court counselling and mediation services. One of the reasons was the need to reduce the expensive legal and court fees that often accompanied family law matters, and another reason was the need to reduce the workload of the family court.

If the mediation and counselling services of the court are successful in helping couples come to an agreement or in bringing them back together, isn't that what this service is all about? Shouldn't we be trying to save marriages, shouldn't we be trying to reduce the number of divorces and shouldn't we be trying to help keep families together—especially if there are children involved? Not only is this service there to assist families, it is also helping to reduce the costs of the court by reducing the number of cases the court has to hear. The service is essential to families. It is essential for the security and often protection of the children in these families, as the children are the ones who are affected the most.

In Queensland, and probably in other states, the waiting time for a court hearing is set in excess of one year from the directions hearing. I can see the workload of the Family Court increasing dramatically over the years to come. The reason for the increase in the workload will be that some couples will decide not to go through what will now be expensive counselling and mediation. Another major reason will be that couples, of their own accord, or because of advice from their lawyers, will realise that if they appear before a registrar or a judge they can be ordered to undertake mediation and counselling. When such counselling and mediation is ordered by the court it is, of course, free. So why not wait for a judge to make such an order? As a result, the workload of the courts and the extra waiting time involved will only exacerbate the marital problems and the anguish that the partners involved, and particularly the children, will be forced to endure.

In addition, this will not save the government $1.9 billion over the next few years. Instead, the extra work of the court will add costs to the system. It makes you wonder whether this was simply a Treasury slash which the minister and cabinet blindly followed without thinking the process through logically.

Families—particularly women, because they are often the losers financially—need access to free court linked mediation and counselling services. It is not only the financial savings that are important in being able to access the court's mediation and counselling services, it is also the added authority that a service connected to the court brings to the situation. This authority is extremely important for women who may be trying to escape an abusive marriage and who might be easily bullied by an aggressive partner. Chief Justice Brennan has publicly stated:

There is no reason why, in the vast majority of cases, mediation should not be compulsory in the sense of being a condition of the right of any party to have the dispute brought to trial. But let it be court mediation. Either the mediator should be a court officer or a private mediator selected by the parties, by lot or rotation. In either case, the fees should be a charge on public revenue.
Jenny Boland, Chair of the Family Law Council, has also come out strongly in favour of the retention of the court's counselling and mediation services. She has stated:

If changes such as those proposed were implemented, this recommendation would destroy the successful conciliation aspects of the Court's operation. It would hamper the settlement of matters, particularly those involving children, and result in the loss of a significant degree of expertise within the court which has benefited the interests of children, as the legislation requires.

She went on to detail how important the roles of the court councillors, mediators and registrars are and the extent to which the conciliation services are integrated with the litigation process. She also lamented the failure to differentiate between voluntary and court related counselling, each of which requires particular skills and knowledge which the court councillors have acquired and developed over a 20‐ year period. She pointed out that appropriate community and court based dispute resolution processes were both important.

This bill, if it is passed, will be a giant step backwards for Australia. It will mean that people who would benefit most from counselling and might have the greatest need for it will not seek it. It is $40 for one counselling session, $80 for two sessions and $120 for three sessions, and so on. Ordinary Australians cannot afford that. They are already going through emotional trauma and additional financial expenses because of their marital predicament. They also have to pay a fee of $460 if they are filing for divorce—a $92 or 25 per cent increase on the previous fee. Non‐ divorce application fees are $250. How much more does this government want these people to pay? Are they not going through enough anguish and financial suffering as it is?

All of this is, of course, on top of the legal aid cuts that the Attorney-General is implementing. What will happen to the 18,000 to 20,000 women who have previously received legal aid funding and the tens of thousands more who receive telephone and initial advice from duty lawyers? Now, thanks to this government, they will face the prospect of no free legal advice on family law matters and no free mediation or counselling assistance. This is a disgrace.

The government hopes to save $1.9 million per year by charging for the counselling and mediation services. I have already outlined why I believe that this figure is very doubtful. Even if $1.9 million could be saved, is this relatively small amount so important to the government and so significant that it is worth all the associated anguish and suffering to the families that it claims to represent?

On that point of reconciliation, I might point out that on 20 August last year, the Attorney-General announced:

BREAK.PARA: Meeting its election commitment to invest in the future and security of relationships, the Government will spend an additional $6.1 million over the next three years to expand the availability of preventive marriage/relationship education services. More than 81,000 additional clients will have accessed the services which support and strengthen Australian marriages and relationships.

As I understand it, to date some 34 centres have been approved across the nation for this purpose. Nothing can be clearer than that the government wants to, wherever possible, retrieve a marriage which is on the verge of breaking down. The government acknowledges that the rate of matrimonial breakdown in this country is just too high. But, of course, once people go to court, counselling is still needed and a number of issues have to be resolved which may not include the questions of reconciliation. So it is that we have had counselling services operating in the court environment.

Senators from the other side have said that, by bringing in a fee for these counselling services, you will deter people from using those services. But I put it to the opposition that in the community sector there have been fees charged for some time and that this proposed legislation is to bring about equity so that the same situation applies to those counselling services in the courts. If fees were a deterrent, why are we looking at some three times the number of people going to the community agencies rather than using the services in the Family Court of Australia? That speaks volumes, because you have more people going to the community agencies where a fee is charged than you have going to the Family Court itself.

Opposition senators also said that this fee would be an impediment to people achieving some form of reconciliation. But the figures show that some 41 per cent of litigants in the Family Court go to counselling after filing an application. At that stage you have people who are in the process of litigation because they have filed an application, and some 40-odd per cent of them are at that stage going to counselling. I would submit that the chances of achieving a reconciliation there are much slimmer than they are prior to filing an application. Of course, a fee in that instance does not strike at the heart of reconciliation at all. I put it to the opposition that that is a furphy. Indeed, so was the $240 suggested by Senator Carr, because he said a family could be looking at $240 for counselling, when what we are looking at on the grounds of parity is a fee in the region of $40 a session. This was touched on by Senator Gibbs, Senator Hogg and I think Senator O'Brien as well.

It was Senator Murray who asked how this will impact on the domestic violence, and I think Senator Gibbs raised that as well. I put it to the Senate that, in fact, most restraining orders are taken out in the Court of Petty Sessions and the various states have discrete legislation which deals with this. The greater number of applications for restraining orders come before a magistrate in a Court of Petty Sessions rather than before the Family Court, and you do not have a Family Court counselling service there in that situation. I would put to Senator Murray and other concerned senators that what you need is urgent relief in those situations, and that is what happens in the magistrate's courts. Sometimes it is not possible to even have counselling before you get to that position. But, in any event, the majority of these applications are in a Court of Petty Sessions rather than in the Family Court.

Nonetheless, regulations will be dealing with how these fees are applied. Negotiations are under way with the Family Court of Australia to work out who is to pay and how it is to be applied. At this stage—and I give no undertaking on this aspect—it is looking as though the fees could be shared equally between the parties. If one party is well off, they could pay a fee; if the other one is not, then the fee could be waived.

On that point of waiver, much has been said by the opposition in relation to the question of this fee being imposed on those who cannot afford it. Nothing could be further from the truth. What we have is a similar situation to the waiver which applies to those fees which are charged for applications in the Family Court, and some 40 per cent of applications in the Family Court are waived due to the impecuniosity of the person concerned. If you are on legal aid, if you have a health card or if you can show that your financial circumstances are such that you cannot afford the fee, the application fee will be waived. The same situation applies in relation to these proposed counselling fees. So it will not be a bar to those people who cannot afford to pay it.

The opposition stated that this was a budget measure. Senator Cooney touched on that. I say to Senator Cooney that it would be an ideal world if we could allow justice to be available without any thought as to cost. These days the judicial system is a costly system. Even the courts themselves have taken steps to restrict the hearing of cases and the unnecessary prolonging of cases. This is quite justifiably so because we only have a limited dollar to go around in relation to the judicial system. The Family Court itself costs in excess of $100 million per annum to run. It is only reasonable that this government looks at some form of cost recovery.

In relation to the filing fees, I remind honourable senators opposite that the states have a higher rate of cost recovery than the Commonwealth. In fact, the Commonwealth has recovered costs in excess of 50 per cent less than the states in relation to the running of courts. It was well overdue to look at filing fees and fees for counselling.

It is interesting to note that under the previous government a fees review was under way. In the 1995-96 estimates there was provision for these filing fees that have been mentioned and, indeed, the previous government was looking at the very same thing. I find it absolutely extraordinary that the opposition can come in here today and say, `This is the worst thing to happen to the Family Court since its inception; these fees have struck at the heart of the judicial system', because the previous government was looking at it itself. It was looking at it because of the cost of justice in this country.

These fees that have been attacked by the opposition are not being brought in because this government necessarily feels like it or just on a whim thought that it would be a good idea. It was a thought through process whereby we had to look at every aspect where there could be some cost recovery to offset the running costs of the Family Court of Australia. In that there is a safety net, as I have said, where some 40 per cent of people have had their application fees waived in the Family Court.

This question of regulations covering the fees concerned has been raised by the opposition. These regulations are disallowable. They will be subject to the scrutiny of this chamber. No doubt, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances will be having a look at these regulations. These regulations could cover the aspect of who would pay and how it would be applied and the detail would be in the regulation. There is nothing untoward in that. Throughout the whole spectrum of the federal government's jurisdiction, there are fees imposed by way of regulation. Those regulations are subject to disallowance.

This bill seeks to bring about some parity between the Family Court of Australia and the wider community and agencies such as Centacare and Relationships Australia, who charge a fee. They too have waivers, just as this proposed legislation will have a waiver provision. No-one will be disadvantaged. Although the cost recovery in the first instance is somewhat modest—I think $0.8 million in the first year and $1.9 million in the second year would be recovered—nonetheless, they would all go towards lessening the general cost of running the Family Court. It would not be done at the expense of those litigants.

Finally, I reiterate that this government is committed to primary dispute resolution. It is committed to saving those marriages which can be saved. It has announced an extra $6.1 million to be spent on that very subject. I commend the bill to the Senate.
