TALK.START.PARA: —I asked a question about related issues of the operation and effectiveness of the Child Support Act, which I think would have a particular bearing on mediation services. There was a report in the Sunday Age yesterday which said that the government is considering lowering the threshold amounts in respect of the formulas for the child support scheme. I ask: what is the validity of that report? Is the government preparing a statement in response to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, given the report was brought down in November 1994? I understand the previous government was preparing a response that was held over during the election. This government has had 12 months to do something about it. What is the situation in regard to that matter?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that the government is committed to the concept that parents have an ongoing responsibility to their children which does not end when the relationship between the parents breaks down. I am advised that the government is currently examining the outstanding recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues in regard to child support and has not made a decision as yet on that matter. I have only just been shown a copy of the article which I think Senator Carr refers to and I believe that it is incorrect.

—I am not asking for the figures, but has the government done any investigation into the amount of fees that a family in dispute and looking for the assistance of a court or tribunal might have to pay? Did the government have any idea about that before it decided to allow a fee to be charged for voluntary mediation? As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) has said, the way family intervention orders are obtained varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. A whole variety of fees may apply to a family that goes through the Family Court or through the appropriate courts in the states. As the parliamentary secretary has said, the amount of filing fees and other fees that are associated with the state courts are, in many cases, much more onerous than those charged by the Commonwealth. I was wondering whether a record or document showing these various fees could be made available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —The average number of sessions envisaged is 1.8, which I believe would be in the region of $60. I think that is something of a yardstick. Of course, that would vary, though, depending on the circumstances. When looking at this issue, the government had regard to fees charged by the various agencies in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney touched on the fact that this can vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. For instance, looking at fees charged by Centacare, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia apply different fees according to the financial situation of the people concerned. In relation to Relationships Australia, the level is again a bit different. So the government really had to look at a variety of fees which are being charged in the community and then draw from that what might be an appropriate fee. I must stress, as I indicated earlier, this has been negotiated with the Family Court and the regulations will reflect this. That is how the government approached it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray has given me a list of percentage increases in court fees and new fees introduced through the 1996 budget, and they certainly show a considerable increase. Has the government satisfied itself that the fees are not becoming so prohibitive that people who not only want to go to court but should go to court or to mediation will be shut out of that process?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whether these fees have become prohibitive is being looked at, albeit in this early stage. The filing fees were put in place in, I think, September last year. Anecdotal evidence suggests that no-one has been precluded thus far from making an application to a court, but of course it still is early days. I am not saying there is empirical evidence. All I am saying is that so far there seems to be no indication that these fees are proving to be prohibitive. I might also add that the fees charged in Family Court matters are the same as those for state and territory courts in that jurisdiction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the regulations that are being proposed pursuant to this legislation, the government has said that those who cannot afford to pay the fees will be exempt and:

SPEECH.PARA: The current provisions relating to waiver of fees for people in possession of cards entitling them to Commonwealth health benefits, those in receipt of legal aid and those who will otherwise suffer hardship will continue to apply.

What is meant by the phrase `otherwise suffer hardship'? I know that there are guidelines which apply to the Family Court. At the moment, under those guidelines some 40 per cent of all fees are waived by the Family Court.

Something that Senator Cooney just mentioned jogged my memory. We may well have a situation whereby a number of counselling sessions are required. Leaving aside mediation and court counselling, court fees are generally fixed. But we could have a situation where relationships are so intertwined and difficult to unravel that a number of counselling sessions may be needed.

You say that the average in one particular area is 1.8; but they might need five sessions of counselling. How is this to be assessed when it comes to the matter of `otherwise suffer hardship'? People who have to pay for maybe five counselling sessions may indeed find that a difficulty. Will the number of counselling sessions be taken into account in the regulations to determine whether or not a person or a couple will `otherwise suffer hardship'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My thanks to Senator Harradine for raising a good point. The matter of `otherwise suffer hardship' in this instance is similar to that applicable to the court fees, which we have been talking about. It is the registrar who would determine that. Of course, if you had numerous counselling sessions over a period, the litigants' financial circumstances could change and that could be taken into account. But I will certainly take on board Senator Harradine's query in relation to the number of counselling sessions.

SPEECH.PARA: Once you do get to the Family Court, it is not common for people to have numerous counselling sessions. You might have one or two, but it is not as if it is an ongoing situation. You might have that in cases where you have litigation which is protracted and particularly nasty, but I think those cases would be very much in the minority and that the majority of people would have one or two visits to the Family Court counsellor. So we would be dealing with a minority of cases. Nonetheless, Senator Harradine, I will take your matter up as to the number of counselling sessions and have that looked at with respect to the criterion to be applied to the waiver.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary, I did raise a couple of points in the second reading debate. I was taken out of the chamber during your contribution. I am told that you did not answer those questions. If I am wrong, I apologise in advance. I will raise again some of those points. Has the government a view as to how the charge for counselling will be levied? In particular, will it be as per court fees: charged when the request is made for counselling; will there be some sort of flag fall? A number of questions follow from that, so perhaps you can tell me what the intention is. Will there be up‐front payment before counselling or will there be a billing arrangement?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address the matter of domestic violence, which I think Senator O'Brien raised. I did touch on that matter. Suffice to say, most applications for a restraining order are made in courts of petty sessions, governed by discrete state legislation. That is a court which is not sitting as a Family Court, and that is a very different situation. You have immediate relief or urgent relief granted in those sorts of instances. So there is not the facility for counselling in those courts. In relation to domestic violence, counselling is really looked at in another venue, more likely in a community agency or subsequently once the matter gets to the Family Court.

SPEECH.PARA: But, initially, in domestic violence situations, you have one partner going to the court for an urgent restraining order, and that being either granted or not granted. If it is granted, that puts a hold on things and then counselling is subsequently sought. So it is not a matter of putting the counselling before the restraining order; the restraining order normally is granted before any counselling is undertaken. So, as a question of whether this would impact on domestic violence, I think not.

In any event, there is a waiver application. If the person concerned—and this is only if they go to the Family Court of Australia—has a health card, is in receipt of legal aid or fits the bill of `otherwise financial hardship', as I have mentioned to Senator Harradine, there would be a waiver. We expect some 40 per cent of those people who would apply or would go to counselling would be exempted. That is again from the rate of waiving fees for applications.

With respect to how this will be administered, this is currently the subject of negotiation with the Family Court. Such aspects as to the method of payment are being looked at. It is envisaged that payment would be made on the day, that there would be some sort of billing process at the conclusion of the counselling and that the parties would be equally responsible. If one party is in a lesser financial position than the other, then it stands to reason that that party could make an application for a waiver; whereas the other party, due to their respective financial situation, would not.

So, if you have a situation where one person is left with the care and control of the children and is not enjoying a position where they are employed, then they could make that application for a waiver and the other party would not be eligible. So you would have that situation there. But, as I say, these are matters which are being looked at by way of regulation. Those regulations will be disallowable and negotiations are under way. But, of course, I will take up with the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) your concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise this issue that has been previously dealt with in the second reading stage—that of the ability and the capacity, as it were, for community organisations to take up the slack if, in the circumstances, there are persons who might rather go to community organisations than go to the court. The court counselling system is attractive at the present moment because it is free.

SPEECH.PARA: What has the government done and what is it doing to enhance the capability of these community organisations to take up the slack—in other words, to deal with a further volume of requests for counselling? These organisations are very good at and particularly concentrate on reconciliation counselling and I have heard that a number of them are quite good on mediation counselling also. I point out that regularly there are situations where there needs to be counselling on access to children—for example, for arrangements on living places—and mediation on a number of other financial matters also. Are the community organisations equipped for those purposes?

Whilst I am on that matter—and I have had this information supplied to me, but I think it ought to be a matter of record—what is the government doing in respect of family and relationship education and the organisations that are dealing with those particular matters? Has further attention been given recently to that particular aspect? What is the situation in regard to the funding of mediation and counselling services? Has the government increased funding for those organisations?

BREAK.PARA: What are the numbers of those who have sought counselling from community organisations compared with those who have gone to the Family Court? I would be interested to know whether the number of those going to community groups has exceeded those going to the Family Court—potentially, of course, those going to the community groups would be subject to fees whereas those going to the Family Court would not be. I think those figures would be revealing. Finally, what percentage of those seeking counselling from community groups has been able to receive that counselling free?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in relation to the comparison of those people who seek counselling at the Family Court as opposed to the community agencies, the best I can advise you at this stage, Senator Harradine, is that, in the year 1995‐96, some 31,500 people sought counselling in the Family Court jurisdiction. In the year 1994‐95, some 90,000 people sought counselling in the community sector. I have not been able to obtain figures which relate to the same year but we believe that those figures would not have changed greatly—one would imagine that they would be roughly in the same order. So, in round terms, you would have one to three when comparing how many go to the Family Court for counselling to those who go to the community agencies such as Relationships Australia and Centrecare. So, it seems that by far the majority of people choose to go to those agencies run in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the government's policy in relation to marriage and relationship counselling, I understand that some 34 centres have been approved. However, the community education program is yet to start and I understood that there was some half a million dollars dedicated to that. That has yet to start, but those centres have been approved.

You also raised the question of the effect that this might have on community agencies. Some concerns have been expressed to the government from the community sector, and those concerns are being taken up. Certainly, I will take up with the Attorney‐General the matters that you have raised here, and they, no doubt, could have some relevance to the regulations that come into play. I think I have covered the questions that you asked, Senator Harradine. Forgive me if I have missed one. Was there another one?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Firstly, are those 34 organisations in addition to the 81 organisations that are already established to deal with family and relationships education and the 89 that are already funded which are termed as mediation services? Secondly, the question that I asked and which was not answered was: have you any rough idea as to the number of persons seeking and obtaining counselling through the community organisations who are not charged a fee?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that last point, we undertake to get that information for you; I do not have that to hand. With respect to the 34 centres, I understand that they are additional services to those provided by the 81 that you mentioned, although some of those 34 are funded for other things.

—Parliamentary Secretary, can you tell me how much the Family Court cost in the year prior to this? I see from the second reading speech that this year it is costed at over $100 million. It would be helpful if you could tell me the previous year's cost.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —My recollection is that it was in the order of $105 million.
—If I understand you correctly, this year it was over $100 million and last year it was $105 million.
—That would be right.

—I want to point out something to you, if I may: in my speech on the second reading I made the point that usage of the Family Court had increased by nearly 8,000 people. A simple mathematical calculation will indicate that if you divide last year's number of people using the Family Court into $105 million and then you divide this year's usage, you are likely to get a more efficient use of the Family Court per family member in the court with larger numbers. In other words, there is not a direct relationship between the numbers using the court and the increase in costs. In economic terms, your marginal rate of return improves. If that is so, will the government, if it gets this bill through, examine the relationship between people using the court and the total subsequent cost of the courts? If the cost falls as a result of your increase in fees, will it reconsider the possibility of lowering those fees?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that question from Senator Murray, might I say that each year the government looks at the annual report of the Family Court and, in any event, monitors that relationship between the workload and the cost of the Family Court. At this stage it would be impossible for me to say what the government's course of action would be in the future, just as I am unable to say what will or will not be in the budget. Nonetheless, the situation is monitored—and it is done through the annual report of the Family Court. The questions you raise are looked at by the government but I cannot say what the government would do in a given circumstance in a year's time.

—If I can be personal for a moment, I judge your character to be one such that you would be concerned personally to ensure that the access to courts is as easy as possible for the people who need to use them. All I am saying is that in view of the fact that there is an economic relationship—that is the terminology of the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) in approaching this bill—between the cost of the court and the numbers using it, if the figure for the numbers using the court divided into that cost falls, it would seem to be cost efficient from your point of view, in your role as parliamentary secretary, to encourage the government to look at that issue again. That is all I am requesting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the complexion you have now placed on this matter, I assure you that I will take this up with the Attorney‐General and advise him of your concerns.

—Thank you. Parliamentary secretary, you made the point, if I heard you correctly, that Commonwealth costs are 50 per cent of those of state courts—roughly half. Would you suggest that the reason that states' charges have been higher than the Commonwealth's is the states' narrow income base which has required them to search out every corner for cost increases, not that they found some relationship between the usage of the courts and the charges they apply. In other words, it is not appropriate for the Commonwealth to consider the relationship to states' costs on a comparative basis simply because the motive for the states might be entirely different from yours.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that question, what I actually said was that the rate of cost recovery—not the filing fee or the cost itself—by the Commonwealth was 50 per cent or more of that of the states. What I was saying was that the states were recovering much more from their filing fees than the Commonwealth was. With respect to whether the states have a narrow base, I really do not have the numbers of litigants that the states have using the courts or, on the other hand, those of the Commonwealth with which to make a comparison. Suffice to say, in most jurisdictions the states have more courts than the Commonwealth from which to recoup costs.

BREAK.PARA: With cross‐vesting you have the availability of the Commonwealth and state to have cases run in each other's jurisdictions which touch on their respective areas. It is not, I think, an unfair situation to compare the rate of cost recovery between the states and the Commonwealth because as time goes by we are moving closer together and our systems are becoming similar. One example is the state Family Court of Western Australia. Their procedures and legislation reflect the Commonwealth's procedure and legislation. As time goes by, the similarities will become even greater.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition and the Democrats have made the case that raising fees and charges could have the effect—and we feel it will have the effect—of reducing the ease and the access of people to the court system. The states and the Commonwealth have different filing fee costs and charges. Has anyone from government or government departments examined whether that contributes to greater or lesser usage of the courts? In other words, what effect do different charges and fees have on court access? Is it known?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there was a matter that I touched on in relation to Senator Cooney's concerns. These increased filing fees came in in September last year. It is still too early to have any empirical evidence available as to whether this has been a prohibitive factor to people having access to the courts. Anecdotal evidence suggests that it has not been prohibitive.

—I acknowledge that response. However, before you did that, from your own speech, the difference between the states and the Commonwealth was apparent and quite marked. I therefore wonder whether an empirical relationship—to use your own language—has been identified between court usage and fees when that disparity was wider than it now is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any assessment being made in the terms suggested by Senator Murray.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MURRAY (Western Australia) (5.17 p.m.)- If no assessment has been made, is there not a risk in unilaterally raising fees without knowing the consequence, which could be to lower the access of Australians to our courts?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —What the government relied on was how other jurisdictions operated and the percentage of cost recovery that they had. There did not seem to be any problem in those jurisdictions. Therefore, with the growing uniformity across the country in relation to legislation and the discrete jurisdictions that exist, it was thought there would be no fallout from any increase as such.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, in an area such as family law, which is terribly important, there was still the waiver provision. Some 40 per cent of applicants are successful in having their fees waived. There was still the safety net which would apply. From what other jurisdictions have told us, there would not be any problem in the increase of fees. Hitherto, since September last year, anecdotal evidence suggests that the government's course of action was sound.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the department and the government did not do any assessment or research, how would you know there was no problem?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Governments, unfortunately, do not have a crystal ball. It is very hard to hypothesise in these sorts of circumstances because you are dealing with human behaviour. To indulge in prognostication in relation to human behaviour is a very risky exercise at the best of times. One does not know whether there will be more litigants this year or the next year, but I dare say that if human nature is true to form it will be on the increase.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Murray that all the government could be fairly expected to look at is other jurisdictions within the country. When you look at the way people access the courts in the various states, you can get a good idea as to the access that people are enjoying to those courts. I do not think that is an unreasonable base to use when looking into the future. I do not think the government could have done any more to work out a model. In some aspects, modelling can be successful. However, it is a hard task to look at the number of people suing each other, or the number of people using the courts to seek remedies for matrimonial breakdown, and work out with accuracy where it is going to go.

I think the approach of the government was quite sound in saying, `In the states you have this rate of cost recovery which seems to work. People do not seem to be saying that this is too much; that they cannot go and exercise their rights in the courts.' We looked at the local court, district courts, the Supreme Court in Western Australia and the equivalent in other states. There was a good cross‐section in relation to the rate of cost recovery from the small cases to the large cases. I think that was a fair approach by the government. It could not have done any more. In any event, the government will have a clearer picture by the end of June this year, which is only a few months away. Those figures will then be available to this chamber for assessment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim
