TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the package of telecommunications bills 1996 as listed on the Notice Paper . When stacked up, this package can be seen to total 400 to 500 pages of legislation, memoranda, explanatory notes and second reading speeches. The process of preparation surrounding these bills which now are before us to be debated has been going on for some two to 2½ years.

SPEECH.PARA: It is known, of course, that the previous Labor government, when changing the structure of telecommunications in Australia in 1991-92 to allow competitive carriers into the marketplace, at the same time announced that on 1 July 1997 the regulatory regime would be deregulated, that there would be no limit to the carriers and service providers and that full‐blooded competition would be allowed. I think as early as 1995, the then minister Mr Lee started the process of drafting this package of bills. That process was substantially completed when the government changed.

The new Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) continued that process at further forums and discussions. The bills were introduced into the parliament in late 1996. By agreement with the opposition here in the Senate, the bills immediately went to an ERCA legislative committee for final examination—and not in any way to delay the bill, but to develop a process whereby consultation with interested parties could be had in a constructive atmosphere so that senators could be educated about the full nature of the scope of these bills and deal with any amendments that may be proposed.

As I said when the report from the committee was tabled a few weeks ago, that process was extremely constructive. I think that having a round‐table type of committee with almost everybody at the table, all being recorded in Hansard, with senators being able to get people to argue amongst themselves on different viewpoints and then asking departmental representatives what they thought of proposed amendments—and I acknowledge Mr Shaw and his officers, who at present are in the advisers box, who sat patiently through all of that—was a very constructive arrangement.

I have never been noted as a great devotee of Senate procedure in this place or as having any great interest in it, but I would want to say to the Procedure Committee that the performance of the ERCA legislative committee in the way this matter was handled is actually a model that should be used for a lot of legislation—where you get the contending interest groups at the table at the same time and they argue with each other rather than with the committee members and then you can ask questions to elucidate more information and to create the argument. It means that you are much more quickly able to make a judgment about the merits of the argument because people are there at the same time. I would have thought that Senator Allison from the Democrats and the government members would all agree that the process was very constructive.

As a result of that process, the government has now tabled its report, and I congratulate the government on taking up so many of the unanimous recommendations from the committee, representing the government, the opposition and the Democrats. Although we put in minority reports on certain aspects, the majority of the recommendations were supported by all parties. That support was gained from a spirit of compromise on all sides, even though individually you might not have absolutely supported one particular recommendation as it came out.

At the end of last week the government circulated their response to all members of the Senate committee. It is a daunting document that goes for some 93 pages of further amendments, explanatory memoranda and notes. But overwhelmingly the government had dealt with the unanimous recommendations of the committee.

I wish the clerks of the Senate well in putting all of it into a running sheet for the committee stage of the debate, together with amendments that will be coming from the opposition, the Democrats and maybe the Greens. I hope that we can do that expeditiously and sensibly to make sure we keep our wits about us in handling these amendments.

The opposition and the Democrats both put in minority reports covering a number of very important areas. The opposition certainly acknowledges that overwhelmingly we are in support of this bill. Why would we not be? When we were in government we started the process, the theme and the principles in this bill, and it would be hypocritical of us, to say the least, if we totally opposed the bill.

There are certain areas we want to raise in which we believe improvements can be made to this legislation, and we will be moving amendments accordingly in the committee stage. I am pleased to note that on two of our recommendations the government has already basically accepted opposition suggestions—on the issue of industry development and on the issue of making sure there is no possibility that major infrastructure, such as telecommunications and the like, can be declared as low impact. We welcome the government's acceptance of those amendments from the opposition.

The opposition has also had informal discussions on a continuing basis with the government, the minister and his staff on other areas where we still have differences but where maybe we can reach a compromise. There has also been very constructive discussion with the Democrats in a number of areas. In the end, I would be surprised if we get complete agreement in every area but that discussion has been the theme for handling this bill through the Senate committee and subsequent to its report.

The areas where the opposition will be putting strong amendments and arguing for them include, first of all, what is called carriers' powers and immunities. We believe absolutely that local government, representing the local community, must have the right to appeal against the construction of major telecommunications infrastructure in Australia—whether it be mobile telephone towers, microwave towers or overhead cables.

That issue is now far too strong in the community to allow the old system of complete immunity under the federal constitution from people being people being able to object to such developments. The government, the opposition and the Democrats have strongly supported an appeal process. The debate we now have is what form the appeal process will take.

The government has put forward a proposition that the codes of practice in many areas of how the appeal process and the planning provisions will operate will be left to the states. The opposition opposes that. We believe that the development of a sensible, national telecommunications system means that that responsibility should remain with the Commonwealth parliament.

We therefore propose that national guidelines be prepared for all of Australia after an open, consultative process with local and state government, carriers and interested parties in the community, and that when that document is prepared by the ACA it should become a disallowable instrument in the parliament. Of course, that means that from time to time as circumstances change it can be amended, added to and changed.

We believe that once that is established, when there is a dispute between a carrier and a local government, under our model we want to say if that council objects to the carrier or the carrier cannot get agreement with the council one or other of the parties can appeal direct to the ACA for determination—an independent body to weigh up the national interests of a telecommunications system with the local concerns in the community. I believe that is a simple, cost‐effective way which means that this parliament will have discharged its duty properly in its constitutional responsibility for telecommunications.

The government proposal is different in that it relies on the state government stepping into what I think is an unnecessary void being created. They would then draw up their own guidelines, which means you will end up having six state and two territory sets of guidelines. By their very nature they will be different. I believe this leads us to move away from a national responsibility and national guidelines. Even if a state planning authority is appealed to, in the end if one of the parties disagrees in most cases they will be able to appeal to the ACA. I believe it is an unnecessary step in the middle that is unnecessarily complicating and is expensive to provide.

I have put to the government on several occasions variations about how we could get a compromise between the minister's position and the opposition's position. One that the opposition is willing to discuss with the government—and I put on the record here—is that the federal parliament and what will be the ACA draw up a national guideline that is available across Australia so that when a state planning appeal authority is dealing with an appeal they would have a national guideline to look at to see whether the issues of telecommunications were being properly dealt with in that guideline, which, as I say, is a disallowable instrument in this parliament. This parliament maintains the oversight of that guideline but the minister still gets the state planning process into the system. I believe that is a reasonable compromise which the opposition is willing to look at.

We absolutely believe the immunity to lay overhead cables must end at midnight on 30 June. Carriers have been told since 1992 that the immunity will end on 30 June 1997. They should plan accordingly. The government's proposal to extend that by another three months to complete the roll‐out is not extending immunity; it is playing semantics. The community is expecting, and has been told for a long time, that the immunity will end on 30 June. I think the parliament should stick to that and we will be supporting an amendment accordingly.

We also believe those communities that now have extensive overhead cables rolled out should have some long-term plan available to them to have the cables put underground. We will be moving some amendments. We accept the fact that there are some parliamentary procedures in moving an amendment to impose levies on carriers. Only the House of Representatives can introduce a levy or a taxing bill; it cannot be done from the Senate. But at the very least we believe this is an area that the parliament cannot walk away from. Unless communities that have overhead cables can see in the intermediate to long term there is some process to get rid of them, there will be consistent antagonism in the community against the carriers on this issue.

As I said before, we believe that the communications towers, et cetera, should no longer have any risk of being classed as low impact and therefore be exempt. We also believe that in the future all overhead cables, even those below 13 millimetres diameter, which is the government definition, have to go underground. I think that is the very minimum the community will ask us to support.

I have already mentioned industry policy. We are pleased the government has accepted the opposition's amendment for the minister for industry to be able to sanction carriers when they promise industry development programs but do not carry them through. I note that we are doing this not in a way that puts us out of kilter with the World Trade Organisation arrangements. This is being done in accordance with World Trade Organisation rules. I think if anyone else from America or Europe wants to have a go at us it ought to be put on the record now that this is not contrary to the WTO rules.

The area in which we still have differences with the government is the area of pricing arrangements and services to the country areas. Competition is coming to the cities for local loop telephone calls. Optus, if they can gets its overhead cable to work for telephony, have said they will offer local call rates at 20c in markets like Sydney and Melbourne. When those local call rates are offered in the city they should also be offered in rural and regional areas of Australia so that country people get the benefit of competition directly, even though they may not have a competitive market of their own.

We do not want to have the re‐run of the argument about petrol. In country areas there is angst against the petrol industry that there is no reduction, no discounting, of petrol in rural areas; it is only in the city. Quite rightly, country people feel hard put upon about that. We do not want the rural areas feeling that there is a two-tiered price system operating, discriminating against the country. We will be moving an amendment accordingly.

We also believe that by the year 2000 we ought to guarantee all Australians will have the availability of digital data capability—that is, on-line services of 64 kilobits per second, which is a substantial improvement on the present power available of on-line services for Internet and so on. It is very important that our rural areas get access to the same capacity as our city areas. At the moment the government is saying that 94 per cent will be available. It is the last six per cent that is difficult. I agree that it is difficult and that it could be costly, but I believe that you do not have to lay all the infrastructure out. You can do it in a way that when someone wants it you provide the service so that they can get access to digital data capability even in rural and remote areas.

If we want our farming community and our small business community in rural and regional Australia to be internationally competitive they have to have access to the latest communication system. They have to be able to connect to their marketplace elsewhere in the world or elsewhere in Australia. If they do not have access to the same level of communications on-line services they will be disadvantaged and accordingly not be as profitable and not be as prosperous. This is an important issue for the opposition, and we hope that the government can support our amendment in this area. They have come a long way in supporting this, but the last bid to ensure the last six per cent get it by the year 2000, I believe, is very important.

There are some other amendments we have, which some people might say are a little bit more esoteric to the general public, that deal with competition notices and tariff filing notices. We believe that Telstra should file tariff notices so that the ACCC can see what the dominant carrier is charging and, if necessary, can take action if it believes it is acting in an uncompetitive way. We believe that tariff filing notices should be compulsory for a period into the future. We also believe that the service providers should have reasonable access in the transition period to competitive prices from the carriers. Again I say that that is not an issue that the general public are overwhelmingly besotted with. But if you really want to develop a broad based telecommunications system with all its services growing, the service providers have got to be given reasonable access to the interconnect fee that is available to carriers between themselves. We believe our amendment in this area is very useful indeed.

Finally, we will of course be supporting amendments to guarantee that business on‐line services get a standard flat rate untimed local call charge. As it is at the moment, we do not accept the position of the government or the carriers that automatically that is going to jam them. We think that with new technology this should be seen as a new business opportunity.

All in all, the opposition overwhelmingly supports this bill, but in the areas I have outlined we believe we have important amendments that will enhance the outcome of this package of bills. That will mean that we have a robust and healthy telecommunications services industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Greens (WA) I would start by noting the criticisms by both the Australian Democrats and community groups of the Senate inquiry into this package of telecommunications bills. The time given to groups to submit evidence to the inquiry was inadequate and it seems that not enough simple information on, and explanation of, the intent and detail of the bills package was given.

BREAK.PARA: Further, the terms of reference for the inquiry called for specific legislative amendments from those making submissions. This is a completely unreasonable request that seems to have been designed to stifle input rather than encourage it. It is one of the things that could have been encouraged, but often it is used to intimidate people. All in all, it was clearly not a great moment in community consultation. It poses a question: if this legislation is so clearly of benefit to consumers, as we are told so often, why is the government reluctant to hear consumers' opinions of it?

We are also concerned about the regulatory structure contained in the new legislation. The proposed act will rely on self‐regulation of telecommunications with codes of practice. Yet when it comes to the provision of such an essential service as telecommunications, we would like to see a stronger and more binding regulatory scheme introduced. Of particular concern is that the industry codes will be voluntary. If we are to have self‐regulation based on codes of practice surely, at a bare minimum, compliance with the codes should be compulsory.

Only last week in this place we debated amendments to the Trade Practices Act relating to access to infrastructure services such as electricity, gas and water in our newly competitive economy. Some of the issues raised in that debate are relevant today. Our general concerns with the telecommunications bills relate, as they did last week, to matters of the public interest and the need to ensure that competition does not override the need to protect the public interest. As with the bill last week, we do not believe that enough has been done. We will be moving amendments to the bill and, unless they are adopted, we are not able to support this bill.

Last week's Industry Access Codes Bill contains inadequate provision for protection of the public interest. It stipulates that when the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is assessing a code for an infrastructure industry, it is required to give consideration to `the public interest, including the public interest in having competition in markets'. We pointed out that this was a very narrow description of the public interest and that it did not take into account that in many cases competition was against the public interest.

This bill's attempt at describing the public interest is even worse. Part 6 of this bill deals with industry codes for sections of the telecommunications industry. Section 111 specifies the general principles. It states that:

. . . the ACA, in exercising its powers . . . will act in a manner that, in the opinion of the ACA, enables public interest considerations to be addressed in a way that does not impose undue financial and administrative burdens on participants in sections of the telecommunications industry.

This statement is very revealing. It puts one thing completely beyond doubt as to the intent of competition policy. It is designed to maximise corporate profits and the sale price of Telstra, not to enhance the interests of the consumers—let alone the wider community. Section 111 then goes on to state that when determining whether public interest is jeopardising corporate profits, the ACA must give regard to:
(d) the public interest in having competition in markets.

This is an even worse description than that contained in the recent Industry Access Codes Bill. That bill at least referred to `the public interest including the public interest in having markets'. The definition at least allowed for the possibility that public interest could mean other things. The Telecommunications Bill, however, has dispensed with this nicety.

The complete inadequacy of this definition of public interest is revealed by the next section of the bill, section 112, which outlines `matters that may be dealt with by industry codes and industry standards'. These include: the internal handling of customer complaints, debt collection practices and disconnection of customers.

What is clear from just these few examples is that there is a great need for a much wider definition of the public interest to be used by the ACA when considering codes. How does competition protect the public interest with regard to issues of debt collection or disconnection? Principles such as social equity are central to the consideration of these issues, and they must be spelled out in this legislation. We will move amendments which seek to have these principles included.

We have other specific concerns about this bill, including a concern about the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman scheme—or should I say ombudsperson because it is not yet in legislation. Clause 236 of the Telecommunications Bill stipulates that carriers and eligible carriage service providers must enter a scheme providing for a Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, or TIO. This is something that we welcome, and we hope that the government will give this person the resources and facilities necessary to do their job properly.

However, clause 237 then gives the Australian Communications Authority, the ACA, the power to exempt a carrier or eligible carriage service provider from the obligation to enter the TIO scheme. What is the rationale for this? I fail to see a situation where the ACA could justify deciding that a carrier should be exempt from an oversight scheme that other carriers are a part of. I would welcome the government explaining this part of the bill to the Senate.

Further to this scheme, the report of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee recommends that the definition of `eligible service providers' be extended to include Internet access providers and Internet service providers. They could then be included in the TIO scheme. I think this is sensible and I would urge the government to accept this suggestion.

Clause 22 of this bill gives the definition of the `boundary of a telecommunications network'. The boundary is that point to which the carrier's obligations extend. The boundary is defined in regulations or, when there are no regulations, this bill sets down definitions. In the case of services provided by a line that enters a building, the boundary is the building entry point; that is, the point at which the line meets the outer surface of the building.

This is a regressive step, it would seem. In the current act, the boundary for most consumers is defined as the wall socket in their house. This is specified in the legislation. We would like to see this carried over to the new legislation; otherwise, we are concerned that this bill's new definition of the boundary as a building entry point will be adopted to the disadvantage of consumers. For instance, for someone living in a large block of units, the boundary at which the carrier is responsible is currently the wall socket. If a problem arises up to that point, the carrier is responsible for dealing with it. If the boundary is moved back to the building entry point, then any problems arising between the entry point and their apartment could be the responsibility of the building's owner. All this does is make it more difficult for consumers to have problems with their telecommunications services fixed. We would urge the government to revert to the definition contained in the current act, and we will be moving amendments to protect residential customers in this regard.

Turning to the universal service areas: we have had representation from the Consumers Telecommunications Network, or CTN, pointing out the need to extend the definition of a `universal service area' to cover non-geographically defined loss‐making services that constitute a public benefit. This was supported by the standard telephone service review. What this means is that a designated service area could include things such as individual pay phones. As an example, a pay phone in a disadvantaged area of Sydney may operate at a loss but be heavily relied upon by local residents who may not be able to afford a telephone service in their homes. As such, it should be declared a universal service area.

We also strongly support the recommendation that a levy be incorporated into the annual carrier licence charge which will be used to fund consumer representation and research into social policy aspects of telecommunications related issues. The issue of low-impact facilities is also of great concern. The bill does not define low-impact facilities, yet is giving low-impact facilities immunity from state and local planning and environment laws. Austel is currently conducting an inquiry into what is a low-impact facility, yet the government is now expecting us to give these facilities immunity before this is deter mined. I understand the Democrats are moving to delete the immunity for low-impact facilities from the legislation, and we will be prepared to support this.

The government will be moving an amendment which appears to be a concession to concerns that consumer bodies will not be consulted when the ACA determines, varies or revokes an industry standard. A new section, section 131A, has been added which directs that the ACA must consult `at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers'. However, while this might seem to be a reasonable step, it might be meaningless. `At least one' body effectively means one, and which one body will be consulted? Most likely the one which gives the least difficult and challenging point of view. How do we know that this body can be taken as representative of consumers as a whole? If the ACA is committed to consulting one consumer body, then surely they could just as easily consult others and thus get a broader and more representative view of the opinions of consumers. We would urge that this amendment be altered. I intend to move our own amendment to it.

Then there is the issue of overhead cabling. Although the government will be moving amendments which are an improvement on the existing situation, it is still inadequate. What is needed is clear legislation that all future cabling will go underground and that existing aerial cabling will be replaced with underground cabling. I would note that we seem to be behind the rest of the developed world in this regard. For example, I understand that underground cabling has been required in Germany since the early 1980s. Once again, corporate interests appear to be overriding community interests. I will be saying more on these matters at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Telecommunications Bill 1996 and the associated bills, I wish to raise just a few of the concerns that I have with this legislation. It is not only members on this side of the chamber who have some concerns with these bills; in fact, ministers Cooper and Veivers, the two Queensland National Party ministers responsible for the emergency services in my home state, have written to Senator Alston on at least two occasions expressing their concern about the weaknesses of the proposed legislation in respect of emergency call services.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 255 of the bill—provision of emergency call services—is simply not strong enough. This is a section of the bill that deals with life‐threatening and time critical situations. This is a section of the bill that will help determine the effectiveness of emergency calls to the ambulance, fire and police services. This section should therefore be quite prescriptive. It should set out the minimum requirements that will ensure the health, safety and well-being of all Australians.

Subclause (2) of clause 255 states that each telephone user should have direct access, free of charge, to an emergency number unless the ACA considers that it would be unreasonable for such access to be provided. Under what circumstances would the ACA consider direct and free access to such a service unreasonable? Surely not when your telephone is on a remote rural farm or when you are using a mobile phone. When is it unreasonable to provide a service to help save a life? Part (b) of subclause (2) states that the ACA must have regard to the objective that carriage services used for emergency calls should, as far as practicable, provide the emergency call person with automatic information about the location and identity of the caller.

What on earth is meant by `have regard to' and `as far as practicable'? What is being said here? If something is technically too difficult, too expensive or too much trouble, can a commercial telecommunications provider forget about providing this information? I do not believe that some senators opposite realise just how important it is for this type of information to be provided directly to the emergency service providers. The increasing use of computer aided dispatch systems for emergency services means that this type of information can make the difference between locating a fire or a person in a critical medical condition and saving lives.

Take, for instance, the case of a child dialling the emergency number or a distressed or injured person dialling the number where neither the child nor the injured person is able to provide the location for the emergency. In such cases the computer aided dispatch systems will show emergency personnel on a computer screen the exact location—on an on screen map—of the telephone from which the call is being made. Failure to gain this information from the carriage provider could lead to the death of the injured person.

In addition, this type of system also helps to eliminate hoax callers, as the location and telephone number of the telephone is immediately shown on the computer screen. Once again, a failure to provide all the information could mean that the emergency personnel are too busy following up on a hoax call to go to a genuine emergency, thereby creating a life‐threatening situation.

To be as effective as possible, there is obviously a need to set a high standard of service for emergency calls. There are no clauses setting out the standard of either the delivery or the ongoing development of emergency call provisions. On top of all this, in a competitive environment there is no written requirement for the telecommunications providers to fund or finance the emergency call services. In other words, there is no guarantee in the legislation that emergency call services will have adequate funding to operate efficiently.

In fact, this hole in the legislation was pointed out to Senator Alston, obviously with no effect, by his state colleagues in Queensland, the National Party emergency services minister, Mr Mick Veivers, and the police minister, Mr Russell Cooper. I will quote from a letter that they wrote to Senator Alston on 12 November last year:

Neither my colleague nor myself can understand why, in life threatening and time critical circumstances, your Government chooses to be vague and non-committal given how successfully the present national system, developed largely voluntarily by a monopoly carrier, has operated, especially by comparison with other parts of the world. Any reference to funding these critical services is absent in the Bill, causing us to wonder about the motivations behind the design of the Bill.

In a competitive environment all commercial providers will understandably try to minimise the cost of any of its operations, including emergency call service operations. The risks involved in not prescribing a funding regime in this particular case are too great to contemplate. It is shameful that an Australian government should make no provision to ensure that there is adequate funding for emergency call services. I will quote from the Queensland coalition ministers again:

Competitive commercial market forces are simply not going to produce safety critical systems where no revenue stream is allowed. Indeed the greatest concern will be the exposure that will begin to develop in rural and regional areas. That position simply cannot be accepted by the Queensland Government. The need for a uniform Emergency Call Service is clearly more critical than the provision of the standard telephone service, yet while the requirement for the latter is quite specific in the Bill, the full requirement for the former is not.

It is obvious that the Queensland coalition, and therefore the Queensland government, is not at all happy with this legislation. In the minister's stubborn approach to the Queensland government he has ignored their very valid fears about emergency call numbers and a well‐funded emergency call service. Apart from this, and possibly even worse, is the potential for confusion about emergency numbers, which is embodied in the legislation. Clause 450—emergency service numbers—states:
The numbering plan may specify different numbers for use in different areas.

Imagine those people living near state or regional borders, holiday makers, those moving interstate or someone who is simply travelling in an area away from home. What number do they call? The time taken to find out or decide whether to call 000, 112 or whatever other numbers might be used for emergency calls under this system could be long enough to cause the unnecessary death of someone in a critical condition.

Surely we can agree that there should be one emergency number across Australia. Surely it will be confusing enough, especially for young children, to unlearn the 000 number and learn to dial the new emergency number without being confused with different numbers for different areas. It is not uncommon for ordinary people to forget their four‐digit pin numbers for various credit cards. Is this government going to put lives at risk by confusing telephone users, especially itinerant ones, with a plethora of emergency telephone numbers?

The Queensland National Party Minister for Police and National Party Minister for Emergency Services understand the perils of this inadequate legislation. When is the federal minister going to realise and understand the problems that his legislation will cause and the lives that he might sacrifice as a result? The minister's state colleagues, in a joint letter about what they describe as a critical issue, pointed out:
The Telecommunications Bill 1996 exposure draft was released in October 1996 with an impossibly tight program for consideration of submissions.
They went on to say:
. . . but we believe the timetable was such that none of the changes needed could have been incorporated.

I realise that there are some 800 pages of legislation involved here and that it is difficult to make such a large piece of legislation perfect, but please let us at least get the provision of emergency calls right.

I want to turn now to the consequences for rural and regional Australians. I represent Queensland, which is a diverse state, and many Queenslanders live in rural, regional and remote areas. I cannot emphasise enough the need for up‐to‐date telecommunications services to be provided to these areas. There are many farmers who use modern fax facilities, and there are School of the Air students who will increasingly want to use Internet services, e-mail and other developing technologies.

The standard telephony service that is now in place will not be the standard of the future. The provision of modern, advanced telecommunications services to rural and regional Australians must be ensured. Because the provision of such modern services will be uneconomic to commercial telecommunications providers, the legislation must specify quite clearly that modern telecommunications services must be specified as part of the universal service obligations.

A failure to do this will mean that Australians who live outside the capital cities, and especially those who live outside other major centres, will become second‐class citizens. I am sure that the National Party senators in this chamber will also stand up for Australians living in the country.

The standard telephone services referred to in the bill under universal service obligations must never be allowed to become old standard or substandard telephone services. The bill is not clear enough on this matter which is essential to the Australian way of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address my comments in this second reading debate on the Telecommunications Bill in a more general way. Despite numerous inquiries and reports into the various telecommunications and information technologies that have surfaced over the last few years, neither the governments nor the carriers have provided a blueprint or industry development plan of where our telecommunications industry is going.

SPEECH.PARA: The maintenance of society is properly addressed by coupling investment and information technology expenditure with social equity and access provisions. There exists an interdependent link between social policy and economic development, and governments have the ability to position the telecommunications industries within a framework of regional development and infrastructure. For instance, locating knowledge and information technology based industries together with transport, mining and construction creates a Silicon Valley style development that develops regional and rural Australia.

The telecommunications industry is undergoing revolutionary transformations, and Australia is in a position to ride the crest of this wave provided we implement far-sighted and comprehensive policies. For too long parliament has had its attention diverted to other issues, specifically ownership, with this myopic view of telecommunications allowing central issues to be downgraded while public debates about who owns what are carried out.

BREAK.PARA: At the same time, governments should be prepared to provide sanctions to enforce carriers to commit themselves to decisive industry development plans, and the telecommunications industry must expand, but information technology will achieve this only if it is freed from languishing with some decrepit, old legislative structure within which carriers and new technology providers struggle. I am pleased to see that the government has indicated that they will be supporting Labor's amendment to include sanctions with respect to the implementation of industry development plans.

On telecommunications generally, part of the role of government should be to be able to articulate a social policy objective which recognises the direction telecommunications infrastructure, telephony, facsimile services and other services like the Internet are taking. The coalition has, to some extent, abdicated its responsibilities by failing to outline a philosophy or cultural direction with respect to telecommunications. They are content to ape the US without regard to our unique culture and history, ignoring many unique features of our telecommunications industry, which include our geography, our spectrum availability and our unusually high uptake of new technologies.

A perception exists that the Australian telecommunications industry is subservient to overseas markets, and hence the communications community views the Internet and electronic commerce as generally a foreign domain, one in which Australia is not required to take a proactive legislative role. John Nieuwenhuizen, author of Asleep at the Wheel: Australia on the Superhighway, told the Weekend Australian of 15 March that an inquiry into the proposed introduction of the Internet in schools is essential. Nieuwenhuizen said:
There were royal commissions when radio and television were introduced. There ought to be public debate and inquiry [about the Internet] before it's too late.

Nieuwenhuizen's point is that this government has failed to provide a blueprint or policy for the Internet and that when other communications technology such as television was introduced there was widespread debate and investigation, yet the Internet, which defies national borders and to some extent regional control, has not been brought into the wider telecommunications policy debate. I am not calling for another inquiry, but it is essential that major parties develop a comprehensive policy vision for the social implications and applications of telecommunications infrastructure, industry access and specifically content. Labor is moving down this path, and yet the government is stricken by an all too familiar inertia.

With respect to this issue, Labor, in one of its recommended amendments to these bills, talks about the importance of having some sort of body that can conduct the type of social research to which I am referring. Certainly the Consumer Telecommunications Network and the Communications Law Centre advocated that quite succinctly in their submissions to the inquiry into these bills. Labor has recognised the value and strategic importance of this type of work and hence has embodied that in one of its recommendations. That will go some way to making sure there is a facility and body in Australia to perform some of this work. Nonetheless, that does not remove the obligation on major parties, particularly the party in power, the government, to have some comprehensive vision for the future.

There is also a growing perception within some sections of the business and commercial sector that the Internet has failed to deliver. Of course, the Internet is not there for commercial transactions only. To many users it is about entertainment and surfing. In fact, the majority of Internet users use it for entertainment purposes. To others it offers the promise of information access and exchange for the benefit of the global community.

Sales tax is another issue. Others are piracy and copyright protection. What is freedom to some people—freedom to access materials, goods, knowledge and ideas—may be oppressive or fraudulent to others. Intellectual copyright and plagiarism are issues now confronting both high school and university students as well as the general public, whilst globalisation of trade and encryption requires some specific policy response.

Ultimately, it is the federal government which must find a balance between protecting the disparate public and private interests with regard to the Internet, and articulate a holistic approach to information services. Serious questions regarding the Internet must be addressed in this policy context, including where it is taking us, whether it is a tool that is essential in schools, and whether it is a service for industry or an entertainment and niche service provider.

Teachers and academics have already voiced their concerns about the effect of the Internet and other telecommunications on literacy and writing skills. A Tasmanian based group called Switch Off and Play, or SOAP, has voiced concerns about the long-term damage that computers and video games have on children. Gradual loss of creativity and originality in young people may well result from the unchecked use of such telecommunications and information technology. These issues go beyond just IT policy and well into the realms of education and social policy.

The shift towards what the Americans call `edutainment' is acceptable in Seattle schoolrooms. However, teaching our children via video games and cartoons may well prove to be culturally and educationally misguided. I believe it is reasonable to implement very succinct policies that will ensure these issues will not be subsumed by the commercial interests of IT providers.

Similarly, libraries are facing a dilemma caused by the massive availability of electronic information. The Internet, electronic commerce and basic access and equity to telecommunications services are obviously paramount, and in many respects this whole area is a major policy tool for governments. Information and access to information are now a determinant of power in the community, and governments have the ability to use telecommunications as a mechanism with which to introduce social policy.

Untimed data calls is one area where public policy impacts upon social structures and environments. I am firmly in favour of untimed data calls in both the residential and the business sector. That is all well and good, but when analysing that position it is important to understand that we cannot consider data calls in the old context. We have to consider how those calls will be used in the future.

It is unclear what the government's position is with respect to data calls, specifically those for local businesses, despite the government having articulated quite a clear position in the inquiry report. Labor has made it patently clear what its position is: untimed voice and data calls for local business and residential customers must be maintained. Paragraph 2.80 of the inquiry report states:

The Committee carefully considered the views put by Telstra and found some merit in its argument. The Committee does not believe that the Government should allow these guarantees to be exploited by some to the cost of consumers in general. However, the evidence put before the Committee did not persuade it that there was a widespread problem of exchange congestion or that, where such problems existed, they were leading to significant costs being passed on to other consumers.

That comment was made in the majority report and was made in the context of the government arguing for the retention of untimed local data calls for business, certainly until they advocate a review in July 1998. Since that report has been published, the government's position has become very fuzzy indeed and I wait with interest for the minister's position with respect to these calls and exactly what the government intends to do.

If the government is true to its views in the report and it in fact does not back away from a very important position, then we have to look at that in the context of where the current debate is with respect to Telstra, given that obviously Telstra will be impacted upon largely in the first instance. There is no doubt that in the current climate they are positioning themselves for privatisation and are attempting to ensure that they have at least some reasonable expectation of a profit generating market in business data calls.

In relation to questions responded to in the recent additional estimates hearings, Telstra are aiming to have the technology installed to ensure that they will be able to provide a comparison to consumers, whether they be business or residential, as to what their bill would be either under a timed call package or under the current untimed billing mechanisms. I will quote again from Hansard with respect to that. In response to a question from me as to what degree Telstra had conducted investigations to implement the appropriate technology for billing for timed calls and untimed calls, Mr Ward said:

We are certainly working on technology to provide the capacity to be able to identify local call usage in terms of time of day and usage. In terms of the cost of that technology, I do not have those numbers in my head but I can certainly provide them. The capacity is certainly not implemented at the moment, but we think this is important—not only in the longer term of providing options for pricing but also in terms of billing inquiries and helping customers understand their usage patterns, et cetera.

The significance of this is highlighted for small business, whom the minister has described as having the capacity to pay. Under the government's position, the small business users of data calls will not have the opportunity in the first instance to compare such billing; they will be potentially straight onto a time based system without having the option of untimed local data calls.

With bills packaged in this way, while being perhaps competitive in the first instance, it sets the carriers up for complete control over the pricing of bandwidth along a vertically integrated pathway of data. Perhaps the minister should also have a look at the additional estimates Hansard, in which Telstra appear to contradict the position they took in the bills inquiry. I asked:

Just returning to my earlier questions with respect to billing and pricing policy, how do you intend to implement a timed data call for business in relation to Internet services provided by an Internet service provider other than Telstra?
After a comment by Mr Ward, Mr Hambleton went on to say:

I do not think we have a clear mechanism yet to implement time dating for data calls, whether for business or residential. In fact, in the process of representing to the Senate on the post-1997 legislation, we asked for a reserve power to address the issue if, in fact, there was a need to have a timed charge in the future and we specifically did not request any immediate intervention.

I sense a slight contradiction in there somewhere and believe that that statement by Mr Hambleton from Telstra really calls into question the minister's position quite generally with respect to the government's position, being ambiguous on timed local data calls for business quite specifically.

More generally, 40 per cent of Australian homes use personal computers. It is not an unreasonable expectation that some time in the future a far greater percentage of those will be connected to the Internet. At the moment the protection of untimed local data calls is expected to be reviewed in 1998. I would like to be a voice for those residential users, too: down the track, timed data calls by residential users are a completely undesirable outcome, as they are currently with respect to business.

This debate regarding the provision of untimed local data calls to business has particular relevance with respect to the Internet generally. Currently, Telstra charge for the volume of data that ISPs—Internet service providers—download. Then those ISPs on‐sell in a variety of ways, providing customers with a range of charging options. Telstra's position in the marketplace as a wholesaler of bandwidth to Internet service providers puts their pricing policy for Telstra Internet access under the spotlight, as Telstra also compete against the ISPs for market share for commercial access to the Internet. The spotlight is warranted not for the wholesaling of bandwidth but for their charging of the connection between the user and the independent ISP.

The main issue there that comes into play is that, when we are talking about competition, are we talking about competition for competition's sake or are we talking about this particular issue with respect to ISPs and the ability of this legislation to address what could potentially be a conflict under this particular legislative regime if in fact those ISPs do not have some sort of protection from Telstra?

The `so what' in all of this is of course ensuring that independent ISPs can continue to provide affordable Internet access without being squeezed. It is their servers that provide the free content back into cyberspace and those ISPs are important because they ensure the content remains free on the Internet. It is becoming apparent that many of the larger corporations view content provision as being profitable in the future, and the control of access to the Internet will be the key to charging for content.

In the recent US election campaign, President Clinton announced a major initiative concerning the Internet in classrooms, the role of the Internet in people's homes and the strategy he would implement via a legislative mechanism similar to our own universal service obligation. I think there are valuable lessons to be learnt from that, both with respect to education and with respect to ensuring that content is of a high standard and not in the grip of a particular commercial interest.

Another upcoming issue is spectrum allocation. This issue tests legislators, who sometimes grapple with the concept of anticipating where future technologies will emerge from. In other words, we have got to be able to anticipate those developments and not restrict or confine any legislation to specific technologies.

The government has yet to outline its policy position in regard to the procurement of telecommunications technologies. This government has ignored, in the processes of this, local IT manufacturers continuing to purchase offshore. Although the modem market has been tariff free for over a decade, local manufacturers are still restricted by federal policies that favour imported products.

The fundamental tenet of good and reasonable government is its ability to provide basic access and equity to telecommunications. While increasing numbers of Australian homes have become on‐line, many other families are still without video recorders. For those at the bottom end of the scale, wealth now determines access. The information divide between rich and poor, haves and have‐nots, has the potential to create a permanent underclass that will take no part in this revolution, as Paul Crawford has articulated.

The fundamental question is who pays for and who benefits from telecommunications? Is it the users, be they private, business, government or other organisations? Is it the indirect beneficiaries or is it the community at large? Competition for competition's sake ignores the potential of our indigenous IT industry as much as it relies solely on consumer savings as a measure of its success. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats recognise the reality that competition policy will be applied to telecommunications in this country. This raft of bills before us today, as Senator Schacht has said, concludes the direction set by his government back in 1991. Both major parties subscribe to the competition policy and so we must accept that the matter in relation to telecommunications is all over bar the shouting.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, however, two aspects of this debate which we feel bound to put on the public record and about which we know we will hear very little from the government or the opposition.

Firstly, we said in 1991 that the benefits of competition had not been demonstrated. Six years later there is no more evidence that an industry with three major players is more efficient or benefits taxpayers or consumers more than one which is dominated by one player and that player, a publicly owned company. Senator Kernot said then:

We do not believe that competition will necessarily lead to increased productivity and changes in work practices. It is a fact peculiar to telecommunications that technology, as much as competition, is likely to result in lower prices.

Through technology, the cost to deliver STD calls fell dramatically in the 1980s. Charges have not reduced at anything like the pace of the savings, in spite of competition. Of course, the new competitive regime prevented Telstra, at the Senate hearings into these bills, from revealing what the share of its revenue derived from this source is. The new cloak of secrecy, jargonistically referred to as commercial‐in‐confidence, which goes hand in hand with competition, is of major concern to the Democrats—not just for the obvious reasons of accountability but because it significantly reduces the scope for government to plan for the future of telecommunications in this country.

Another fact peculiar to telecommunications is that the government, as owner of Telstra, has determined both the rate of return and the cost to consumers. These two factors will make it conveniently difficult to question the outcomes and challenge that blind faith of adherence to competition policy.

The second matter which must be put on the record is the question of public ownership and responsibility. I ask the Senate to reflect for a moment on what it is actually doing as public custodian of Telstra—one of the largest profit making organisations in this country. I ask the Senate to imagine a board of directors acting as a driving force in reducing its company's market share and therefore the profits it returns to its shareholders. The aim of this legislation is very clearly to reduce Telstra's so‐called market dominance.

Over the past decade, governments have shaped Telstra into a corporation and a highly competitive organisation, encouraged it to eliminate thousands of jobs, to sell off sections of the organisation, such as Visionstream, and to wind back research and development and community service undertakings. Now the government will insist that Telstra gives up a substantial part of its custom in the name of competition.

But, of course, when Telstra behaves like its competitors and fights to defend and expand that market, the major parties accuse it of anti‐competitive behaviour and regulate for so‐called competitive neutrality. When it complains about having to fund directory assistance, to provide untimed calls for data or to give support to advocacy groups—in other words, behaving like any free market operator—the government increasingly waivers.

There are no prizes for guessing who the likely competitors for telecommunications in this country will be. We know we can expect the multi‐billion dollar overseas telecommunications giants to dominate our market in Australia in the not too distant future. There will be more foreign ownership and more profits leaving this country—and from an industry which is perhaps the only one to enjoy a high rate of growth at this time.

I am reminded of the minister's desire that we should regard Telstra as, I think he put it, a 60‐pound gorilla, devouring and destroying its emerging small and medium sized competitors. I think the time has come for us to see Telstra as a medium sized player on a global market competing against foreign giants such as British Telecom.

Three weeks ago, the government announced quietly that it had signed an agreement with another 67 nations that it would not in any way impede the entry of multinational telecommunications companies into this country. Senator Kernot said in 1991 that she believed that the government was so busy tilting the level playing field heavily in favour of the new foreign owned entrant into international telephone services against the incumbent Telecom that the paying public's contribution and shareholding was being ignored. She pointed out that each and every Australian had already made a fundamental investment in the telecommunications network to a tune of $3,500 for each household. Ordinary Australian have already paid to establish a network from which big business in particular is to gain an enormous profit.

Senator Kernot said that for perfectly sound economic reasons Telecom's new competitor is likely to be interested in only the profitable heavy trunkline traffic and the new mobile telephone network—and how right she was. As I said earlier, the Democrats have yet to be convinced that competition is any guarantee of efficiency, better services or lower costs. Competition in the roll‐out of TV cabling has seen carriers riding roughshod over community wishes, aerial cabling just for expediency, expensive duplication of infrastructure and, at the end of the day, deals which will no doubt result in reducing competition being done between carriers.

We also think the major shareholders of Telstra, the Australian people, are getting a raw deal with this legislation. Having said that, the Democrats acknowledge that there is little we can do to reverse this tide of major party support for competition policy. We will, however, remain vigilant and we will continue to highlight the failures of competition as it applies to this important industry.

Today and tomorrow I will be introducing a number of amendments. They will attempt to make the post‐July 1997 competitive regime fairer and they will strengthen the provisions in the legislation to protect rural, marginalised and residential consumers in particular. The Democrats want to see that the benefits of technology are shared much more equitably. We also want to see local government given the planning powers to act in the interests of their communities in relation to telecommunications infrastructure.

The major parties have argued that the powers and immunities from state and local government regulations were given to carriers in the national interest. The Democrats fail to see how the national interest can be threatened by councils insisting that telecommunications cabling is installed underground where there is capacity to do so. We also fail to see why it is that the national interest is threatened by requiring carriers to site mobile phone towers away from schools and kindergartens.

Rather, we think the interest here is that of the telecommunications industry. Telecommunications carriers were granted immunity from state and territory environment planning laws back in 1991 in the Telecommunications Act by the then Labor government with the support, of course, of the coalition. The Australian Democrats were the only party to raise vigorous objections at that time. I remind the Senate that the Democrats position on these powers and immunities has been consistent throughout. Senator Coulter, back in 1991, said:

The Democrats believe that no such power should be available. We believe that there should be the application of State laws to these bodies and we can point to numerous instances where, in the recent past, Telecom with its existing exemptions has engaged in activities that are contrary to State planning, zoning and environmental protection laws. This has caused very considerable disquiet in the local communities and there has been no legislative mechanism properly to correct or to supervise these activities.

Since the immunities were introduced it has been understood that these powers and im munities would be removed from 1 July this year. But in this legislation they are to be extended a further three months and six months for cabling and towers respectively. Senator Alston has said on many occasions that these exemptions will be removed on 1 July and our amendments will hold the government to that commitment.

One of the more worrying provisions of this legislation is the proposed ongoing exemption for so‐called low impact facilities. The Democrats see no reason to support any exemptions, particularly as these definitions have not been made public. We would vigorously oppose mobile phone towers and personal communications transmitters, for instance, being exempted from the normal planning requirements of local government.

The bulk of the Democrats amendments to this legislation will ensure that residential, rural and the more marginal consumers are provided with effective safeguards against the disbenefits of a concentration of services in high density sectors where competition will inevitably be the greatest. We are not convinced that voluntary codes of practice would give adequate consumer protection. I must say we are pleased to see that the government has taken up this issue in its amendments and to see that consumer organisations are represented in the development of these draft codes.

The Democrats also strongly support the establishment of a fund for communications social policy research. Other Democrats amendments will strengthen the universal service obligation. These will include the national relay service in the USO; maintaining free of charge operator assisted directory services and including them as part of the USO; insisting that the USO plans are lodged prior to awarding a tender to a provider; and ensuring that clear and public payphone siting guidelines are developed. The Democrats would have liked to put forward the Austel policy for payphone compliance but we note that this document is, in fact, confidential and I will be asking the minister to expand on why it is that this is not available as a public document.

One of the most striking inadequacies, I think, in this legislation is the provision of telecommunications services to people in rural areas. There are a substantial number of households which do not presently receive the benefits of untimed local calls. There are those who are part of, but just outside, the designated call zone of regional and metropolitan centres and the rural sector, generally, has already suffered from the disproportionate investment in new infrastructure in our cities. In its haste to erect TV cabling and mobile phone towers in metropolitan areas Telstra has, for instance, neglected urgently needed upgrading of technology in country exchanges.

Our amendments will also bind Telstra, as part of the USO, to targets for extending access to digital data capability by the year 2000 for that last 6.6 per cent of customers in Australia. The legislation before us would allow carriers to offer lower charges for local calls in some geographic areas or for some customer groups or individuals but not others. In our view, this goes against any notions of equity and fair play. Our amendments will prohibit price discrimination across call zones on all carriers. Another casualty of competition policy has been coverage of rural Australia by an adequate mobile phone network. The phase‐out of the analogue mobile phone network in advance of complete coverage by the digital system will be a major setback for rural users.

Our amendments will require a review of the phase‐out of the analogue system and a guarantee that analogue will continue to be available until such time as the interference experienced by those users of hearing aids and other equipment is eliminated. This legislation will provide the minister with discretion to exempt carriers from any requirement to prepare industry development plans. Our amendments will make industry development plans a precondition for obtaining a carrier licence and will put in place the necessary enforcement mechanisms.

It is our view that the industry development plans as currently outlined quite needlessly limit their effectiveness as a tool of industry policy and weaken the government's ability to extract desired outcomes for industrial development. Carriers are only required to have an industry development plan in force within 90 days of being granted their licence. We think it is far more appropriate that approval of industry plans by the industry minister be made a prerequisite for obtaining a licence. This would guarantee that the government had more leverage and that industry development plans were not simply bureaucratic procedures which had no relevance in themselves.

I have indicated some of the amendments to be put by the Democrats, but I wish to take the opportunity to say how very difficult it has been for us to frame up the amendments in the impossibly short time frame that has been available. The government's own amendments have been available to us only in the last two days and even so were in draft form. The ALP amendments have still not been seen by us in their entirety. I want to refer to a motion put by Senator Alston in 1991 when similarly complex telecommunications legislation was before the Senate. His motion condemned the government's failure to allow reasonable time for consideration of the measure.

The consideration of these very important and complex bills has been squeezed into a very short time period. We have already expressed concern at the insistence of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee that submissions to its inquiry should be in the form of amendments to bills.

As I understand it, we now have the opposition agreeing with the government to bring on these bills when the government's own amendments—some 300 pages—were received only a matter of hours ago and we still do not have all of the opposition's amendments. The Democrats believe that this is very unreasonable. This legislation is very important. It is impossible for us to properly deal with the legislation in this time frame.

No doubt the opposition will mention the industrial relations agreement that was reached between the Democrats and the government late last year. I remind the opposition that, under those circumstances, two full days were given for the scrutiny of those IR bills and agreements. This, as I understand it, is not planned to be afforded to the Democrats today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a feeling of deja vu about this debate because a number of the issues canvassed were canvassed in the Telstra sale bill. It is a pity that some of those issues were not taken cognisance of. Today I want to address my concerns about the impact of the Telecommunications Bill 1996 and cognate bills on rural and regional Australia. The Telecommunications Bill is a very large bill. A lot of reviewing has gone into it, and it entirely replaces the legislation which currently regulates the telecommunications industry. I think it grossly discriminates against the residents of rural and regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The most discriminatory parts of the bill are found in part 7. Part 7 purports to ensure that all people in Australia, wherever they reside or carry on business, will have access on an equitable basis to standard telephone services, pay phones and other prescribed carriage services. Its main defects relate to the specification of the universal service obligation. Clause 144 is the key provision of part 7 because it defines the universal service obligation. The clause is problematic because of the definition of the standard telephone service—that is, the bedrock service which must be provided to all people under the universal service obligation.

As the explanatory memorandum notes, part 7 of the proposed act is based on part 13 of the 1991 act. The explanatory memorandum asserts that the current act has been effective in delivering universal service to date. It is true that under public ownership Telstra provided a national service that was high by world standards. Telephone penetration is in excess of 96 per cent of Australian households compared with 94 per cent in the USA and 90 per cent in the United Kingdom.

Consumers generally enjoy direct, uninterrupted access to the national network. However, in basing part 7 on part 13 of the current act, the government has seriously erred. It has failed to take into account in the last six years the rapid convergence of technologies currently taking place and the increasing demand for services such as rapid fax trans missions, e-mail, the Internet, electronic commerce and educational applications.

The old voice telephony service is no longer good enough for the majority of Australians. This error, if allowed to go uncorrected, has potentially disastrous consequences for regional Australia in particular. This is because the provision of advanced telecommunications services to much of rural and remote Australia is uneconomic. Unless such services are specified as part of the universal service obligation, no carrier will provide them in the foreseeable future.

The government attempts to explain its failure to properly address the issue by saying in the explanatory memorandum that, due to the important regulatory role played by the standard telephone service, its definition can be adjusted by prescribing other purposes and by precisely specifying performance characteristics. The explanatory memorandum states:

. . . the ability to prescribe additional purposes for the standard telephone service provides an effective functionality‐based means of clarifying or upgrading the standard telephone service over time.

That is good public service jargon. In other words, residential consumers in rural areas will be stuck with the plain old handset, together with the government's assurance that it will clarify or upgrade the standard telephone service by regulation under the act and over time.

I would have thought the appropriate time for this clarification, for this to be spelt out clearly, would be now whilst this act over considerable time undergoes one of the most significant rewrites ever. It does not occur to the government to do that. No, it wants to keep us out there in the bush in the horse and buggy era, while allowing those in the city areas to have all sorts of mod cons that we can only dream about.

As I say, this is not good enough. I have no reason to believe that the government, in fact, will upgrade the definition of the standard telephone service. Why would it? People who already are getting into the industry will not be in any great hurry to see themselves having to pay more in connection with the universal service obligation or to see increases in services included under it, because they will cost them more money.

In my speech on the Telstra sale bill, I spoke about the standard telephone service review group that had been set up by Minister Alston in July. I questioned then, and I question now, why the Telstra sale bill was not held over until this information and report had become available.

When Minister Alston announced the review, he lauded it. He said that it was being undertaken by a very good group of people; they were a very broad representation of a very wide cross-section of the industry and the consumers. It did have representatives of Telstra, Optus, Vodafone, ATUG—the Australian Telecommunications Users Group—National Farmers Federation and consumer groups. There were 10 people on that committee which put out a report on 5 or 6 February—an interesting report.

Nine of the 10 committee members put out a majority report comprising 178 pages of well argued information and recommendations. There also was a six-page minority report from Professor Ergas. Guess which of those two reports the minister decided to talk about and praise in response? It was the six-six page minority report of Professor Ergas. It was not the majority report of the representatives of all the industry, consumer and telecommunications users groups and the National Farmers Federation. I wonder why.

I suspect that one of the reasons is—and it is pretty obvious now with this legislation—that the nine‐member majority report recommended `a cautious upgrade of the telephone service to digital data capability by the year 2000'. That would mean that everybody in Australia by the year 2000 would have access to digital data capability, fast faxes, e‐mail and Internet at a reasonable standard and reasonable speed.

Prior to the election we had this now government, the then opposition, running around saying, `Everybody in Australia will be on ISDN by the middle of this year.' Whoops, it forgot about the six per cent who are remote. By the middle of this year 94 per cent of Australians will have ISDN access, and that is good. But what about the six-per cent? That six per cent is scattered across most of the states and one of the territories in this country.

Access to these services by children who are undertaking distance education would be of great assistance to them. These children would benefit greatly from good access to the Internet, good e-mail and good fax stream access. They would improve and enhance their educational standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have, if you had given it to them too.

—We had, and still have, a policy of the year 2000, because we see that as realistic. It is interesting when you read the press comments of the time. An article by Anne Davies published in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 February entitled `Rural phone reform less likely' picked up some comments from Allan Horsley who was the chair of the committee. He said of Senator Alston's press release that it was `almost an insult to the committee' and that it was `grossly inappropriate that the work be given the offhand treatment it has, especially as the committee included the carriers'.

SPEECH.PARA: There was an interesting article by Steve Lewis in the Financial Review on 7 February entitled `Alston stirs up static over digital access costs query'. Again, there Allan Horsley's comments are noted that the minister risked losing the `confidence of the industry if he ignored a substantial body of work undertaken over a reasonable period of time'. Graham Lynch, in an article in the Australian of 11 February entitled `Alston weighs up cost of national ISDN standard', again quotes Allan Horsley that `the work and opinion of a reasonable bunch of people has been set aside by one distant professor. He has an academic ultra‐dry view, which has as much relevance as cows jumping over the moon'.

These are scathing media comments which were made at the time the minister was making known his support for the minority report. It is interesting because, as I have stated, Mr Horsley was the chair of Senator Alston's expert working group, established in mid-1996 to assist in the formulation of policy to guide the drafting of the post-July 1997 legislation. Julie Austin of the National Farmers Federation has also strongly criticised the minority report. So you can see that there is a great deal of concern being expressed by people who know about, and have an interest in, this issue. The minister's reaction to this and what will happen to standard services, standard definitions and access to the data is of grave concern.

Another issue that is of grave concern to people in the bush is what might be done to local call rates. There has been talk of encouraging competition between the various capital cities, that there will be an average and that the country people will get the average. That is not fair. That is not the equal playing field under which competition can exist. You will be putting a greater impost on country industries and businesses to compete against their city counterparts when, in fact, they will be financially disadvantaged.
