TALK.START.PARA: —This message concerning Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is being dealt with in rather a hasty manner given the circumstances that have arisen. I trust that the chamber understands the manner in which we enter this debate. It is a most extraordinary way of doing business.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequential amendment to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is one which the opposition welcomes in that the government has come to accept the Senate's original amendments—amendments Nos 1, 2 and 4 that were proposed by the government in the Senate—which flowed from a welcome and constructive relationship that has developed notwithstanding the differences that still exist between the opposition and the government on these matters. When these measures were first brought before the parliament, the opposition expressed the view that a number of them were harsh and unjustifiable.

The government wrongly claimed it needed these measures in order to deliver the program it had announced for 1996-97. The fact is that Labor in government delivered programs of a similar size in successive years without resorting to such harsh measures. The opposition was very concerned that a gulf had opened up in the public sphere of debate on immigration matters. In discussions with the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), the shadow minister Mr Kerr made it clear that common ground could be reached and, in so far as it was possible, the opposition would enable that to happen.

The minister took up some of these matters and, as a result, undertook not to proceed with increasing the English education charges at least for this budgetary period. We thank him for that. However, we do not know what the government's intention is with respect to the next budget round, and we have some apprehension on that score.

We hold the view that it is wrong in principle to increase the English language charges. At the last election the coalition said that they were operating on the basis that `a common language is the glue of a cohesive nation'. It seems hypercritical to us that, in the first budget that this government brought down, they increased the cost of English education for migrants by some 200 per cent which therefore restricted access to such tuition.

The parliament expresses the correct precedence that it gives to the importance of the English language and, through this mechanism, the parliament will give proper priority to ensure that new arrivals in this country are able to access tuition at a cost which is not excessive. In recognition of this fact the minister has deleted the English education charges from the increases being pursued by this government.

Another area in which the minister has indicated there is some capability of modification has been the issue of de facto and interdependent applications and a prior cohabitation period. There has been some suggestion that the opposition has taken the view that it would be inappropriate for the government to insist on verification of the substance of de facto and interdependent relationships before they enter this country. That was never the case when we were in government, and in opposition we have supported the government on a number of matters which further tightens screening procedures, including the introduction of a two‐year probationary visa for off-shore applicants whether they were married, de facto or interdependent.

On this bill, we stood ready to assist the minister on all reasonable measures to ensure that any necessary tightening could be dealt with. We did so, however, on the basis that we had a genuine concern about the application of a scheme that would have required a two-year prior cohabitation period outside of Australia for applicants to establish legitimacy of a de facto or interdependent relationship. Many people who have travelled overseas and established a relationship which they regard as akin to a marriage‐like relationship would have found it impossible to access this scheme.

Indeed, what would have flowed from this is an increase in the so-called sham marriages. In other words, people who had put themselves forward as couples in a genuine relationship but who, for various reasons, chose not to consummate the relationship by formal marriage would have been compelled to go through a marriage ceremony they did not desire to have. More importantly though, this would not have been available to interdependent couples. The interdependency class, which is certainly not required as a matter of law, is utilised by people who form same sex relationships. Of course, such persons are not in a position to formalise their relationship by a marriage‐like ceremony. The result is that it would have opened up an area of discrimination in public policy.

The minister has undertaken that, in exercising his power to create regulations under these provisions, the period will be set at no longer than 12 months. The minister has recognised that this may still create some particular instances of hardship; so a discretion will reside with the minister enabling him to waive the requirement in certain circumstances.

I will now move to the issue of capping. We note that the government has also accepted amendment No. 3 but has done so with some reluctance. The government has moved in the House a further amendment enabling us to cap and queue the aged parent category. The issue at stake is the principle that was established in legislation, which was proposed by the now minister when he was an opposition spokesman and agreed to by the then government, that we would exempt direct family members—that is, husbands and wives, dependent children and aged parents—from arrangements relating to the power of the government to determine or to cap the number of family members who could enter the country under this provision.

But even then there was a distinction between, on the one hand, husbands and wives and dependent children and, on the other, aged parents. Inherent in the arrangement was that people did not have an absolute right to bring their aged parents here because of the balance of family test. The test means that for people to be eligible to come, they had to have at least half their children in this country.

When this bill came before the Senate the shadow minister had reached an agreed position with the minister that we were prepared to propose an amendment giving effect to enable the government to cap and queue the aged parent category, but the government insisted on taking the vote to the brink and testing the numbers in the Senate for the power to cap all categories. The minister recognised in opposition that it was no task of government to deal with those matters. In fact, he said that it would be unconscionable for the government to do such a thing and it would cause agony. The government has been spared this agony by its welcome concession.

I conclude by saying that the opposition will support the amendments, given that it was an amendment that we were prepared to move. I believe that we can say that there has been some cooperation, which has produced a fruitful and commonsense approach on this matter. We firmly say, however, that no government should restrict the most fundamental of all human rights—that is, the right of persons to choose to marry and start a family.

In the debate on the matter I made it perfectly clear that the problem with the government's previous approach is that you have a very important principle. Yes, it is if you are talking about societal rights in the sense that marriage and the family are the foundation of any civilised society. I do not propose to go over the areas that I canvassed on the previous occasion, nor do I intend to go over the areas that I canvassed when talking at length on Migration Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996, No. 211.

It is very heartening to see that the government has accepted the overwhelming view that was stated on 3 March 1997 by the Senate in respect of capping and queuing of spouses. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine is quite right in drawing my attention to an injudicious use of the expression `most fundamental of human rights'. I indicated as I rushed down to participate in this matter, which was brought on very suddenly, and it was in fact a position that I would not—

It ought to come on tomorrow night, as scheduled and as foreshadowed for weeks now, in its own good time and when the people of the Northern Territory can listen to that debate.
—I seek leave to make a few comments and then move a motion.

—I would be happy to grant Senator Abetz leave to make a short statement. I am not willing to grant him leave to make a short statement and move a motion. He may seek leave to move a motion at a later stage. So I am happy to grant leave to allow Senator Abetz to address the Senate for five minutes.
—We have certainly got a clear indication from Senator Faulkner, but I would like to get an indication from the whole Senate.

—I can assure honourable senators that I will not take five minutes. In very general terms, the submission put by Senator Brown to this chamber this evening would have a degree of credibility and sincerity about it but for the fact that Dr Philip Nitschke was on the parliamentary network today broadcasting the fact that the honourable senator would in fact be using every delaying tactic possible to avoid the discus sion of this very piece of legislation. That is the only statement I wish to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Brown gives his principal concern as being that the people of the Northern Territory will not be able to listen to the debate. We are on broadcasting time and if any sensible Northern Territorian is listening to the debate—

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senator interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not get it up there? Good luck to them! I was going to say that they would not be sensible, because if I were them I would be listening to the test between Australia and South Africa, to be frank. That would have been a more sensible reason for not having this debate at this present point in time than the one given by Senator Brown.

SPEECH.PARA: We all agree, whether we are for the legislation or against it, that the Euthanasia Laws Bill is a major matter of public policy which should be determined by consideration by this chamber. The legislation has been put forward in the House of Representatives, it has come before us and we have to tackle it at some stage. Why not start tonight? There has been no reasonable cause put forward by Senator Brown for it not to be considered tonight—either that or he wants to gag the thing. Does he want to gag debate on it? If not, why can't we at least start dealing with it tonight? As I understand it, people in the chamber, with the exception of Senator Brown, want to start on it tonight. We are going to be pressed for time. I do not think anybody, frankly, whether they are supporting or opposing the bill, wants to gag the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's an unconscionable delaying tactic.

—As Senator Abetz said, it is an unconscionable delaying tactic. We ought to all agree to deal with it tonight in the two hours that we have. If we are fortunate enough to get through all of the debate on it before time in the second reading stage, then so much the better. I do not think, with all due respect, that denying leave to have this matter debated as part of the ongoing debate tonight is serving any useful purpose other than to put off the day when the determination will need to be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I had not intended to make any contributions in the chamber tonight about this or any other matter. But I am provoked by the comments of Senator Harradine, who has just sat down, that there is a move on to gag the debate or even to delay the debate on euthanasia. My understanding, as a member of this chamber, is that the debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill commences at 8 p.m. tomorrow or perhaps a little bit earlier. I understand that that has been agreed to by all the major parties and the Independents in this chamber. So, if there is any delay, or attempt to delay or attempt to gag the debate, I do not think it is happening here, because we have not reached that appointed hour when the debate is to start.
—Say it with a straight face.

—I am saying it with a straight face. There is something very strange happening with this private member's bill, which has been brought into the parliament and which is receiving treatment that no other private member's bill that I have known of in my time in this chamber has ever received.

SPEECH.PARA: This private member's bill was debated in the other place. Was it debated in the chamber or was it debated, as one member of the other place described it, in sideshow alley? Is this bill so important that we have to debate it in the dead of night, when the Senate would normally be adjourned—from eight o'clock onwards? Is it so important that we use the debate on this bill to act as a filler because we have got into some problems with other pieces of legislation which are before the parliament? I do not know. Let us all make a judgment on that and do it, as one of my colleagues opposite said earlier, with a straight face. Let us do it on a matter of principle. Let us start the debate now, tonight, and continue the debate when the Senate sits again tomorrow. Let us give this bill the priority that some in this place think it deserves. Let us continue it through government business tomorrow.

BREAK.PARA: If it is good enough to debate the bill in government business tonight 17 March 1997, it is good enough to debate it within government business tomorrow 18 March, as well. I hope, from a personal point of view, that we do get on and debate this bill and get a decision on it. I think the matter has hung around for far too long. As a member of the committee that had carriage of the matter and that took advice from the public, I was involved in the process more than most other members in the chamber.

I think the parliament of Australia has probably reached the position where it can make a decision on this matter. Whether or not it is going to be an informed decision can only be revealed through the processes of the debate. Whilst I am rising, as it were, in tacit opposition to not bringing the debate on, if there were to be a vote on it, I would not vote against the debate being brought on tonight. I just want to get the thing over and done with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make what I also consider to be very important statements on this particular piece of private member's legislation which has the effect of overriding legislation of the Northern Territory parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Many senators will recall that, earlier this year, 450 territorians attended a public forum on the issue of voluntary euthanasia, convened by Senator Bob Collins and me in Darwin on the evening prior to the public hearings of the Senate special committee that was investigating this matter. It was quite apparent to any of us who attended that meeting in Darwin that for 450 people to attend a public forum and for 51 of them to speak at that public forum there was a great deal of community interest in this particular matter. The matter has been before the Northern Territory parliament and has been circulating in the Northern Territory community now for some considerable time.

It is therefore with a great deal of anticipation and expectation that territorians are keen to listen to the full debate that is to proceed in this parliament this week. Whilst I appreci ate that Senator Harradine has pointed out that we are currently broadcasting—and being broadcast on the air—I would like to point out that, by arrangement with the ABC and the Parliamentary News Network, a historic arrangement has been struck. For the first time in the Northern Territory, the debates of this parliament are to be broadcast from 7.20 tomorrow night and on the subsequent two evenings of this debate. Whilst, like Senator McKiernan, I will not oppose any motion to proceed with debate tonight, the fact that it will be brought forward is important.

The other point I would make is that, last Saturday evening in Darwin, I attended a historic celebration of the 50th anniversary of the commencement of ABC broadcasting in the Northern Territory and, likewise, I believe that tomorrow night's event was to be historic. I know that the mechanics of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation are in Darwin at this very moment working on the final arrangements to enable the broadcasting to proceed and to cover the next three nights of deliberation and debate in this place.

Therefore, I counsel any of my Senate colleagues who wish to speak tonight, who may well have wanted those territorians to hear the contributions they make to any side or any perspective of this important debate, to be mindful of the fact that, as of tomorrow night, I can assure them that at least those 450 people who attended the public forum, if not many more, would want to hear and participate in the special arrangements that I appreciate that Madam President, Mr Speaker, the broadcasting committee of this parliament and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation have set in place to enable the proper and appropriate coverage of this particular debate.

As I said, like Senator McKiernan, I will not oppose any motion tonight, but I certainly ask senators to be mindful of the last minute precedents that are being created and changes that are being made because of the other arrangements to the legislative program for the night, and which we have only become aware of in the last half hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move that intervening business be postponed until after consideration of general business order of the day relating to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Harradine moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to the consideration of the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

It would be fair to say that the Euthanasia Laws Bill has been within the Australian community for some considerable period of time. I think the people of Australia are entitled to believe that most of us have given due consideration to the matters that are contained in the Euthanasia Laws Bill. The issues have been widely canvassed in the Northern Territory, in the media around Australia and indeed before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, on which I had the pleasure of serving.

Today we have been sitting, deliberately, to try to make up some time in the considerable agenda that this Senate faces. Having said that, we have now come into a situation where, as a result of last minute amendments to other legislation which other parties need to consider in detail, there is somewhat of a hiatus in the Senate's program.All honourable senators would have before them a speakers list which indicates that some 50 honourable senators wish to participate in this debate.

A considerable period of time will be used in this place to consider the Euthanasia Laws Bill. When we have the opportunity of two hours of debating time being made available, albeit at short notice, I believe it is appropriate to bring on this piece of legislation which is genuinely ready to be debated. Everybody has considered their position and a lot of us wish to make a contribution to that legislation.

It is quite clear that the people of Australia expect us to deal with this legislation, not have it dragged out. We have the opportunity of using two hours of the Senate's time to consider this piece of legislation. With due respect to some of those senators opposite, and in particular Senator Brown, it is now on public record through the good offices of Dr Nitschke—I do not know whether what I have been advised is right or wrong—that every single delaying tactic would be employed. I would have thought that if there is a speakers list of honourable senators ready to make a contribution, which there is—well over half a dozen of them, as I understand it; it is a list of eight speakers—and they are prepared to start the debate today at this very moment, there is no good reason why that should not be allowed to occur.

Sure, the people of the Northern Territory might not benefit from the pearls of wisdom of those of us who speak tonight. They might have to read the Hansard rather than listen to the parliamentary broadcast. But I would have to say, with due deference to my colleague Senator Tambling, that if they are so genuinely interested in hearing or seeing what those of us who are going to make a contribution this evening have to say, there is the Hansard available for those people in the Northern Territory to read and consider our comments. I dare say the Northern Territory media outlets will give appropriate time and air play to the various comments made by honourable senators during the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pearls of wisdom will be reported; fear not.
—Senator Collins has confirmed that the pearls of wisdom will be fairly reported—
—As they always are.

—As they always are—in the Northern Territory. The question is: why should this debate be delayed? Senator McKiernan did make some comments earlier on but I have to say to Senator McKiernan—with due respect—that it is not unusual for legislation to sometimes come on and be moved up the agenda if the other legislation does not materialise because there is a hiatus in the agenda. I would simply recommend to honourable senators that they support the course of action. Let us get the debate under way because I think the people of Australia do want this issue resolved one way or the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to very briefly indicate to the Senate that as far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned there will be no party discipline in relation to this particular vote for a suspension of standing orders. We have made our position clear that procedural matters relating to the Euthanasia Laws Bill as well as to the substance of the bill are matters of conscience for senators in this chamber and members of the House of Representatives who represent the Australian Labor Party. As a result, there will not be any party discipline in relation to this particular vote; it will be a matter for individual Labor senators to determine whether they believe it is appropriate for this debate to continue at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to briefly indicate that the reason we are debating this motion is that government business before us was concluded at 8.40 p.m., so there is no further government business. I think we all take account of the fact that the Senate is sitting today on a public holiday. We have made a range of special arrangements to enable the Senate to deal with the euthanasia bill. It includes a number of late night sittings which a number of senators obviously are prepared for.

But in this circumstance—I think a very unusual circumstance, with a special day's sitting on a public holiday and where the Senate effectively has run out of government business—it is now an issue for the Senate, up till the hour of 11 o'clock tonight, to determine whether it believes it is appropriate for this bill to come forward for debate. That is an issue, as far as Australian Labor Party senators are concerned, that they will determine as they see fit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly I could have moved some time ago that the Senate adjourn. I think the time available is time that can be used, by leave, as I said earlier, for those wanting to contribute to the bill. Government senators will be in the same position as the Australian Labor Party senators and will be voting on any procedural motion in relation to this as a matter of conscience. The government will not stand in their way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to these proceedings basically since the suspension of standing orders, which was somewhere between half past eight and a quarter to nine, and we have been debating ever since whether we are going to have a debate or not. It is probably proper to bring that to a close. I want to briefly indicate my position on this issue. Both sides I think very responsibly have taken a position of allowing a free vote on procedure. That also happened in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I again find myself on exactly the same footing as my colleague from the Northern Territory, Senator Tambling. Senator Tambling made the point quite properly about the extraordinary procedures being taken care of at the moment in the Northern Territory. The way in which the territory tends to be forgotten and left out in these matters is interesting. I was interested in Senator Harradine's contribution, which I know was made in the best of faith, that people in the territory who wanted to listen would be listening now.

We do not have either the benefit or the detriment, depending on which way you look at it, of parliamentary broadcasting in the Northern Territory. As an Australian first and a territorian second—but a close second—I have always regretted that subtle exclusion of those of us in the Northern Territory who have an interest in federal affairs and who would like to listen to parliamentary debates. This episode tonight simply puts the spotlight on the fact that we do not have this facility in the Northern Territory. I would like to thank both the President and the Speaker for the efforts that they have made. This legislation does, in effect, only impact—and impact severely, depending on which side of the debate you are—the law making powers in the parliament of the Northern Territory in which I served for 10 years.

I want to draw some attention to just how extraordinary this private member's bill is that we are dealing with. People keep talking about it as a private member's bill. I am sure over the last few months that, when the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Campbell) and a number of his frontbench colleagues, along with opposition and independent members, were scratching their collective heads trying to fit in a long debate, they wished the same priority being attached to this private member's bill could be attached to government legislation.

The reason I make that statement is that a number of ministers—not in respect of the Euthanasia Laws Bill—have publicly grizzled and complained, as we all did when in government, about the fact that they have been trying might and main to get their own legislation on the debating calendar and have failed. As Senator Abetz pointed out to this chamber, a number of people have gone on the public record saying that their primary objective in this debate is to delay the bill, to string it out so that there will not be a vote and to put it off as far into the future as possible.

Despite my views on euthanasia being different from those of Senator Tambling, we are ad idem on the question of the bill itself. I do not think it is in anyone's interests, and certainly not that of territorians, whichever side of the debate you are on, to delay this unnecessarily any longer. There is no argument that there is a hiatus in here tonight. I do not think there will be an argument over the responsibility for that. The fact is that there is a hiatus.

The reason I make that point—and I make it with some feeling—is that of the loneliness of the long distance politician. I have flogged down here gladly in the sense that I am a member of this parliament and I have a very good attendance record in the 10 years that I have been here. In fact, I am proud to say that when in government I had an impeccable record in the ministry for attending this parliament. However, it is a long way to come for a half‐day debate.

I want to point out the extraordinary measures that have been taken to get this private member's bill through. We have called the Senate back here today to make time for the euthanasia legislation. We have brought the Senate back in here with those officers that are obliged to serve the chambers, not the parliamentary committees. I spent an unproductive morning wanting to finish off the drafting of two Senate reports that I have an interest in. I was not able to effectively do that because the staff of the committees are not here, and neither should they be. The expense of bringing them in would have been horrendous.

I want to make the point that some quite extraordinary provisions have been taken and some extraordinary expense has been gone to in expediting this so-called private member's bill. I do not think people should be getting too hung up on that at all. I must join with Senator Tambling in protesting this, but I will not be opposing the vote for the debate to go on tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this motion. As I said earlier, it is quite wrong because of a hiatus in government business—although more than 50 pieces of legislation are slated to be debated in the Senate—to bring on the Euthanasia Laws Bill, the debate of which territorians are waiting to listen to tomorrow night. As Senator Collins has just said, Senator Harradine was wrong in saying that they can listen to it tonight. They cannot because this debate is not being beamed to the territory. A very special effort has been made to ensure that territorians could listen to this piece of legislation when debated by the Senate tomorrow, the next night and the night after that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite wrong and it is patronising to the people of the territory for Senator Abetz to get up and say, `Well, they can read it in Hansard.' It is totally patronising to the people in the territory who want to see their euthanasia laws protected and who are vitally concerned about the debate. If those people in the corridors saying that the Andrews bill will get through are correct, surely the territorians have the right to listen to the reasons for that event occurring in this place.

Let us go back to the cause of this hiatus tonight: the government has not been able to get one piece of legislation, out of 50, ready to be debated here. I reiterate: the Telstra bill connected with money for the environment was being debated here a fortnight ago. It was taken off because the government would be debating or negotiating the matter with the Democrats. The fortnight has now passed, so why can't it be brought back on? I suggest that it cannot be brought back on because the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) is not here. And, because he is not here, the Euthanasia Laws Bill will be shoved on and accelerated forward.

Let me categorically reject the suggestion, which I have heard a couple of times from those opposite, that I will do anything to delay the Euthanasia Laws Bill. It will be debated in the next few nights. I will not stop that. I will take my part and my constituency seriously in having input to that debate. But, like Senator Collins, I am aware also that there is an inordinate rush to bring on this mightily important piece of conscience legislation to get it through this place as fast as possible—and override the Northern Territory laws as far as possible.

Tonight that rush is becoming unseemly and reprehensible. The people of the territory deserve to be given more consideration by the Senate. I submit that the people of this country deserve to be given a better go by the Senate. I think it is quite wrong that, because the government is so inept as to not have one of those 50 pieces of legislation ready for debate, it now wants to break an agreement, a general arrangement which was agreed to by all parties in this place, and rush on this euthanasia legislation in a time slot where the start of this very important debate cannot be heard by Northern Territorians. It is very wrong, it is totally inconsiderate and, if allowed to happen, it will leave a pretty black mark against the government.

There will be a conscience vote on this matter. However, I appeal to members of the Senate: in voting on this motion, consider those people who are not being heard and who cannot hear what is going on here tonight—and they are the people of the Northern Territory, who above all ought to be given our consideration and ought be able to hear the debate about a matter which is so important to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be one minute. What Senator Brown says is absolute nonsense.
—You would say that.
—Yes, I would say it, because it happens to be absolute nonsense.
—That is your opinion.
—No, it happens to be absolute nonsense. You are suggesting that we are attempting to rush on this piece of legislation.
—I am not suggesting it; I am saying it.

—Yes, I know, which is absolutely wrong. This is a hiatus. We have had this happen very often in my experience of being here for over 21 years. We have often had that happen. And around the chamber we have decided, `Well, yes, we'll bring this or that piece of legislation on'—and generally it has been with agreement. It appears, Senator Brown, that you are the only one in this chamber who is opposing this particular proposition; and we will see.

SPEECH.PARA: We will not deny Northern Territorians what they were to get anyhow. They, God bless them, were going to be able to listen to the debate in this chamber tomorrow night, on Wednesday night and on Thursday night. The territorians, if we start this debate tonight, will still be able to hear our dulcet tones when we debate this measure tomorrow night, Wednesday night and Thursday night. We are not delaying, nor are we denying them.

What we are doing is recognising that we need to do something between now and 11 o'clock tonight. The fact of the matter is that some senators, given the huge list wanting to contribute to the second reading debate, would not be able to do so if debate were confined to tomorrow night, Wednesday night and Thursday night only. I am voting for the motion by Senator Abetz because it will enable those senators who would not otherwise be able to contribute to the debate to do so—and to do so in the extra time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—
—Hey, it's your amendments bringing this about.

—That is what I wanted to speak about, Senator. I understand that the government, in the search for the guilty in that they cannot manage their own government business when time has been made available, may well point the finger about the—
—We have not done so; we won't.

—Fine. But I want to put some facts on the record about the dealings with the telecommunications bill. There has been extraordinary cooperation between all parties and the government over the process of dealing with the telecommunications bill. Going right back to when the bill was introduced, the opposition made an immediate offer to refer it straight to the legislative committee of ERCA in the Senate, on which the government has a majority, to deal with any disputes about amendments—and I outlined that in my second reading speech today—and so on.

BREAK.PARA: The recommendations that came through from the Senate committee were, in detail, overwhelmingly supported by all sides on that committee. There are a number of areas where there are amendments where we and the Democrats would oppose the government's position. But one should point out that the government—and I do not blame it for this—only last Friday circulated 93 pages of amendments which had to be added to the telecommunications bill; and that those amendments overwhelmingly were in response to the unanimous recommendations of the Senate committee, most of which, I have to say on behalf of the opposition, we will vote for.

We did not get hold of those amendments until late Friday night. Over the weekend it is difficult to examine their drafting if they make changes to any of your own amendments. Certainly the Democrats had long indicated that they had many more amendments than the opposition to put forward on a range of issues. They have said, `We can't draft our amendments until we see the government's amendments,' which they were dealing with today. What happened tonight is that, as they were trying do that, a 400‐ or 500‐page bill came in here to be debated without a decent running sheet detailing all the amendments—and that just should not be done.

I do not blame the Democrats and I do not blame the government; it was just the logistics of what has come up. I am a little surprised that when it was accepted that the telecommunications package be adjourned until tomorrow the government was not able to find some other government measure to come back—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because no‐one was expecting it to fall over.
—Even so, in view of the range of bills that are on the list for this last two weeks, I would have thought one of them somewhere, even if it was non-controversial, could have been brought in here—
—The manager thought that too.

—Well, I just find it difficult to believe that there were not some available. Now we find that we use this time on this issue of euthanasia in the Northern Territory. I am told that apparently this procedural issue might be a conscience vote. I do not know whether that is true or not.
—It is true. We are all at sea now.

—So we are all at sea now. My own view is that if the time has been set aside from tomorrow to start the euthanasia bill that is when it should start. It is just unfortunate that there is no other government business to be debated tonight. But I do not think the problem can be corrected by bringing on the euthanasia bill when everyone had agreed that there were set times for that to be dealt with starting tomorrow. Even though there are many speakers I think it is only reasonable that that start tomorrow when people expected it to.

BREAK.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Abetz's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Motion (by Senator Abetz at the request of Senator Harradine) agreed to:
That general business order of the day No. 62, relating to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, have precedence over all other business today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That a motion in the following terms may be moved forthwith and have precedence till determined over any motion or order of the day for any stage in the passage of, or for the consideration of, any bill concerning euthanasia or laws relating to euthanasia:
That the Senate endorses the right to voluntary euthanasia as expressed in the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995.

I have moved this because of the unseemly haste with which I believe some members of the Senate at least are trying to push forward the debate on the bill itself. I have no objection to the Euthanasia Laws Bill being debated and it will be debated this week and in the coming week but, as I said earlier, the territorians above all have an interest in this piece of legislation. I believe very deeply and implicitly that every means possible should be afforded to the people of the Northern Territory to take part in this debate by at least hearing it and being able to respond to it over the coming days.

Predicating that belief is my support for the territory to be self‐determining in the matter of voluntary euthanasia. It goes without saying that there was great deliberation in the territory. There was a preponderance of support in the territory and there was three times a vote in the territory for their voluntary euthanasia measure, their pioneering measure which has broken through as far as the inexorable move to voluntary euthanasia right around this world is concerned.

That legislation I put in the same camp as the pioneering legislation in New Zealand and South Australia 100 years ago which gave women the vote, and legislation earlier than that which gave children the right to education, and earlier still the legislation which freed people from slavery in certain parts of this planet. This is a part of the civilising progress of our world community.

Members opposite may disagree with that but who could agree with them in trying to rush this legislation through and leave the people of the territory out? I believe the people of the territory have their right to determine this matter and they have spoken loudly on this matter. What we ought to be debating is that right in the territory of the people to voluntary euthanasia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania determining the Franklin River, Bob?
—Senator Abetz laughs at the matter but, above all, I take it seriously.
—No. I am laughing at you, Bob.

—I am going to make my major contribution to this debate when the second reading of the bill comes on in due course. But I say at this stage that we should be at least in this Senate free of all other considerations endorsing the right to voluntary euthanasia as expressed in the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act for all Australians. It is a matter for all Australians to have that right.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter for the whole of this country that individuals in their dying process have access to voluntary euthanasia if they so choose. It is a matter of individual rights for every person in this country. We have to pay tribute to the Northern Territory for the fact that it has expressed that right for the people of the least populous of all the states and territories on mainland Australia. What my motion explicitly calls on the Senate to recognise is that that right which the Territorians have taken for themselves ought to be a right for everybody, for all Australians.

I point the Senate to the persistent opinion polls which, since the 1950s, without failure, have shown that the majority of Australians wish for themselves the right to access voluntary euthanasia should they find themselves terminally ill, suffering, in pain and in undignified circumstances, and should they decide, along with their loved ones and their medical attendants, that enough is enough, that they cannot return to a full productive life, that they are terminally ill and that they want to end their suffering peacefully with their loved ones around them. Surely that is not too much for every individual in this country to be afforded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I support voluntary euthanasia.
—Do it in the second reading debate.
—As I understand it, the Senate has voted to enable the euthanasia debate, as it is called, to take place. The debate has now started.
—He is moving suspension of standing orders.

—He is moving suspension of standing orders so that his contingent motion, which is on page 36 of the Notice Paper , takes precedence. That is fine. It says—this is why I am attracted to it—that if the suspension is carried `the Senate endorses the right to voluntary euthanasia as expressed in the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995'. I am supporting it because this is putting the issue of support for voluntary euthanasia in the positive.

SPEECH.PARA: When, like every other senator, I have been written to by hundreds of people about this issue, I have made it quite clear that I oppose the Andrews bill.
