SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are entering the final stages of debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, which will culminate in a vote of the Senate. Since the bill has already been supported in the House of Representatives, its passage here would effectively confirm the current laws banning euthanasia in the states and the Australian Capital Territory and overrule the action of the Northern Territory government in legalising euthanasia.

SPEECH.PARA: In my contribution to the debate, I do not wish to canvass the constitutional position. This has been more than adequately covered in the House of Representatives. Nor do I wish to address the issue of morality—this, too, has been effectively addressed.

All of us in the Senate come from different backgrounds. We bring viewpoints unique to each of us as we are not constrained by party discipline. My own perspective is from that of a doctor, one who graduated in medicine from the University of Queensland in 1956 and who has practised surgery predominantly in cancer of the breast, bowel and melanoma. I am a fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh, England and Australasia. For 35 years I have taught medical students and surgical trainees and have been enriched by the experience of involvement in the process of dying of thousands of patients. I have assisted many.

The titles under which I will address the bill before us tonight are doctors, diagnosis, depression, dying, duty to die and death. The training of a doctor commences generally on matriculation from high school at the age of 17 or 18. Quotas are applied and less than five per cent of the top matriculants enter the study of medicine, which usually takes six years until graduation, with a further two years of hospital training before registration to practice.

Most matriculants are idealistic and strongly motivated to serve their fellow man. Their eight years of training emphasises the preservation and prolongation of life—death being the ultimate enemy. On graduation, by tradition all subscribe, at least in theory, to the oath of Hippocrates, which states that no medicine be given that will cause the death of the patient.

Doctors, nonetheless, are human beings. They are subject to the same frailties as their fellow man. In fact, in many respects they suffer more. The majority are quite outstanding and held in very high regard by the community. However, there is a high social morbidity and mortality among doctors. Not only do they have a higher suicide rate but also there is a greater degree of alcoholism, drug dependency and marital breakdown than any other professional group. In essence, they are more dysfunctional.

Last year was the fiftieth anniversary of the Nuremberg war crimes tribunal, where 23 physicians and scientists were accused, amongst other matters, of euthanasia. In every profession there are some who are incompetent and inevitably a few who are venal and dangerous. It is in this category that I would put those who believe that killing can be justified by higher motives, just as those physicians and scientists did during the Second World War.

Those 23 physicians were accused, amongst other matters, of euthanasia of undesirable racial groups. Sixteen were found guilty and seven were sentenced to death by hanging. It is chilling to know that the main Australian proponent today is a doctor who pleads similar higher motives. It is important to note that the Australian Medical Association, the nursing profession and the overwhelming majority of the caring professions are opposed to euthanasia.

Forty‐five years ago, I attended a debate on abortion. A speaker forecast that the introduction of abortion would inevitably lead to the legalisation of euthanasia. I scoffed. In retrospect I apologise to that speaker.

Implemental steps may be slow but they are inevitable: the first step, voluntary euthanasia; the second step, involuntary euthanasia; the third step, euthanasia for specified purposes. There is only one way to prevent the slide down the slippery slope, and that is not to get on it in the first place. It is important that we stop now.

BREAK.PARA: My second `d' is diagnosis. Before a doctor is authorised to kill, he or she must be certain of the diagnosis, that the patient is incurable and is terminally ill. I can tell you of a number of patients who have satisfied these criteria but in whom the diagnosis was wrong. One patient of mine had fluid on the lungs and fluid in the abdomen, an abdominal exploration was positive and her body was wasting. She was admitted for terminal care yet inexplicably recovered. A review of the microscopic material showed that the pathologist had made a mistake in his interpretation of the cells. I have seen that on a number of occasions. Fortunately, they are rare.

Pathologists are as fallible as others. You will recall a recent compensation case involving a young woman with melanoma secondaries where the diagnosis was wrong on the histological evidence, and last year another woman had an incorrect papanicolaou smear report. I have personally done a mastectomy on the basis of a frozen section report which was subsequently shown to be incorrect. Similar errors can occur in the interpretation of cat scans or magnetic resonance imaging scans—plain X-rays, even. No doctor is infallible, nor are two. Diagnosis is often difficult. It is no coincidence that a doctor, no matter how eminent or world renowned, can give only an opinion.

I queried the diagnosis on the first patient killed under the Northern Territory legislation by asking whether an autopsy had been performed. I discovered that the legislation was flawed and the body could not be disposed of initially because nobody had considered the fact that a death certificate could not be issued at the time, as the patient had not died of natural causes.

These are the legislators upon whom we are relying for legalised killing. There is no doubt that the legislation was flawed, yet the proponents of the Northern Territory legislation are asking the upper house of the federal parliament to legitimise flawed legislation.

Dying is the last great challenge of life. For some it is abrupt, but for the majority it is prolonged. In my experience it is a great privilege to be given the knowledge that one has time to prepare for death. The process has best been described by Elisabeth Kubler-Ross in her book On Death and Dying. She describes five stages: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and finally acceptance. The penultimate stage is depression, and it is at this stage that the dying person is most vulnerable—both to themselves and to outside influences.

You will recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, that a seminar on suicide was held recently in Parliament House. It was apparent that the two essential components of suicide are depression and social disruption. Depression is insidious. Kubler-Ross describes two components, the first reactive and the second preparatory—a part of the grief that the terminally patient has to undergo in order to prepare for final separation from this world.

One of the bizarre features—and I speak from experience—that a doctor experienced in the care of the dying observes is premature grief in loved ones prior to the decease of the person dying. At this stage there can be enormous self-imposed pressures on the dying person to end it all and relieve the distress of their close relatives and their loved ones. This is referred to as `duty-to-die'.

In essence, voluntary euthanasia is medically assisted suicide. Suicide can also be the way an individual regains control of his or her own life by ending it. Professor Pierre Baume of the Australian Institute of Suicide Prevention says this may be summed up in a sentence: `I'll control my own destiny; I won't let you control my destiny.'

The proponents of euthanasia, as a last throw of the dice, brought in a spurious argument that doctors are already killing by subterfuge, an argument that it is already occurring but not regulated. I would ask the proponents to produce the evidence. I can assure the Senate it does not exist. I have been president or chairman of all the major medical organisations in my state of Queensland, stretching from President of the University of Queensland Medical Students Association, President of the Resident Medical Officers Association, Chairman of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, Chairman of the Australian Association of Surgeons and, prior to entering the Senate, President of the Queensland branch of the Australian Medical Association. I have never seen it. I would ask those who propound that statement to produce the evidence. It does not exist. I know it does not exist. It does not occur. I have written to the proponents asking them for the evidence.

I remind all senators that this is a conscience vote. This is the first time in my nearly seven years in the Senate that this has occurred. I understand that the last time it occurred was nearly 20 years ago. I am sure that all of us will exercise that vote considering above all else our own conscience. On that note, I end with a Shakespearian quote—I ask all to consider it:
This above all:
To thine own self be true
And it must follow, as the night the day
Thou canst not then be false to any man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking at the merit of the Euthanasia Laws Bill, which is before the Senate today, I have been influenced by three differing perspectives. The first is a personal perspective: the death of a close family member in recent times. The second was a clearer, more deliberate form of reasoning based upon specific conclusions derived from the consideration of general issues involved in the euthanasia debate. The third was the huge amount of correspondence received in my office. Some of this correspondence in quite stark terms addressed the real issues at the heart of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the first issue: in the last 12 months a member of my family died from a longstanding illness associated with cancer. An uncle died in great pain after long suffering. His death was a release to his family. I witnessed and was informed of his great pain, his movement in and out of consciousness, the distress felt by his wife and children, the searching for false hope to relieve the pain and stress.

I was also touched by this man's strength of character to accept death, his desire and that of his family and friends to put aside longstanding disagreements and estrangement and come together to share his final days. I observed his rapprochement with sons and brothers and the putting aside of past hates. I observed how his children put time aside to spend hours simply sitting and talking with their father and how they came to accept death as a natural event. Finally I saw how all of those people drew strength and love from the act of sharing time with him in the final days of their father's illness.

It would not surprise me for some to argue that we should have hastened his death to avoid his suffering. It is a superficially attractive but still an essentially simplistic argument. It is an argument that goes to the core of the euthanasia debate, but it is not an argument that I could draw a general principle that justifies state legislation to authorise a third party to engage in the activity of intentional killing—because that is the current practice as authorised under the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act in the Northern Territory.

As outlined in the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report, the Northern Territory act expressly authorises a patient in the course of a terminal illness experiencing pain, suffering or distress to request a doctor to assist the patient to terminate the patient's life. The act further provides that those persons who participate in the process shall not be subject to criminal or civil action or professional discipline.

Similarly, the intent of the Euthanasia Laws Bill is clear. The bill removes the power under the self-government acts of the three territories to enact laws which permit the form of intentional killing called euthanasia or the assisting of a person to terminate his or her life. The bill also provides that the three territories shall have power to make laws with respect to traditional treatment as behaviour develops over time associated with terminal illnesses. So, notwithstanding the interesting discussion in chapter 4 about legal issues and the submissions made by a range of eminent jurists and QCs, the intent of both the Northern Territory act and the Euthanasia Laws Bill are reasonably clear to this particular layman.

So, having somewhat briefly dispensed with the arcane legal arguments, one can address the issue in terms of broad principle. The Northern Territory act expressly gives the power and hence a licence to membership of one group in our society to engage in the activity of legalised homicide. Doctors, medical practitioners, are apparently so special, so wise, so well-informed and so across complex moral and ethical issues that the state in the form of the Northern Territory government has issued them with a licence to engage in a form of killing.

This raises the fundamental issue of the appropriate divide between the state and the individual. All over the world we see government in retreat. It is said that the market is supreme. There is no role for state assistance, state regulation, state involvement. Corporations are privatising, the labour market is deregulated and Australian companies are required to compete on unequal playing fields. Welfare assistance to families is withdrawn and age pensions apparently are to become an individual responsibility. In nearly all other fields of activity the state is winding back its influence at a rate of knots inconceivable 20 years ago.

Yet in parts of Australia the role of the state is so paramount that 5,000 years of recorded history, both East and West, is to be turned upon its head. I am greatly troubled by this paradigm shift of power. Individual freedom is a precious right. Few citizens and few countries enjoy it to an absolute degree. Time and time again we hear of abuses of power by governments, bureaucracies, state agencies and security forces. Quite properly we are troubled by the intervention of the state in our bedrooms. Quite properly that issue is the subject of real discussion in our society, yet that issue is not resolved. There is no consensus viewpoint. Yet the Northern Territory Act sanctions the killing of our citizens by other citizens whose only qualification is that they are medical practitioners.

In the Senate there are a number of doctors: Dr Brown, Dr Herron, Dr Eggleston, Dr Crowley. The former Senator Woods is a cancer specialist. They all bring widely different philosophic viewpoints to a range of debates, all make worthwhile contributions, but none, with due respect, are so wise and so on top of complex ethical issues that the state should presume to licence them to be an arbiter of life or death. So the act of the Northern Territory government or any other government in licensing doctors to assist in the killing of terminally ill patients is something I find greatly worrying, deeply offensive and a cause for real concern for the future.

Having stated a major problem with state intervention or state licence in this matter, one needs to inevitably consider the issue of other groups in our society. That of course needs to be done in context. We all know that medical costs, drug costs, costs of nursing homes and costs of training doctors, nurses and health professionals are rising dramatically and in some cases almost exponentially. We know that pension and aged care costs are on the rise. We know the work force is contracting in relative terms. We know that the taxation base is dwindling.

Paradoxically, there are increased demands for provision of new government services. Soon, governments will say, `There is no more. We will not levy additional taxation.' Economists, if they are not doing it already, in the not too distant future will cost the provision of service to the dependent or needy groups. If doctors can assist the death of the terminally ill, others will argue that we should assess the contribution of these other groups. Some will suggest this argument is fanciful. Why should the legislation not apply to retarded persons, paraplegic and quadriplegic individuals, persons with debilitating illnesses, persons suffering from mental diseases? The list is potentially endless. If the state has the right to sanction and authorise the killing or death of one group of citizens, it seems to me that that is an absolute right and can be extended to other groups in our society. In this debate, we cannot have relative rights.

Once you cross the line of absolute prohibition in the taking of another's life, you cannot, in my view, attempt to restrict that absolute right. Logically it is a contradictory position. There is either an absolute right for the state to legislate to licence the killers of its own citizens or there is not. I for one will vote against giving the state that absolute right.

In this context, I wish to make two other observations: firstly, the issue of palliative care and, secondly, the rights of groups who might be affected by this debate in the future. I was greatly helped in my deliberations by the Senate discussion on palliative care in chapter 6 of the report. Paragraph 6.74 stated that palliative care is the active, total care of patients whose disease is not responsive to curative treatment. Control of pain, of other symptoms and of other psychological, social and spiritual problems is paramount. The goal is the achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families. Dr Smith from the Australian Association of Hospice and Palliative Care made the following points: palliative care is a developing treatment and there is much confusion about what palliative care is and how it is provided.

The level of knowledge or skill required to effectively manage the symptoms of people in such dire circumstances that they seek euthanasia is still not achieved by enough medical practitioners. The availability of euthanasia in such cases can lead to an undertreatment of such symptoms and an overall worsening of the quality of life. Basically Dr Smith submitted that the introduction of euthanasia legislation will paradoxically worsen the quality of life and care of the very group it is attempting to aid.

Another report in the field of palliative care explained that suffering when dying takes two forms. Firstly, there are organic problems such as pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation and depression. With very few exceptions, Dr Smith reported, all of these problems can be handled satisfactorily by an expert palliative care team. Secondly, there are existential problems in loss of self‐worth, loss of control, fear, guilt, anger and resentment. According to Professor Ravenscroft, it is the second group of problems that lead patients to request euthanasia more often than the pain does. Dr Smith went on to explain that this caused problems for doctors, as they were often not adequately trained to deal with these most difficult issues. However, these problems can be addressed by skills, such as counselling, which many doctors have not been taught or have not been able to master.

Indeed, the evidence shows that requests for euthanasia are extremely rare when concerted efforts are made to alleviate physical, spiritual and emotional suffering. According to the evidence, requests for euthanasia are usually a call for help rather than a call for euthanasia itself. Even Professor Baume acknowledged that for 95 per cent of people palliative care is very effective and it is a developing technique.

Our society should be allocating resources to get that figure up from 95 per cent to as near as is humanly possible to the absolute figure. It is incorrect to say that the two, three, four or five per cent who are not totally assisted by palliative care do not gain any relief. They gain some relief. As Dr Smith explained:
The group of people who do not get complete relief of their symptoms do receive a proportionate degree of relief.

In 95 per cent of cases, palliative care is a complete answer and, in the remaining cases, which is an absolutely declining figure, there is some relief. This is a powerful argument alone for supporting the bill.

In the context of alternative solutions for those who face terminal illness, I was struck by the nature of the argument for the rejection of the bill before the parliament. The correspondence received in my electorate office reflected the summarised arguments for euthanasia in chapter 6 of the report. As I considered the correspondence, I was struck by the analogy with the capital punishment debate. Often I was influenced by the argument of putting to death an innocent person. Indeed, the investigations of the current inquiry in New South Wales suggest that a significant number of senior and powerful people routinely lie to achieve their purpose. I think it would be a remarkable conclusion that police officers, lawyers and judges have not conspired in the past to wrongly convict accused persons. We are fortunate that capital punishment is no longer on our statute books.

Essentially, the argument concerning euthanasia comes down to five: individual rights, choice, compassion and death with dignity, legalising common practice, and moral equivalence. Those arguments have varying degrees of strength, the weakest in my view being that of legalising common practice. The Senate committee did not report any empirical evidence to support this argument and I suspect it is argued more often that it is practised. I draw some support for this view from the rigorous, consistent and continuing opposition expressed in surveys which show significant doctor opposition to the practice of euthanasia.

Similarly, the view of the AMA on behalf of doctors was strongly opposed to the legalisation of euthanasia, which suggests the argument for common practice is not as strong as its proponents suggest. Indeed, apart from a number of pro‐euthanasia lobby groups and like organisations, I was repeatedly struck by the lack of any widespread publicly supported move for legalising euthanasia. In the bulk of correspondence received in my office, approximately 50 private submissions out of 1,500 argued a pro‐euthanasia position. That is quite a revealing statistic.

The various pro‐euthanasia societies basically address the issue from a philosophic or ethical perspective. A small number of individuals wrote opposing the Andrews' bill principally because they had observed suffering of a family member. If these two groups are removed from the debate, I am left with the question: who is actually in favour of legalising euthanasia? I am unable to give a clear response to that question. In response, I conclude that I do not know that a lot of terminally ill people do wish to die. The extent of demand for palliative care treatments and its evident high success rate suggests there is little public or private clamour for legalising euthanasia.

I suspect people do not want to die. I suspect people want medical treatment, want palliative care and want the state to provide a viable public health system to help in their dire moment of need. These are logical and sensible positions for people to hold. I suspect the great mass of Australians would favour further public assistance to help those people. Indeed, legalising euthanasia is a concern because it sends a message to a lot of Australians that their life is no longer worth anything.

In the last six months alone, there has been a developing debate about youth suicide and, in particular, young male teenage suicide. The evidence suggests that these boys killed themselves because, like a character from a Camus novel, they have no hope, they feel totally isolated, they feel alone and without parental community or societal support. Because they are alone, they feel stressed, depressed and unable to see a way through the mire of their own hopelessness. How are they any different from the terminally ill? If state assisted homicide is good enough for the terminally ill, why should not the state assist those young men and women who want to choose to end their own lives? Both have their roots in the same cause: isolation, depression, tension, stress, an inability to cope. In reality, both are making pleas for help, pleas for assistance. Both are saying that they want to be part of our community. They are not sending a plea to help end their lives. They are sending this plea—help make my life worthwhile. That is a most reasonable request.

Passage of this bill in the most minor way sends a message to those young boys and girls that their life, all life, is important. It is not beyond the realms of possibility to comprehend a situation where children might apply oblique pressure on parents to do the right thing for their own financial gain. Independent terminally ill people might place less value on their lives than others because of stress or isolation.

Finally, in this context, one should address the question of opinion polls. They show that around 75 per cent of people favour euthanasia. I suspect that high affirmative response relates to the wording of the question. A differently phrased question or one with more detail or explanation might result in a different answer.

Similarly, I have been struck by the different voting responses in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The bill under debate today, and during this week, passed through the House by 88 to 35 on third reading. I am told that the vote in the Senate will probably be a margin of one to four votes. Why is there such a difference in the two Houses? My suspicion is that lower House members have reacted to community pressure and lobbying and senators by and large are able to be guided by their own consciences on this debate.

In summary, I support this bill because it is a small step toward achieving community responsibility and community obligation. It treats all citizens the same and does not draw a distinction between those who are terminally ill and the remainder of the population. It does not draw a distinction between citizens of the Northern Territory and the rest of Australia. Finally, and most importantly, it limits the power of the state in an area in which the state has no role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senators Herron and Bishop, I support the Euthanasia Laws Bill. My reasons for doing so are more than adequately set out in the advice to the Senate which was included in the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee's report which I signed, along with 12 other senators. I do not want to take up the Senate's time by expanding unduly on the reasons why the 13 of us who signed that believe that this bill should be passed.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to take the opportunity to say that it does not give me any pleasure at all to be voting in favour of a Commonwealth bill to override an otherwise valid law of the Northern Territory. I am, in principle, very much a federalist and that is one of the reasons I am in the Senate. I am never very favourably disposed to Commonwealth laws which seek to override the otherwise valid laws of states and territories.

In that context, I was disappointed by some of the speeches in the House of Representatives which treated the Northern Territory with contempt, which sought to belittle that jurisdiction. I personally have a very great regard for the Northern Territory, for the achievements of the people and the recent governments since self‐government and I am very optimistic about their territory's future, indeed so optimistic that one could say that the state of South Australia was very unwise to give the Northern Territory away to the Commonwealth in the earlier history of this federation.

BREAK.PARA: I also have a very great regard for Chief Minister Shane Stone who I think has done a superlative job as chief minister. I have known him for many years and knew him well when he was President of the CLP in the Northern Territory. So I certainly mean no slight whatsoever to the territory in indicating my support for this bill, but we have here a bill passed by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly which does apply to every Australian.

Some may be under the misapprehension that the Northern Territory legislation applies only to Northern Territorians; it does not. Every Australian is affected by it. Already a resident of my state of South Australia has been killed under the provisions of this law. In relation to this issue of states' rights the fact is, whether the territory or the rest of us like it or not, the territory is not yet a state. I believe and hope that one day that will occur but the fact is it is not a state, it is a territory. That is its constitutional position and it is a territory for which the Commonwealth has responsibility. In the case of this most extraordinary law it is my view that that responsibility must be exercised.

We should also remember that this was a law passed by only one vote in the single chamber of the Northern Territory parliament, the Legislative Assembly. One of the strongest and most persuasive speeches against the Northern Territory law was given by none other than the Chief Minister, Shane Stone. I think it is worth referring briefly to his speech which some have overlooked. On 24 May 1995 in the Legislative Assembly he said:
Some believe that both practices, of assisted suicide and euthanasia, are morally wrong and should not be allowed . . . I am firmly in this category.

What the member for Fannie Bay's private bill proposes is to transform the right to decide about medical treatment into a far broader right to control the timing and manner of death. I am firmly of the persuasion that the dangers of such a dramatic change in public policy would far outweigh any possible benefits.

The simple fact is that there is a huge difference between helping a person to die as opposed to killing someone. I believe that distinction has been lost on the proponents of the bill. The moment that you legalise doctors killing their patients, even with their consent and with benevolent motives, you cross an important threshold. You debase the currency of human life. The potential for error and abuse, the risk to vulnerable individuals and the profound effect on society's values present the most compelling reasons against allowing assisted suicide and euthanasia.

I could not possibly say it any better than Shane Stone did in the debate in the parliament of the Northern Territory. I agree completely with him. I was going to say something about opinion polls, that being something with which I am extremely familiar through professional practice but Senator Bishop has put it as well as I could.

I think the alleged support for euthanasia is support for the right to be allowed to die. I think that is the way people are interpreting the question that was put to them. I do not believe that there is popular support for legislation allowing doctors to kill patients. If we are going to take public opinion as our guide in this we would be all supporting capital punishment because polls consistently show that a majority of Australians support capital punishment. I do not notice those who rely on public opinion polls to support euthanasia also advocating capital punishment.

I would also like to briefly place on record my concern about the effects of the Northern Territory law on Aboriginal health in the territory, given my particular responsibility in native title. That subject is of concern to me. We are all well aware of the magnitude of the problems of Aboriginal health across this country, but particularly in the Northern Territory. The Senate committee report provides, in my view, overwhelming evidence that this law could do untold damage to our efforts to improve Aboriginal health. There is quite a compelling section in there about the person hired by the Northern Territory government to talk to Aborigines about this euthanasia law who strongly recommends that the bill be repealed because of the potential for it to have disastrous effects on efforts to improve Aboriginal health. I would have thought that for people like Senator Brown that alone should be a very compelling reason to think seriously about whether this bill should be supported.

This is a very difficult issue for all of us. It is one of those rare occasions when we are able to exercise a conscience vote. It is not easy for me as someone who does in principle believe in the right of lesser jurisdictions to make valid laws. But in this case I must, as a matter of conscience, support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I too welcome the opportunity to speak to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. I indicate from the outset that I intend to support this bill. It has not been an easy decision because I do not know of any other matter that has been brought before this parliament on which my colleagues and I have received so much personal correspondence.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the correspondence was in the way of form letters, but there were many individual letters written to me and my office citing individual cases and expressing both sides of the argument. For that reason, this is a very difficult decision. It is not difficult for me to make because I have felt the same way since the bill was first introduced, but it is difficult because of the amount of feeling that has been put into that correspondence by the various people holding a variety of views.

This point was made even more closely last Friday night. I attended a function at which a relation of mine who was down from Katherine in the Northern Territory asked me, `Why would you seek to overturn the Northern Territory's right to legislate for itself?' I said, `It is very simple. I wouldn't do that but neither do you, as territorians, have a right to legislate for all other Australians and, on this particular case, on a life and death matter.' If the Northern Territory had chosen to pass this legislation and to have it apply to only Northern Territory citizens or citizens who had resided in the Northern Territory for a period of time, I would have much more difficulty in supporting this bill. That is one right that I do believe they have.

However, because this legislation has been passed in the Northern Territory and because, as my colleague Senator Minchin has said, of those people who have availed themselves of the legislation I think only one was a territorian and the rest have been people from other states in Australia, my conscience dictates that I should support this bill. The Northern Territory has passed legislation on a life and death matter to legislate for every other Australian.

Just over 20 years ago I watched my father die in considerable pain. That was before the days when palliative care of the quality that is now available was available to patients. At no stage did I ever think that my father would have wished to end his own life. I know that does not apply to every single situation. But I am concerned and my own conscience is that the law as it is put forward—and as I think has been put so ably by Senator Bishop previously regarding the many matters that he raised in his speech—is such that there is no way that I could not support the Andrews's bill. That bill overturns the legislation which was passed in the Northern Territory; legislation which now applies to all Australians as it stands. They can if they want to go to the Northern Territory without spending any time there as residents of the Northern Territory and avail themselves of the euthanasia legislation and be participants in voluntary euthanasia.

I understand the feelings of those who feel differently about this matter from the way that I do. Strong feelings have been expressed from both sides of the argument on this issue. As I said previously, I like many others have received more correspondence on this issue than any other. However, at the end of the day, as this is a conscience vote and as we have been asked to exercise our own consciences on this very important matter, my conscience dictates that I must support the Euthanasia Laws Bill, or what is otherwise known as the Andrews bill.

As I indicated at the start of my speech, I intend to support this bill. I know that by Thursday night a lot of speeches will be made on a variety of issues—some emotional, some perhaps less emotional, some from people who feel very strongly about this issue and some from people who do not feel so strongly. Some will still be making up their minds as to which way they will vote, although I think they are very few in number. But I know that there are still one or two people who are not sure which way they should vote in this matter.

BREAK.PARA: I hope during the next three nights when this bill is being debated that it will be debated in a rational manner. I hope that people will express their own convictions and let the Senate know the way their conscience dictates that they should vote. When we come to the final vote after the debate on the second reading stage is finished, I hope that vote is respected in the knowledge that every senator who has cast their vote on this will have done so as their conscience dictates that they must.

I did not intend to speak for very long because I know that there is a considerable number of speakers on this bill, and the opportunity to get some of these speeches completed tonight is a bonus to our program. I thank the Senate for the opportunity for expressing my point of view in this matter. Once again, I indicate that I will be supporting the euthanasia bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that I will be voting to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. Because this is a conscience vote and I understand that this happens very rarely in the Senate, I indicate that I came to this debate and the consideration of this matter not as a politician, not as a lawyer, not as a doctor but as a human being. I simply wanted to consider the matter in the quiet of my own conscience and to ultimately come to a decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Like many other senators, I have had hundreds if not a thousand letters in my office urging me to vote one way or the other. I will not pretend not to admit that many of these letters presented some compelling circumstances for voting one way or the other. But I have made up my mind to support the bill for probably four main reasons. The first reason is a fundamental belief that we should not allow one person to decide whether or not the life of another human being should end. I simply cannot take the decision to allow that to pass into legislation, which is why I will support the bill to overturn the Northern Territory legislation.

Secondly, like Senator Ferguson, I believe that even though I am a strong supporter of federation, it is wrong for a state or territory to impose a law on the rest of the country. This is no ordinary legislation. It deals with the most fundamental question which every person in this chamber and every person in this nation ultimately faces, and that is the question of life and death.

As politicians, we have had many messages from Northern Territory parliamentarians, including one message which arrived today saying that this debate is not about active voluntary euthanasia but about states rights. I beg to differ. With great respect, I must say that this debate is about life and death, and it must be in the federal context and in the interests of this nation that we consider this question.

As I said, I did receive in my office an overwhelming number of letters, and some of them certainly presented compelling cases. I have experienced enough of life to know that, if it is deemed necessary to end a person's life by decision of the person involved, it is possible for that decision to be taken and implemented usually by a passive choice for action, in that action is not taken to prolong life. I understand that it is the choice of many compassionate doctors and probably many patients who feel that they are unable to go on living in the way that they are.

But to take an active decision to kill someone is not something that I can contemplate. I am also enough of a cynic to believe that unscrupulous relatives will take advantage of a person in a weakened physical state to end that person's life and thereby gain advantage for themselves. I know this is not an argument that usually is advanced against euthanasia. But certainly many of the crime histories that one reads in the newspapers and the way in which elderly people can be dealt with most unfortunately in this modern society of 1997 lead me to believe that many people would take advantage of that particular position.

I also believe, with Senator Bishop, that to acquiesce in the Northern Territory legislation sends a most unfortunate message to the youth of our society. Many of them, through circumstances totally beyond their control, feel that work is meaningless because they have none, families are meaningless because they have none and, ultimately, their life is meaningless—and so they may decide to deprive themselves of that life. Youth suicide is one of the most alarming problems that we have to face in our society. To undertake any moves, certainly by parliament or by the territory legislature, which I consider would encourage that are only to be deplored. We need to inspire in our young people a capacity to enjoy life to the fullest and to the longest, and to make the most of the life that they have. To acquiesce in the Northern Territory legislation would totally negate that.
As I said, a decision which is taken actively to end life is a decision with which I cannot agree. Therefore, I will be voting to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of the orderly conduct of the business of the Senate, I too will be brief. If time permitted, there are many more points I would wish to make, even though many of these undoubtedly will be made by other speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I speak in this debate at all is that I believe the people of Australia—each one of whom at some point in their lives may be affected in some way or another, either personally or through the suffering of a beloved family member or friend—have the right to know why each of us here in this chamber votes in a particular way on this intensely sensitive and emotional issue: an issue that embraces our role both as individuals and as collective members of society; and an issue that embraces our views on the sanctity of life and whether we as human beings have the right to choose the moment of our passing from this life.

It is a debate that in many respects goes to the very core of our human beingness. It is a debate that embraces our religious beliefs. It is a debate that must pay due regard to the constitutional position of the federal, state and territory legislatures. It also is a debate about whether any government has the moral or other right to legislate with respect to the right of any human being to seek death by other than natural causes. Even if one answers yes to this fundamental latter question, there is then the further fundamental question of whether such a law can be administered and monitored in a way that ensures the more vulnerable in our society are not left even more vulnerable.

Each of these issues and questions can be, and is, argued persuasively by the proponents of opposite points of view. Vast tracts of complex legal, medical, ethical and philosophical discourses have been written on them. None of them can be judged unequivocally to provide an unambiguous answer.

I can only cast my vote on the Euthanasia Laws Bill on the basis of how I feel and what I feel is the right approach. You can argue the legalities and the complexities until you are blue in the face. But these are to no avail on such a deeply personal and emotional issue, unless you feel deep inside you that the decision you take is the one you believe in as a human being. On that basis, I indicate that I will vote for the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 because to do otherwise would for me be to deny the sanctity of life itself.

BREAK.PARA: Let me also hasten to say, however, that I fully respect the equally deeply held views of many of those who take the opposing approach. I also want to say to my friends in the Northern Territory who oppose the bill because they believe it tramples on their rights as territorians to determine their own laws, that I understand their position, which is one I would generally fully support—even though in this particular instance there is no doubt that the federal parliament has the constitutional right to pass the Euthanasia Laws Bill.

But the issues in this bill go far beyond federal, state and territory considerations. They go to the heart of what I believe to be the very essence of a civilised, compassionate society—and that is that life is sacred, and that no-one has the right to take another's life, even if the person whose life is at issue wishes it to be done.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 11 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Wlll the Minister accede to a suggestion, made on 7 February 1997 in an article entitled `Lawyers delay Hong Kong refugees expulsion' on page 7 of the Australian, by Hong Kong Human Rights lawyer, Pam Baker, that Australia allow Vietnamese boat people who are detained in Hong Kong, as economic migrants, to make application to come to Australia under the limited family reunion program.

(2) Do any of the remaining 7 000 boat people have relatives in Australia; if so, what were the reasons that these people did not take advantage of the previous Government's offer to re-settle the Vietnamese boat people in Australia if they returned to Vietnam first.
(3) Does the government have any plans or proposals to further assist the Hong Kong authorities to remove the 7 000 from that territory prior to its return to Chinese sovereignty on 1 July 1997.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Hong Kong's boat person population under the now terminated Comprehensive Plan of Action (CPA) currently numbers 4,517 persons who were screened out and therefore found not to be refugees and 1,346 persons who either arrived before 16 June 1988 or arrived after that date and were screened in as refugees and are eligible for resettlement under the CPA. As a party to the CPA, Australia encourages Vietnamese boat people found not to be refugees to return to Vietnam.

Hong Kong, unlike other first asylum countries under the CPA, allows screened out boat people to apply to migrate to a third country. A small number, principally spouses, have migrated to Australia. It is unlikely that there are many remaining in the camp who would be eligible to migrate to Australia under the family reunion program.

(2) The number of boat people in Hong Kong with relatives in Australia is not available, but it is believed to be small. I am unable to speculate why these people did not take advantage of the previous Government's offer to resettle them in Australia if they returned to Vietnam. (To be eligible for this program persons needed to return to Vietnam before 1 January 1996.)
(3) The Government has no plans or proposals under consideration to assist the Hong Kong authorities to remove the screened out population.

At the request of UNHCR, Australia is considering a small number of cases from the remaining population of 1,346 people who are eligible to be resettled. To be accepted they will need to meet Australia's stringent health and character requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been a decision made by the Government to remove the right of appeal by disability support pensioners from the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; if such a decision has not yet been made, does the Government intend emoving this right of appeal.
(2) If the Government is to remove this right of appeal, will this be through legislation, regulation or some other method.
(3) Is the Government aware of the often poor quality of medical reports made available to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
(4) Are there any plans to improve the quality of these reports.

(5) Have there been any reductions in federal funding which have affected the ability of appellants to seek redress through the Social Security Appeals Tribunal or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
(6) Have reductions in legal aid funding affected these appeals processes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been no decision to remove the right of appeal by disability support pensioners, or any other Department of Social Security customers, from the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

An independent review of the Social Security Review and appeals system is currently being undertaken by the Hon Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The terms of reference of the review include an examination of the number of levels of review within the Social Security portfolio, the impact of review and appeal decisions on the quality and efficiency of decision-making by DSS staff, the operation, membership and powers of the SSAT and whether or not there should be a right of appeal to the AAT. Dame Margaret has been asked to report on these matters by May 1997.
(2) Any decision to remove or amend the right of appeal of Social Security customers to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would require legislative amendment.

(3) Customers claiming Disability Support Pension (DSP), or subject to a medical review of their DSP, are required to obtain a report from their treating doctor. In many cases a report is also sought from an Australian Government Health Service (AGHS) Medical Officer following a medical examination. The reports supplied by treating doctors will vary in their quality and usefulness. Reports supplied by AGHS Medical Officers are usually of a high standard.

(4) The Department of Social Security liaises closely with the AGHS to ensure the highest possible quality of medical reports provided in respect of DSS customers. New versions of DSP Treating Doctor Report forms have also been developed following consultations with DSS staff and the medical community. These are currently being trialed in South Australia and Western Australia and, following further refinement, are expected to be released shortly. This new form is expected to improve the overall quality of the reports.

(5 & 6) Federal funding for legal aid is a matter for the Attorney-General's portfolio. Very few customers who appeal to the SSAT or AAT use legal representation or have been granted legal aid in recent years and any changes in legal aid arrangements will therefore have little, if any, overall impact.
